description:
This is my go-to place when I want something cheap, fast and delicious.  I'd recommend the spring rolls as an appetizer and spicy calamari, vermicelli or soup as a main course.  I think most of the stuff seems pretty healthy, which is always a plus.

This isn't the place to go if you're looking for an elegant dining experience.  It is super casual and the food comes out within five minutes of ordering.  It gets pretty crowded for dinner on weekends but is perfect during the week.
author: Lauren R.

description:
OK. So I was torn about what to order. I peeked at Yelp and saw some folks saying "Don't get the pho." and other saying "I loved the pho here" Well, my stomach was feeling a little off and nothing helps that more than a steaming bowl of Pho Ga (chicken pho) so that's what I ordered . . .

Don't make the same mistake I did. The broth was lukewarm and tasteless and the chicken hard and dry. How can chicken in soup be dry you ask? Well, I'm wondering that myself. Maybe the beef pho is better.

The rice plates that other tables were getting looked pretty tasty as did the bun bowl that went to another table than mine. I'll have to come back and see if Sunflower can redeem themselves.
author: Andrew C.

description:
This place is tricky. I stood on Valencia waiting and she stood on 16th waiting, and it took us two phone calls to ascertain that there were two sister establishtments of the same name around the corner from each other. (Crap, which listing is this?!) If you're coming to impress, stick with Valencia. Just be prepared for the arrival bell to clang, and when they don't meet or greet ya at the door it's hard not to shrink under the spotlight as the collective fauxhemian heads raise from their glowing piles of vermicelli and steaming pho.

But yeah, the food's tasty, if not "one-dimensional." (That's my default description for boring but palatable.) The veggie Imperial roll had a satisfying crisp, and chunks of juicy mushrooms. And the noodles! Where would Vietnamese be without the ubiquitous and delicious thin rice noodle? Not in my belly, that's for sure. This version was slightly overdone and lacking in the fresh herbs that I love so much. Fragrant and soothing, the jasmine tea provided a lovely wash at the end.

If they weren't trying to boot us out the door so dern quickly, (dirt cheap gotta have that turnover, hmm?) we might have even stayed for dessert.
author: Ligaya T.

description:
Can I give minus stars? Let me start by saying that I have only rated places on Yelp where I was extremely impressed or extremely insulted...

So on an early Wednesday night you wouldn't expect a place to be so crowded, but despite that, there was only one waiter covering the whole floor. He seemed like this was normal, so it didn't look like a problem...the thing is, the problem wasn't that it was too crowded...it was the just the WORST service I (and my friend who was visiting from Europe) had ever received in both of our lives. 

First, while I was in the middle of giving this jerk my order, he walked away and I had to aks him to come back so we could finish ordering.

Then, when my friend said he wan't ordering food, just tea, he yelled at him like he was inulsted (excuse me, it's just a divey joint serving the same stuff you can get all over the city, it's no exclusive joint sserving gourmet anything).

Then he brought the check while I was still eating and stood there for a second waiting for me to pay him...who does that!? I ignored him and continued eating...

The he came right back to check if I had put money in the bill-holder...I hadn't yet, so he slammed it down to hurry us up. I continued eating...He came back again and took the bill-holder I guess thinking I had paid, but my money was still on the table. He came back and said, "You didn't pay," to which I responded, "Because you walked away before I could give you my money."

Then I put my money down for him, because at that point wew just wanted to get out of there. He says, "It's $9.30." I say, "I know. I gave you exact change"...I had put down a $5 bill, four $1 bills, a quarter and 5 pennies. He says, "You can spend your pennies somehere else, we don't accept them." I thought he just meant that he would accept the $9.25 and not worry about the stupid 5 cents. OH NO! He then says, "You owe 5 more cents!" Obviously, at this point we can't believe this is happening, so I tell him I already paid. He continues with this crap about not accepting pennies and wants 5 more cents...so we walked out (having paid our bill in full). 

I'd really like to know if anyone else has ever experinces this in SF (being told they won't accept 5 cents in pennies)? What kind of crap is that!? And most importantly, how is this place so crowded during the week if this is how they treat people!?

I hope they shut down this place, because I've traveled all over the orld and never been treated that bad anywhere (even as a foreigner who doesn't always speak the local language or understand teh loacl customs).
author: kelly b.

description:
Expensive. Mediocre. Good Service.

$7.25 for 2 Shrimp Spring Rolls: Each roll had 2 shrimp, a little lettuce, and a lot of vermicelli noodle.  Yes all that for the price of an entree.

$8.50 for noodle soup.
author: Theary K.

description:
Summary based on one lunch:
--ok food
--ok service
--ok prices

So, verdict is just ok.
author: Rich H.

description: Basic, great food. Very comfortable, small place, great value. Can be a long wait, but definitely worth the wait.
author: Michael J.

description:
12-24-12
We agree.  It was  a good place but the service is terrible now.  Something is wrong.  We were regulars and we are not going back which tells you something.
Yesterday we had a meal there which was ok...a B grade.  Price is a little high for what you get but its was close by for us and usually pretty quick.  The flaming large waiter was the issue for us as well though lucky for him he did not make a scene like he did for the other post.  I know him and I would have challenged him and he would be blamed for everyone leaving.

We asked for separate checks when we ordered to make it easy for us for the standard reasons-no owing the other guy, no worries about getting paid back etc..

He  brought one ck at the end then apologized when we told him but did nothing.  
My passive friend did not  want to bother about it and changed his mind and said he did not ask for 2 checks.  I did not care EXCEPT my friend  wanted  to give me cash and have me put it on my card.  My friend would have chastised me for leaving a lower tip than he thought I should and would put more money on my tip pile-which always creates problems between us.  When we get one check my friend would add up his part to the penny and then tell me my part...to the penny which I think detracts from the dinning experience....you get the picture... separate checks are best for some.

I did not care about one check until the waiter said he could not separate the check "because the 92 year old owner would be confused".  WTF? I told him my friend had cash and I had a cc and the problem was his to fix.  The waiter looked at me like it was not an option.  ...He even said we had to pay both with cash or both with cc.-that cash and cc was not an option.  My friend decides at that moment to pull out his cc that he made me believe he did not have.  I waited for the waiter and friend find a solution  when I should have been out the door.

The waiter worked in China town on his last job.  ( he is actually Chinese not Vietnamese).  I do believe he is part of the problem.  He acts nice but  seems to make his own rules.
author: John D.

description: Been looking for good Vietnamese Restaurants around the city. Had the  lemongrass chicken lunch combo plate and the BBQ pork vermicelli with imperial rolls. My favorite place for BBQ pork vermicelli has always been Tu Lan but this place comes real close. Their imperial rolls also battle Tu Lan's. The Lemon grass chicken lunch combo was good and the portions were great without charging too much.
author: Craig G.

description:
I really love this restaurant! The food is always so good and they have awesome lunchtime specials. Lots of food for less than $7. The lemongrass chicken is really great as are these imperial rolls they have. SOOO good! 

I also really like the waitstaff there. They are really nice and serve fast. I always feel like we are "regulars" here because the same guys work there all the time. It's a great neighborhood spot :).
author: Jasmine W.

description:
Delicious pho. Literally the best in the city.

Everything else I've had there is ok. It's really the pho that sets this place apart...and the waiter who calls everyone "young man."
author: Jason K.

description: Ordered the lunch special which has spicy green beans, soup (sweet and sour), and imperial roll. Everything was delicious! Looking forward to going back for the Pho!
author: Brian S.

description:
2 words: clay pot.

Get it. You won't regret it.

I need to come back here soon to try their Pho.
author: Sam L.

description:
This restaurant is pretty awesome. They only have one server though. Everyone thinks he's a douche, but the truth is, he doesn't speak English that well and he's usually pretty busy. Homeboy's chill as fuck. Moving right along...
I usually stick with the pan fried rice noodles and prawns, but they're rare beef noodle and pho ga are pretty rad also. Definitely check them out.
author: Nikki P.

description:
Not a big fan of their banh xeo -- too fluffy, bland, and the chicken's dry. Actually I don't really care for most of their menu, since most of it's okay, but nothing worth raving. 

The only thing worth raving about are their very solid vermicelli bowls. Their vermicelli bowls (bun) are HUGE. Big enough to easily be split between two people. They don't hold back on the fish sauce, it's got all the right fishy garlicky flavors. To top it off, their imperial rolls are flavorful and meaty and somehow stay super crunchy even after drenching them in fish sauce.
author: Victoria N.

description:
I have eaten here twice. I was not impressed the first time - but the second time was great! We had the imperial rolls, the vietnamese crepe, pho, and shaken beef. 

I was very satisfied with all the food. I would not say that it was the best Pho I have ever had - but it was good enough to fill a craving. They definitely cater to the crowd that dines in the area. My favorites were the crepe dish (don't know what it is called) and the shaken beef. Yum!
author: Angelito R.

description:
Overrated.  I scanned the reviews and picked 3 of the top dishes mentioned by other yelpers:

1. The Garlic Noodles:  Many yelpers say they could "live off these noodles".  It makes me wonder if you can cook.  They were a step up above ramen: Kinda bland, nothing special.  I feel like my garlic noodles that take me 3 minutes to make taste better.  It took them less than a dollar to make it and then charged me about $10.  Naw.  Fool me once...

2.  The Shaken Beef:  Strangely tender and chewy...reminded me of cube-steak.  The sauce it was prepared in was amazing though!  So, that left me torn and a little nauseous.  Chewy beef cubes. $10.  [There was an entire salad under the beef, it made for a complete side salad so that added to the value]

3.  The Imperial  Rolls:  Probably the best i've ever had even without the sauce.  The dipping sauce was tart and tasty.  I recommend.  About $10. [came with even more lettuce and plain rice noodles]

Cost was $30.  I have leftovers so that makes it about $15 per meal.  I'd say this place's "$" reputation should be more like "$$".  Not what i'd call dirt cheap.  And, it wasn't all that great.  


My friend Art A. summed it up best:

"it was good. filling. kinda tasty. 
not great. Vietnamese? i would say kinda. kinda not. 
will i go back? sure. did i expect more? yes. 
next time i will get the pho..."
author: Jonathan B.

description: I love vietnamese food. The people who brought me here love it because the huge portions are cheap and there are several veg/vegan options. The food is not good. Ingredients didn't taste fresh, didn't have the complex flavors I know from vietnamese places. People who work here seemed tired. Place looked & smelled unappetizing.
author: JJ H.

description:
I got the tofu and veggie noodles which were just standard as u could have gotten at almost any other place that serves noodles. My bf got the garlic chicken and to say the least was disappointed. Didnt taste a thing like garlic :( 
The service was quick and impersonal so that didnt add to the already subpar experience. Possibly might try the pbo next time but even then im hesitant to even giv this place another shot. 
My advice is to pass.
author: Tamara T.

description: This place is tight. Fried rice. Delicious
author: Jonathan P.

description:
I once accidentally ordered from this location instead of the one in Potrero Hill and I was a little disappointed. I think the Potrero Hill location is much better and less greasy. 

BUT this location is close to where I work so I'll take what I can get.

Sometimes, at odd hours of the night/day, I get a craving for garlic noodles with vegetables and Sunflower is quite good at satisfying this craving. I like to call ahead so that by the time I walk over, my food is ready to go.

This place is tiny and much less done up than the Potrero Hill Sunflower. It's a tiny hole in the wall and since I've never sat down to eat here, I don't know if it really just seats about 10 people or if there's an extension further into the restaurant, beyond the narrow kitchen. There's another door to Sunflower on Valencia but I've never entered through there. Sorry for not being more helpful, Yelpers.

Anyway, I enjoy getting the garlic noodles here as well as the crab fried rice. One thing I like about Sunflower is the portion sizes! It's always enough for about three meals! 

Another plus is the waitstaff. They are quite friendly. Once, I came by to pick up an order and (silly me) did not check my box. I walked all the way back to work (about a 10 minute walk), opened the box and found brown rice and eggplant. NOT what I had in mind. So I had to walk all the way back and they apologized profusely and offered me a free drink (which is actually what I was envisioning/hoping would happen on my walk over because it was a hot day!). 

There are always people eating lunch here which I take to be a good sign. If you're craving Vietnamese and are in the Mission area, stop by Sunflower! The prices are cheap and the eats are good.
author: Christine P.

description:
Fresh, tasty food, in a cramped space in the Mission. I had the beef with imperial roll vermicelli bowl. Started off with the Vietnamese Crepe which is crisped nicely and Chicken Roll which is okay but you'd be better served with its shrimp counterpart. 

Service is efficient but gruff. The attitude seems to be order quickly, eat quickly, and get out quickly. Four stars for the food. Two for the service. Three stars overall.
author: Rajiv S.

description:
I used to love this place. I would always get the vermicelli bowl with marinated pork and fried egg rolls on top. Usually, yum. In fact this last visit was tasty, but later that day I had major cramps in my stomach.

This review is 2 stars because of the service. Of course you can't expect much from a casual place like this, but on this last visit the check was presented to us before we even got our food. The older female server said it was because they were closing and she wanted to close out her cash drawer. Fine. We paid then ate. What made it worse was when we just finished our meal, she came by and asked for the booklet which had the change in it, her tip. RUDE. We gave it to her allright, all that was left from the $20 I dropped. She deserved every penny of that 12 cents.

Also, one of the other female workers, a bus person perhaps except that she was the one that took our order, cleared a table and put her fingers in the drinking glasses in order to carry 4 cups away at once. She then proceeded to clean green beans in the dining room without washing her hands. GROSS.
author: Foodie F.

description:
Holy crap, I am in LOVE! 

I am not such a big fan of Vietnamese, but the Sunflower has made me a changed woman. 

Dan and I were late joining our party of 10, and they were nice enough to reserve a near by table so we can be close enough to talk. 

Upon arrival, we started with the Imperial Rolls... the twice deep fried spring rolls are delicioso. Then we had the beef pho and lemongrass beef, the latter of which was an experience close to a spiritual awakening. So good. The pho was good also, but pale in comparison to the wonder that is the lemongrass beef.

And the most amazing part: great friendly service. It almost took me aback. I often joke that part of the authentic Asian food experience is bad service, and Sunflower is a refreshing departure from the stereotype. 

Now I kinda wish I live a little closer to Mission. Will definitely return.
author: Charlie L.

description:
Food was awesome. But get it to go!  I haven't had service this bad in years. They slammed the silverware down on the table, an just after I finished eating they told me to leave because other people were waiting to sit down. 
Try the 5 spice chicken! AS TAKE OUT!
author: Jasper S.

description: Soooo good!  I recommend the Sunflower Prawns, and the Curry Seafood.  Frickin yum!
author: Bradley D.

description: Don't go there!!! If I can give zero stars I would.. The fat guy working there was extremely rude! He actually stopped my friend and asked for additional tip (we tipped 20%) and he wanted more... Even though the service was very bad. And the food was cold when we got it... If you want to waste your money, get shitty service and be stopped at the door to put in more tip this is the place for you
author: Mamut T.

description:
Pro: I hate noodles. I'll just come out and say that now. Never liked pasta or chow mein, so when I ordered Garlic Noodles (I think it's like item 43 or 44 on menu) I really stretched myself out. Verdict: I like noodles now. They were awesome, perfect and had an even greater taste. Add a little hot sauce and your set for a couple hours. Great meal and SUPER tasty.

Cons: I ended up paying 10.47 dollars total for the plate of just noodles. No protein at all and a cup of water. To be honest, that almost seems a little steep for just a plate of noodle. The actual price was something like 8.47 but I left some tip too (the vietnamese lady there puppy eyed me.) I guess if you don't leave tip it would be okay price. 

If they made me like noodles then who knows what else they may make me like.
author: Alexis R.

description:
How can anyone give this place less than 4 stars! What are you expecting, the four seasons? 

Okay, I'm a little bias because the service here, whilst being slow, is awesome. The manager always greets my friend and I when we come in and refers to us as "his friends". He's all like, "Welcome back, my friend!" and we're instantly smitten. Everytime I've gone to Sunflower it's just him and one other waiter bustling around-- and this place tends to get packed even during non-peak hours like 2-3pm.

I always get the same thing when I go here, which is the curried eggplant, because it's so amazingly yummy. This is the dish that basically turned me on to eggplant (it's inspired me to try cooking it on my own). The best part is since it's eggplant which has basically no calories you can feel semi-guilt free knowing that the only thing that's really unhealthy is the oil they cook it in!

Also, while you're there you should get the Thai Iced Tea because, uh, why not? Also try the shrimp spring rolls they always taste fresh and light and come with a delicious peanut sauce -- although they could use a higher shrimp to vermicelli ratio.
author: Sabrina M.

description:
I've always loved this restaurant in the mission.  I came here before heading over to Jennifer CP's UYE event around the corner at Morac restaurant and lounge.  I have only one thing to say about that party....  OMG.

Coming back to Sunflower, however, I had to use the restroom and my God, it's like I walked into a different establishment.  The restaurant is nice but their bathroom is similiar to that of a dive bar's restroom.  There were grafitti all over the walls and it was messy.  A place where you need to use a napkin to open the door and lift the seat  (I respect the female).  The only thing missing from this bathroom was a glory hole.  I'm sure I can probably find one if I looked hard enough (no pun intended).  

The food is always solid.  I would probably not get the pho here.  Stick with the garlic noodles, rolls, 5 spice chicken, prawns.  shaken beef.  You will not be disappointed.
author: jason g.

description:
Just went there seeing yelp's 3.5 stars but seriously disappointed!
The chickens of Garlic Chicken seems like uncooked! Some house noodles were also wacky!! I've eaten Vietnamese way better than this and I'm fan but did NOT like this place at all.
author: Aru S.

description:
Want to add that I now do go in and dine in at Sunflower all the time. While it may look a bit shabby the service is friendly and attentive and I always enjoy my meals here. 

Dine in, take out, both are a go!
author: Tory F.

description: I came here craving the soothing comfort of pho after a horrible day.  I had been looking for MY Vietnamese spot for years and, finally, I think I may have found it at Sunflower.  The chicken soup was perfect with great broth, well cooked noodles and clean white meat.   The Vietnamese Iced Coffee, another staple, is also exquisite.  I have tried many Vietnamese restaurants and firmly believe Sunflower been is the best one around!  I came here feeling sorry for myself and left with a full happy stomach, hope and leftovers for tomorrow.  Could I ask for anything more?
author: Rebecca H.

description:
My favorite dish is the Sunflower Prawns. It costs a little more that other items on the menu (which are reasonably priced), but the sauce is really, really good.

Although others have pointed this out, it's worth repeating so people know: this location has two entrances. The one on Valencia is the "nice restaurant" side; the one on 16th is the "hole in the wall" side. Go to the Valencia side for better ambiance and service; go to the 16th side for a quick bite (or if you don't want to wait since the Valencia side is sometimes packed around meal times).
author: Paul L.

description: Dinner for 4 people came out to $11 per person AND it was delicious, you cannot beat that!  We ordered:  Garlic noodles, vegetables with curry, steamed vegetarian potstickers, and the fried springrolls (Imperial rolls)?  It was just the right amount of food to have dessert and drinks later.
author: Sona P.

description:
One of my top 3 in SF - hands down. Cheap dive with the best tasting food - no matter what category you want to compare. This food is good as food gets, and everything on the menu is delicious.

Let me be specific of what I crave from Sunflower:

Shaken Beef, Curry Vegetable, Fresh Spring Rolls, Hot and Sour Soup...

Damn, I think I'll run down there tonight :)
author: Dan B.

description:
I like my ___ like I like my pho: a HUGE portion that's well flavored, with tender meat.

This place has a ton on their menu, but I have yet to explore it all because the 3 dishes I order on rotation are just so damn good.  

And by great Zeus' beard!  The portions are HUGE here!

My 3 favorites:

1) Vegetarian Imperial Spring rolls - I order these so I can get at least some modicum of vegetable in my meal.  Best of all, they come with a vinegar dipping sauce so I can actually eat it!  Most places serve spring rolls with peanut sauce, and alas, I am allergic.

2) Beef pho - The broth is awesome.  Light and well flavored.  The meat's also high quality and really tender.  (That's what she said.)

3) Chicken pho - White meat, but still tender and flavorful.

I'm glad that the one Vietnamese place I've managed to find in the commercial part of the Mission is great, and I don't have to drive all over SF when I have a hankering for pho!

...by the way, "steak" was what I had in mind for the blank above :-P
author: Alice C.

description:
Nothing to complain about.  Nothing bad, nothing great, which I guess in a good way makes it a dependable place to go get food if you're taste buds aren't swaying you one way or the other.  It's also one of the more lower priced places to eat in the Mission.

I had the Beef pho (they only have one option for that), and it was good.  The portions here are huge!  Looking around, the curry, noodle and rice dishes looked good.  I definitely want to try those dishes next time.
author: Nadiyah S.

description: Came here for dinner.  Had the Shrimp Spring Rolls and the beef vermicelli noodle bowl which came with imperial rolls, as well as Vietnamese coffee.  I have no complaints.  The spring rolls were fresh, the veggies crispy, the rice paper moist but not too chewy - perfection.  The beef was very tender and perfectly spiced, the imperial rolls delicious and the portion huge.  The coffee was an elegant process and exactly the pick-me-up I needed before heading out for the night.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
It was one of those rare hot and sunny days in the city when I ventured into Hipster-town, also known as Mission/Dolores. Even though I was surrounded by taquerias, I had a hankerin' for some Vietnamese bun - it's like a nice salad with some fresh veg, noodles, meat, and nuoc mam fish sauce.  I thought it might be refreshing after hoofing it around Hipster-town for the better part of the morning.

As the heat of the sun reached what seemed like it's apex at noon, I ducked into Sunflower and found relief.  Someone greeted me with a tall glass of ice water and I ordered the #25 BBQ Beef and Imperial Rolls with Vermicelli. 

Holy cow, it was a super-sized portion!  It came in a large bowl and as I mixed in the nuoc mam, I wondered how it would all fit into my belly.  Should I have brought a friend to share it with?  Undaunted, I pressed forward and took my first bite of the imperial roll.  It was delicious!  Fried perfectly - crispy on the outside and had a perfect balance of meat and veg on the inside.  These rolls were among the best I've ever had, and I've had probably more than my fair share.

The rest of the bun was just average.  The noodles were a little hard.  The meat was cut into large, long strips that I found difficult to eat since there was no knife to cut into it.  Speaking of which, even though the imperial rolls were cut into 3 pieces, they were extra large mouthfuls of delicious food.  

After refueling on two glasses of ice water and just half of my super-sized bowl of food, I was ready to take in more of this gorgeous day in the city before going back to my own hood.  I will definitely come back for more of those imperial rolls.
author: vira k.

description: I'm pretty sure this is a Chinese influenced Vietnamese restaurant. A lot of my non-Vietnamese friends recommended this place. Finally I was in the neighborhood with my gf and decided to stop for a bite to eat. We ordered the garlic noodles with vegetables, shaken beef, and spring rolls. The garlic noodles weren't garlic-y at all. More like chow mein. The shaken beef seemed to be coated in flour before fried (all wrong) and the spring rolls were actually really good. I'll have to try some other dishes to judge whether or not it is a real authentic place or not.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
Since my parents live down the street from this little restaurant, I've been here at least 3 or 4 times. I still think pho is the PERFECT hangover food: hot, soupy, and laden with MSG...it's heaven in a bowl! They don't have many choices for noodle soups but I've tried their beef and chicken pho. I prefer the beef one since there's way too many chicken pieces in the latter. Both the soups are pretty well seasoned and they don't skimp on the amount of noodles which is a plus! 
My favorite thing to order there are the imperial rolls though...perfectly fried and tasty. Yuuuum, esp with the fish sauce! 

The waiters are extremely friendly and the atmosphere is fairly intimate since it's in a pretty small space. They have another part of the restaurant around the corner on 16th St too. I suggest that you go here for lunch since it's less crowded and their lunch special is totally worth it...soup, imperial roll, rice, and choice of meat for $7.50 or $8. What a deal! I'm for sure heading back here when I'm craving pho after a long night out.
author: Karen Y.

description:
Shaken beef.  Get it.  Love it.  Go back for more.  

Overall, Sunflower is fine.  I'm not an expert on Vietnamese food or Asian food in general, but I generally find the stuff on their menu to be tasty, which would earn it three stars.  The shaken beef is just outstanding, though, and it keeps me coming back.  If it weren't for the beef, I would probably never go here as a destination again ("Oh, I've eaten there - it's all right."), but every couple of months I get a hankering for that magical dish and have to make a trip back there.

Sunflower shaken beef - how I love thee!
author: Michael I.

description: I have eaten here several times and have always had great Phô, imperial rolls, spring rolls, and vietnamese coffee. I recommend this place to many people and feel its one of the best and reasonable places to get Phô in the city. Most def some great foodz!!!
author: Luis B.

description:
Service:  The waiter sat us down and served us right away.  Waters were always refilled quickly.  Cooks were very loud talking in Chinese while American Christmas music was blaring from the speakers ( I just thought that was funny).  1 out of 1 star.

Food:  Had the pork vermicelli dish.  It was a very large portion and it also came with 2 Imperial rolls (egg rolls) which were very good.  The pork was a little fatty but still good.  1 out of 2 stars.

Price:  Huge portions which will set you back about 5-10 dollars for lunch.  Vietnamese food will never put a dent in your wallet.  1 out of 1 star.

Wow factor:  Small "neighborly" feeling to this place.  Looks like a lot of people know the cooks and tons of people order take out.  Nothing that stood out to me though.  0 out of 1 star.
author: Danny P.

description:
I've been here 3 times now.  I like the place.  It's not mind-blowing food, but it's pretty good.  The portions are also way more than you will eat in one sitting.

The better dishes I've had involve noodles.  The spring rolls are good too.  

I tried the lemongrass chicken and for no apparent reason we didn't get that dish until 10 minutes or more after the first.  When it came it didn't seem fresh - almost stale.  The chicken was dried out.  So, that was disappointing.  

The service is tough to rate - you can tell they're trying and they're really friendly, but when it comes down to it, they leave you sitting there for a while... for your food, for the check, for your change...
author: Amy L.

description:
This is my rainy day place. It's right by my house and it's ideal for going there alone. They have two dining rooms, one on 16th and one on the other side on Valencia, both connected to the same kitchen.

Location: Perfect location accessible by everyone. Although the food here is not something I would think people would come from afar to consume. More on that later.

Space: The 16th side has a bar where I eat alone. The other side is more for when you have a group of folk and are all dining together. Decor? It's welcoming like a Chinese restaurant, since the owners are Cantonese. Nothing special, but I like it's homeliness.

Ambience: Hipsters of the Mission. Also people that might live in the area or on the way to their homes from Mission 16th Bart. Since the Mission is getting a few tourists lately, I've seen a couple of these in there as well.

Service: Cantonese service, meaning throwing plates at you, yelling orders out and refusing to make eye contact until you wave your hands and yell. Gotta love it! Although on the Valencia side there's this really nice server that is super friendly. Nothing to complain about, at all. I prefer this than to have an overly friendly server who keeps asking if you're ok every 10 minutes. 

Food: The food's pretty good. This is probably some of the better Vietnamese food I've had. Some plates are better than others. Personally, I've had better Ph, specially in the Ingleside and on Clement street, but this one's pretty good. Their other plates are also yummy. Nothing particularly amazing, just plain ol' good food on the way home.

Overall: Great place to stop by if you're in the area.
author: SF N.

description:
Fool me once - shame on you.  

Fool me twice - shame on me.  I won't ever dine here, again.

The food is "alright" but what really sealed the nail in this coffin is the service.  I recall not being satisifed with the service my first time around but decided to give it another shot. 

What.....a mistake.

Our server (we'll respectfully call him the old grumpy guy) was SUCH an a$$hole I actually found myself yelling at him as he walked away from me.  

We waited about fifteen minutes before our order was taken in a restaurant that wasn't even half full.  At least he apologized for that.

When asked about the pronunciation of a certain dish (to hopefully try and learn something new) he barked he "DON'T SPEAK VIETNAMESE!"

Well, excuse the f^ck out of me for making the assumption that the Asian guy working in the Vietnamese restaurant might know how to pronounce the name of the dish.

Oh, and don't ask for CHILI sauce.  First, he'll ignore your request.  Then, the second time you ask, you'll get a dirty look with your SOY sauce.  The third time you try to get what you want, he'll scream, "WHAT!?"  

Apparently, he can't speak English, either.

I know it's on a convenient corner but if you want good, "safe" (as another Yelper called it) Vietnamese food, take a little walk - TWO blocks - down to Bodhi.  It's also on Valencia between 13th and 14th.  Their food is kicking and they also treat you right.  Spacious, clean and friendly - if I could only get them to deliver....
author: Jimmie L.

description:
Sunflower needs to get rid of the angry, crazy waiter working there. He is driving away business. We will never go back if he is there. 

We went there the other night, needing a satisfying meal, quickly, as we had theater tickets, and it is easy to get downtown from the restaurant. It was very cold out, and at an off time, so the restaurant was pretty empty. However, the waiter sat us down next to another person, who was eating alone. He asked the waiter, very politely, if he could move, so we could have our privacy. The waiter pushes his table out about an inch. He asks again, still politely, and the crazy waiter, literally grabs his food away from him, and tells him to get the hell out. We could not believe it. The customer is still being very polite, and the waiter is screaming at him. The customer finally leaves. We felt awful, but didn't have much time, and it was too cold to go elsewhere, so we ordered but really could not enjoy the meal. We needed another plate, but were afraid to ask, for fear of also being thrown out. To make matters worse, the waiter is now bragging to other customers how he threw this guy out. 

Yelp is full of reviews from customers complaining about this angry, crazy waiter. There are other waiters there, but this one seems to run the show. I don't know if he is one of the owners. We have gone there before, and one time he kept on ignoring us when we wanted to order another dish. The food is good, the prices very reasonable, but we will never go there again as long as that waiter is there.
author: David G.

description:
The garlic noodles are like crack! Seriously one of the most delicious things I've tasted in my entire life. I wish I knew what they put in there to make it so good. 

The other not-to-miss item on the menu is the Vietnamese Crepe. I've only ever had it vegetarian, but it's just crazy yummy. 

Everything else on the menu I've tried is really good, but those are my two faves. The atmosphere is nothing to write home about, but who cares when the food is that good!
author: Christine B.

description:
Excellent food, excellent service, and well-priced. Average meal around $9.00. 
Definitely recommend this place!
author: Josh S.

description:
my favorite restaurant in the city, hands down. the food is good and it's pretty quick too. Tom (one of the servers, who seems to never get a day off, poor guy) is the coolest "young man" you will ever meet. 

they are open for lunch and dins, and have 2 different parts to the restaurant, so if one side is full (and usually at least 1 side requires a wait) just hop on over to the other side. 

i will admit, your clothes come out smelling a bit like the food. but hey, it's totally worth it.
author: Michael M.

description: This is a place that you do not go to for the ambiance but the food is amazing. Try the vegetarian spring rolls or the chicken noodle soup. You will not be disappointed. As an avid fan, who eats here several times a week, I prefer to eat at the bar at the 16th location and watch them cook. This place is hands down my favorite cheap eat in the Mission.
author: Caitlin W.

description:
I may have been here once or twice before and it was overcrowded, but I shall review my experience of their takeout option for a large gathering;  consistently satisfying and vegetarian. Tasty curry, noodles and crispy rolls, mmm!

I hate to wait, so I vote for takeout on this one.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Awful Service. The one larger guy that works there can be a real jerk sometimes. The food is good but with such great restaurants in the area I will never go back there.
author: Will M.

description:
I'm such a fan of Sunflower. When I lived near Guerrero and Duboce, this was one of my go-to places, and now that I'm in the Inner Sunset I still make an effort to eat here occasionally. I usually prefer to eat on the Valencia Street side, since one of the waiters (he's on the younger side of things, and fantastically flamboyant) over there always treats Jared and I like his "regulars", and it's sweet. 

I always get the vegetarian Vietnamese crepes, and they are sort of next level. Crispy rice noodle crepes with tofu and veggies inside, always served super hot, wrapped up in cold lettuce leaves with a little cilantro, cucumber, pickled carrots and a sweet/spicy dressing.  Their fresh springs rolls are nice, too, though not mind blowing. If you're into veggies and such, I'd highly recommend the green bean and shiitake dish. It's nicely spiced and always well cooked and just a nice little situation.

The last few sunny days I've spent in Dolores Park were followed by  trips to Sunflower. It's easy to keep dinner under $25 for two people, nicely located and there are almost always leftovers. Score.
author: heather c.

description: Some of the best Vietnamese food I've had in the Bay Area. Much better especially than places I've tried in Oakland. Their Eggplant w/ Garlic (or something along those lines) is to die for. Cozy, low key, and only mildly overpriced.
author: Chelsea H.

description: They have the best pho ga (chicken noodle soup) in San Francisco. To be honest, I haven't tried anything else because the pho ga is so good. And they know exactly what I want before my butt even hits the seat. Yes, the decor and lighting is sub par. And yes, the customer service can be rough, but I think it adds character. (It probably helps that I'm originally from New York). Hints: Don't ask to be seated unless your entire party is there; don't sit at a table bigger than you need; and don't lounge around if you're done eating and other people are waiting. Follow those simple rules and you'll be just fine. I really do love this place and will continue to go back again and again.
author: Richard K.

description:
Legit.  Colorful.  Filling.

a girl walks into a vietnamese restaurant.....

She is appalled at the (normal) prices as she is in hopes of finding a $2 belly filler.  Exacerbated with hunger and desperation, she decides to fine dine with the $8.75 imperial roll and chicken verm bowl.

IT. IS. HUGE. she says.  

ate it for dinner.  eating it for lunch.  will eat again for dinner. (the same bowl)  Yes, I'm that girl.  Noodles were a little too warm for verm bowl standards.  Imp rolls and chiggin overflow with Viet flavor

Interior: Feels like Aruba/Jamaica (bright, non sensical, multi colored walls)

To Try Next Time - Pho!

$$ Apps $6-7
$$Entrs  $8-12
author: Jane L.

description: Er....  The environment is not clean. Pho are a little bit over price. How can this restaurant survive in a place like San Francisco? $9 garlic noodle with no meat?!
author: Wayne Z.

description:
food is still tasty, but my last experience here had me a bit put off.  i was served my 5 spice chicken lunch combo, and the chicken was cold.  really, it doesn't take long to grill up a chicken.  and i'd rather wait for a freshly cooked hot meal than get served my plate at lightning speed.  no wonder why the dishes always come out so fast.  in the end they gave me back a warm chicken, which i'm sure they nuked in the microwave.

it's a shame because i did like this place.
author: Sheri N.

description: Garlic noodle was unappetizing and costly ($14.00 for noodles with tofu and veggies?!) and service was...the H&M of restaurants...
author: M T.

description:
Came here for beef pho takeout and it was pretty good.  I also asked for the veggies that comes in the veggie pho on the side.

Service was and nice and they even gave me a thai iced tea to go as well.

For a cold day in SF, I will definitely return!
author: Zivago L.

description: Their lemongrass dishes with green beans and the veggie spring rolls are both excellent
author: Jessica N.

description:
We tried the garlic noodles and the pork and imperial roll, they are good but not outstanding.  The price is not high, and they give you a large portion, however mostly noodles, kinda expected for the price.

I doubt that we will go out of our way to revisit any time soon.
author: jen j.

description:
Love this place!

If you go at lunch the plates are MASSIVE. Easily enough for two to three people, which makes it so cheap!

We pretty much order the same things every time we go here:

Vegetarian Imperial Rolls
Spicy String Beans
Hot and Sour Soup

*sigh* I am getting hungry just writing this review!
author: Breanne B.

description: Probably 3.5 stars.  Very large portions, and very good, tasty food.   Probably not the most authentic restaurant, but a solid choice.   This is my 2nd visit.  We had the BBQ pork and imperial rolls vermicelli, the spicy green beans with mushrooms, and the garlic noodles with veggies.  All three were tasty.  This is no Turtle Tower, but it's probably as good as Tamarine and definitely cheaper.  Like the red decor, and also appreciate the fast service.
author: Vivian W.

description:
Had the Pho there with beef. Extremely yummy!
I saw all kinds of great looking things on other people's plates. I will definitely come back!
author: Dan Z.

description: Loved the change of pace with hipster decor in a pho spot.  Pho itself was pretty decent, nothing outstanding with the broth texture/flavor and noodle consistency.
author: Eric F.

description: Huge servings of bland, barely chopped, out-of-season vegetables. Tall bottles of preservative-laden sauces. Mm.
author: Jade P.

description: So it's always crazy busy. And so what if the waiter or waitress doesn't like you. This place gets turn over wich turns me on cause people flock to good things. These reviews are as crazy as the pepole who post them. The Vietnamese crepe is one of my favorite things to eat in sf. I don't really come here for much else. Had a Viet. iced coffee the other day, and it was just great, then again that should be easy. The cold noodle bowl with imperial roll was great as well. Man is that kitchen small and dirty though.. Cest la vie biot**es
author: alex m.

description:
5 stars for fast service.
2 stars for wrong order and greasy, turn-your-stomach after-effects.

I ordered a shrimp and noogled dish to go. It was $9.75 total... for one dish. By the time I arrived at my destination, I realized it was just noodles and vegetables. It was like top-ramen, but with more oil. I ate most of it, but it made me so sick that I couldn't finish it. 

My boyfriend who has an iron-stomach loved it, however. So maybe he should write the review, 'cause I'm not going back here... unless it's to collect the difference they charged me for the wrong dish...
author: Lauren S.

description:
Let me start by saying that I have been a loyal customer for the past 4 years and have always enjoyed the food. However, this evening I experienced thee worst customer service ever. I arrived with a party of 3 and were seated at a four top. The minute we took a breather from eating our bill was promptly served. I tipped very generously and  gave the bill back. Though I was finished with my meal, my dinner guest was still eating...the server came to our table and with attitude ask if we needed anything else, I replied we did not. My guest was still finishing her dinner, no more than 2-3 minutes later the server returned and rudely asked us if we were finished because he had another party of 4 waiting.  I guess there is no such thing as eating in peace at Sunflower because you are pretty much pushed out after a half hour, forty five minutes. 

I was so bothered by unprofessionalism and lack of appreciation that I spoke to the manager in hopes of turning the negative experience around. The man who called himself the manager (still leery of this being true) was even worse! He told me we were there for over an hour and a half, I told him that was impossible as I was still at work an hour ago and we were there for no more than 45 minutes. 

In a word, this diva and his sidekick were RIDICULOUS and I will never be dining there again. Cheap food, unfortunately equals cheap service now at Sunflower....what a shame.
author: PATRICIA K.

description: I would've expect the food to be much better for a place that is always so crowded.  There are Vietnamese spots close by that are better and not as crowded.
author: Alex B.

description: Delicious. The Vietnamese crepe is to die for!!! Chicken Pho the bomb. New fave place in the City.
author: Rebecca K.

description:
Sunday afternoons are meant for nothing.  A day of rest, a time to reflect on the craziness that was your week.  After watching a horrible movie (9... tim burton seriously needs to lay off the hallucinagens) we decided to go back for my GFs favorite freshrolls here at Sunflower.  Season 3 of lost was beckoning me back home, so we ordered togo and started the fun.

We had:
Fresh veggie spring rolls
Garlic eggplant with tofu
Garlic Noodles
Shaken Beef

If you didn't notice, we both have thrown the garlic caution to the wind.  I mean hey... if BOTH of our breaths stink, it cancels each other out right?

Ah but the food.  So damn tasty every time.  I'll let you switch up the appetizer, but it's just foolish to come here and not order the garlic noodles or shaken beef.  Share em with the table and you'll NEVER ever be dissapointed. 

side note, the freshrolls taste even beter with some peanut sauce, but you have to order it on the side... seeya there!
author: Joseph F.

description: Just has lunch here with a co-worker. We each got the vermicelli lunch and then split a Banh mi sandwich and the sausage spring rolls.  The sausage spring rolls were tasty and they had a nice crunch when you bit into them.  The peanut dipping sauce was tasty but a little sweet so I added some sriacha sauce.  The vermicelli noodles were awesome and I enjoyed the fresh vegetables.  We then split a chicken Banh mi with a fried egg.  The egg made the sandwich very rich.  The egg was good though. The service was attentive and nice.  I definitely recommend this place.
author: Johnny D.

description:
This place has rarely failed me. Being a creature of habit, I pretty much always order the same thing, garlic noodle, which is very tasty. Every so often, I also add their delicious spring rolls if I am feeling a little more hungry. Lately, I have been ordering the vegatarian/ vegan pho. The pho is good, but I usually have to add salt to it-not sure why they make it so bland. 

There are two locations, which are right around the corner from each other; this seems to really confused new patrons. The smaller place is on the 16th street side (this is basically their kitchen), while the bigger spot is on the Valencia street side (feels a little more fancy)-take your pick, same exact food. 

Staff is very nice, although, straight-shooting in their dialogue with you, but it is the city so I am not offended. 

Sunflower is old faithful. When I can't decide where to eat, when eating out, I often turn to Sunflower.
author: Brian S.

description: this place rules. The garlic noodles are amazing. Ask for it without egg if you're vegan. I've tried all the veggie menu items and I love them all. My bf is a meat eater and he loves this spot too, we eat here at least once a week.
author: Sydney W.

description:
Def. a happening little restaurant.

To be honest I go here more for the atmosphere than the food..

I'm a fan of the look & feel (and I like the way this place appears on two sides of the building, creating the illusion of being two restaurants).

The food is pretty good but not great in my opinion.

Prices are decent as is the food. Still, something about this place doesn't quite deliver for me. Not enough to make me a fan.

Might go back here at some point, but I have to be in the right mood to for sure. Maybe somebody else would be more thrilled by them than I ever was...
author: Kai S.

description: Very impatient and rude staff... The food wasn't bad, but the way we were treated really was! :( First off, they wouldn't seat us anywhere close to where we wanted to sit, and then rushed us to finish faster, claiming there was a larger party that needed the table.  They maybe could have asked us nicely to finish up, but instead persistently came to the table to take things away before we were done, and then yelled at us to hurry up and said something like, "this is a business, not a home". I think I'll choose another place next time I'm at 16th and Valencia.
author: Elise N.

description: Amazing service & food! The prawns with ginger sauce w/garlic noodles is divine! I'm having the sea bass next time, it looked great!
author: amanda l.

description: The veggie noodle soup is wonderful! Very tasty, healthy and the peppers(on the side) give a nice kick. It's our favorite take-out in the city. Need soup?  Go to Sunflower!
author: Jodi F.

description:
Yes! I love this place especially the vietnamese crepe , Shaken beef, soups & Friendly smiley guy who always calls me "young man".
Nothing that you'll be lying awake at night thinking about, though I get the craving about once a month and they always do me right here, whether I'm solo, with a date or a big group of friends.
author: Teo C.

description:
I am totally almost BFFs with Sunflower now.  Three of us went dining there last night (2/9/2010), and had an mostly altogether pleasurable experience!

We ordered several dishes: Vegetarian Imperial Rolls w/vinegar dipping sauce, Shrimp Spring Rolls w/peanut dipping sauce, Vegetarian Vietnamese Hot -n-Sour Soup, Spicy Seafood Combo, Lemongrass Tofu, Grilled Beef, jasmine rice, and Vietnamese Iced Coffee.

Imperial Rolls - "really amazing," said one of our diners.  They were crunchy on the outside, and tender-but-not-mushy on the inside.  The dipping sauce was tasty, too!

Shrimp Spring Rolls - Good, but too much vermicelli, and although the peanut sauce required a nice dollop of sriracha to liven it up, had a good base from which to add.

Vegetarian Hot-n-Sour Soup - "reminds me of the old Hung Yen," said me, and that's quite a compliment, if you remember the former Hung Yen (now the not-nearly-as-good Evergreen Garden) on Harrison at 17th.  The broth was complex and flavorful, with chunks of tomato and pineapple and mushroom, with sliced jalapeno.  A couple of leaves of mint added to it rounded it out nicely.

Grilled Beef - "not as high a quality of beef for the price," lamented one of our companions, but he did like how the wrappers were individually served in a pile of steam plates, which kept them from sticking together.  But he ran out of mint leaves before the beef was finished.

Spicy Seafood Combo - wasn't spicy, and although the ingredients were cooked correctly, to the right level of doneness, left much to be desired.  This was the big disappointment dish of the evening.

Still, we all enjoyed out meal and would come back, especially if we could ask for them to make the dishes more spicy.
author: Paul B.

description:
Theres two entrances to this place:

1. the front side on Valencia if you want a white table cloth kind of sit down.

2. the side entrance on 16th which resembles a hole in the wall joint.

Either way you will get served really good food here by the same chefs.

The star dish is the Garlic Noodles. Its what this place is known for!

The Pho' is great and the Vermicelli Bowls are awesome!

Lots of activity in this hip neighborhood especially at night and on the weekends! 

 Hipster Prices, but well worth it!

This Vietnames place is the best in the Mission. Actually, no other Vietnamese place offers or makes Garlic Noodles the way these folks do.

Dont let the heroin junkies scare you. Go in and treat yourself!
author: MacKenzie S.

description:
BEST PHO ever on this side of the hood.

I live too far to walk here often, but I live too close to not be going here more. I f*cking love this place.

They won't split a check and there's only one good server. Its exactly how I like my pho eateries. The more Vietnamese eating in there than hipster whities, the better. Cause you know its authentic. xo
author: S B.

description:
I went here for the first time last night. 

If Yelp allowed half stars I might give this place 3.5 stars.

We ordered the veggie imperial rolls. 
They were good.. not the best I've had but certainly not the worst.
They weren't cut well and we had to rip them apart. 

The bf ordered a veggie vermicelli dish. It was huge and came with a sauce on the side. The ingredients looked fresh and the presentation was fine. BF said that it was completely unseasoned and flavorless without the side sauce. He didn't get a to-go box for his left overs.

I ordered the garlic noodles with veggies. I wanted eggplant with it but the waiter said no. IMO if you are willing to pay for it why would you refuse to add eggplant? le pout* 
The dish was okay but I certainly had to add a lot of spicy sauce and soy to give it flavor. I'd eat it again though. 

The place is a little cramped and the bathroom is questionable but overall the food was pretty OK. It won't be a new favorite but I wouldn't object to going back sometime.
author: Amber F.

description: I have searched far and wide and this is still my favorite pho place in the city. This may just be the most healthy and delicious choice for pho in all of SF!
author: Zuri P.

description: There was nothing really bad about this restaurant however for being below average to average, I feel that the price for a bowl or vermacelli bowl was a little high.
author: randy g.

description: The curry chicken and garlic noodles were amazing. Service was exceptionally good too. Would go back for sure
author: Andy S.

description:
After an morning of watching ladies in skimpy clothing samba dancing at carnaval, the stomach needed sustenance...the growling might've been a giveaway. Using the A-Ok Yelp app on my trusty but aging Blackberry, we located Sunflower in the Mission to satisfy our grumpy tummies. 

Being ravenous, we opted for the lunch specials. A good deal since you get a ton of food: Salad, soup, spring roll, rice, and a meat dish all on one giant plate. Can't recall exactly how much but me thinks it was around 8 pieces of legal tender.

Soup was vinegary with bits of pineapple chunks and veges in it. The best part was the five spice chicken that was grilled and flavorfully marinated. My lunch buddy opted for the lemon grass chicken. Chicken was a bit dry and had some lemon grass taste but could use more.

Service...what service? There were only 2 guys working that day and they were quite swamped as they took a while to take our orders and the food took a while too. 

Still, if I'm in the neighborhood, I'll consider Sunflower again for an inexpensive and decent meal.
author: Norman S.

description:
OMG... I love love love love their lunch specials.  $10 for rice, entree (I usually get the spicy green beans), salad, and imperial roll - enough for two days/meals. 

Too bad they do not deliver; it's a bit far of a walk from the workplace.  When ordering, because which number you call as they have two locations.
author: Joanna W.

description:
This place has good food at a reasonable price and it's open late. After striking out at another place, we went by for dinner at 10pm and it was packed.

We had vermicelli and pork with imperial rolls and lemongrass chicken. I would say the imperial rolls are the best part and the green beans in the chicken were good too. Big portions. 

I'd give them 4 stars for service though. The waiter was super friendly, though sometimes absent. We liked how they packed your food to go instead of having you do it yourself. Also, even after we paid the check the guy came back and asked if we wanted our water refilled. Classy stuff.
author: Abbey S.

description:
Update 9/18/09 - so I ended up going to the "other" Sunflower restaurant around the corner from the one that has the icky seating. It's the same restaurant (I'm told) but the seating is better, the ambiance is better, the service is better AND the food was much much much better! As a matter of fact I really liked it and everything we ate there. 

My friend ordered the steak salad, which was phenomenal. Other friends ordered egg rolls, which I was happy to hear were made with rice, not wheat, flour and this chicken dish that I wish I could remember better because it was so super tasty. I had the green beans and something else as well. It was 2 months ago and my memory is hazy but I did want to update my review because yes it's good and yes I'd go back and yes I will now try the Sunflower in Portrero Hill as well. I'm happy to report back on this because I am a big fan of Vietnamese food.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
Sunflower is a tiny, hole-in-the-wall Vietnamese restaurant that serves tasty comfort food. Their noodle soup is delicious, especially the broth, and of course all of the delicious toppings they include w/ it. Their Imperial Rolls are especially tasty! This is because of the large portion, the perfectly fried roll itself, the yummy dipping sauce, and the pickled carrots, noodles, and lettuce on the side. They are some of the best Imperial Rolls I've tried in SF thus far. I've also had their Pan Fried Noodles w/ Chicken, which was huge, but lacked a tad on flavor. It really helped to add Sriracha and soy sauce, but it wouldn't be my first choice. Their Garlic Noodles w/ Mixed Vegetables was really really good. The Noodles were definitely the best part, but it was also awesome that there was so much of it on the plate! I've also had their Shrimp Fried Rice and Crab and Sweet Corn Soup, which were both good too. All of their dishes are definitely kind of greasy, but as long as you don't shove your face with noodles, you'll probably be fine. (It can cause a bit of a stomach ache after) I can definitely admit that it's hard not to...especially those garlic ones....mmmmmhm. 

Note: Probably better not to sit right by the door with your back to the window. The last time I was there a homeless woman came in and leaned over our table in my face, letting her smelly sweater rest in my fried rice and soup. GROSS! You never know what kind of situation you'll come across in the Mission, so it's better to be safe than sorry! Or take out is always a great option as well!
author: Sonya D.

description:
You must order the following:

1) CHILI PRAWNS over GARLIC NOODLES (I believe it's number 49, not to be confused with pan fried noodles and shrimp)

2) LEMON TOFU with GREEN BEANS (under the veggies section)

Trust me.  You will come back to Yelp.com just to thank me.  It's THAT amazing.
author: Sarah Z.

description:
It's a divey but delicious and affordable neighborhood restaurant for me. It's also a restaurant that has dishes I CRAVE on a regular basis and if I didn't live nearby I'd still probably have to come for these dishes: 

Sunflower Prawns with Garlic Noodles: Their regular garlic noodles are fantastic but this dish is flavor country! Don't order the garlic noodles "with prawns" because that's just going to be some shrimp thrown into the regular garlic noodles--good but not mind blowing. "Sunflower Prawns with Garlic Noodles" are four giant jumbo prawns (with shells on) covered in some magic sauce (that makes me go insane) nesting on a big bed of garlic noodles. I think maybe I could eat anything covered with this sauce. I wish I could ask to take the prawn shells home because I swear I'd just suck the empty shells all night long to get every bit of that sauce off. (I probably could ask, but I'm too embarrassed.)

I also get the Crepe which looks like a big crispy omlette filled with mostly mung beans and some bits of meat. You cut off a chunk of crepe and wrap it in some lettuce along with the fish sauce and mint leave and other stuff they bring with it. It's a little messy but I love it. 

Things like the shaken beef are good and I have a sorority girl type of friend who likes the lemongrass chicken because it comes with green beans and they use all white meat chicken. 

I always seem to get one of two waiters. The thin and exhausted looking man (I feel for him having to deal with privelaged hipsters all day long) or the bigger dude with the effeminate accent. Love them both. The bigger dude also loves the sunflower prawns with garlic noodles and never fails to tell me that's his favorite too. 

This is a great place to come with a big group so you can try lots of dishes and it's affordable (but NOT on a Friday or Saturday night--you'll wait forever.)
author: meehee o.

description:
This place has the best spring rolls in SF. I've been looking all around the city for spring rolls like what I'm used to getting in Hawaii and so far Sunflower is it! Sunflower calls their spring rolls 'Imperial Rolls' and they are deep fried to perfection. Order the Vermicelli with Imperial Rolls and BBQ Pork! It's fantastic!

The service was great and the waiter was so friendly and flirtatious. He even called me young man though we are probably the same age. That's how you get a good tip. I did notice that half the tables were occupied by gay guys (in the Mission, not Castro), so perhaps the waiter flirts with everyone and keeps them coming back for more.
author: Rex D.

description:
Okay, it is CONVENIENT (right on 16th and Valencia) since it is located near the BART station and to my friend's apartment.  The people working there seem nice and the food comes out pretty quickly.  The price of the food is decent.

Yet, the food is just alright.  Nothing to really ooh and aaah about.  Very quickly prepared Vietnamese food.

I've tried the Shaken Beef, the BBQ pork, the garlic noodles, the pho, the 5 spiced chicken, the fried rice...and I'm just left with a feel of eh...
author: Hiromi N.

description: Pho was delicious. If you take it to-go, they'll even refill you. Service was okay.
author: Roxy B.

description: My husband took me here for my first time.  I was disappointed.  We both ordered the garlic noodles, garlic chicken, and spicy calamari.  Both the garlic noodle and chicken had no garlic taste to it.  I believe the cook must have forgotten or was so frugal that he forgot to add it in.  The spicy calamari was not spicy at all.  Of all the ingredients , the main one is left out.  Bottom line, I've tasted better elsewhere .
author: Mary L.

description:
Everything about my experience here was good, so I'm giving it 5 starts because I have nothing bad to say.

The fresh veggie spring rolls were huge!  And the sauce was delicate but packed with flavor.  

The hot and sour soup had an amazing twist, there's pineapple in it!  I've never seen that before and it made the flavor incredible.  It was ust the right amount of spice also; not so hot that you're burning your tongue off, but certainly not mild either.

My friend ordered the lemongrass tofu, which came with lots of yummy green beans.  It was incredible; fragrant, soft, and I was really impressed with the amount of veggies.  I feel like it was almost healthy ;-)

Our other friend ordered the veggie crispy fried egg noodles.  Amazing texture for those noodles, and pretty good flavor, but I enjoyed the other two dishes more.
author: Sarah M.

description: I went there last night for the first time with some friends and we were all completely impressed! Service was fast and friendly and the food was amazing. Proportions were HUGE and very reasonably priced and everything was delicious. We got the vegetable, beef, and seafood soups, as well as the vegetable pot stickers -- so excited these exist! -- and crispy noodles with vegetables. We all had enough leftovers for another meal!
author: Daniel G.

description:
Slam dunk!  The scents coming out of this place from the street were a giveaway.  My friend and I walked right in and were seated immediately (it was probably 9:30PM on a Saturday).

We ordered the veggie rolls for appetizers - they're huge, soft and fresh with fish and Hoisin sauces for dipping.

The entrées we ordered were curried eggplant and the BBQ pork.  The eggplant was perfectly cooked.  It wasn't dried out or too mushy.  The curry flavor was spot on, and it wasn't too spicy for my taste either.  Just watch out for those hot peppers!  The BBQ pork was so delicious.  I had been craving this all day as I lay in bed hungover.  I will certainly go here again and eat it all up.

Pricing is affordable.  The service was very friendly and chill.  We were the last people to leave and we felt bad for keeping them, but then as we left another couple came in and I thought it was closing time, but the servers welcomed them in.  So, they're open late!
author: Rachel S.

description:
Quick, cheap, and yummy. It is not the best, but it certainly is not the worse in town. It is really bare bones, hole in the wall, so I always get take out. Never had a dish I didn't like here. 

It is good enough to help with any Vietnamese food cravings you may have.
author: Amelia M.

description:
One of the better Vietnamese restaurants I've had in the city
5 spiced chicken -kinda sweet, tender chicken
Beef vermicelli w imperial roll ( loaded with goodies; potato, mushroom bean sprouts and other veggies/meats I can't remember

Veggie pancake- fried w tofu bean sprouts really bland until you pour the sauce over. Directions on how to eat would have been nice because a 2nd plate came out w lettuce leaves cucumber pickled carrots and we all looked at each other confused. We didn't know what the heck to do with it other then eat it. I made mine into a pancake. Serves 4 nicely. 

Shaken beef - crispy

Garlic noodles- meh, I've had better. chow mein noodles with chunks of garlic...thats basically it. 

I feel this is a place you can be adventurous and pick something new to you and it would taste fantastic.  

Our waiter stole the show, he was hilarious. He handed the bill to the guy in our group and told him to pay (ahahah) that he looked like a "boss" lololool. He also told me to have chicken soup cooked with wine and my baby will pop out. lmao.
author: Christina C.

description: Once in a while I come here because it's in my neighborhood. I always get the vermicelli with shrimp and imperial rolls. It's always tasty. That's all I have to say.
author: Mandy H.

description:
I'd suggest going to the takeout side of the restaurant. It's closer to the kitchen so it seems to be faster than the other side. My girlfriend and I regularly come here to get hangover recovery pho.

Their garlic noodles with chicken are also great.
author: Franklin H.

description:
Came on a Friday evening with 4 other girls.

The portions here are really quite large, which makes anybody happy, and the prices are relatively low, which is even better.  The servers are really friendly and were super accommodating to our request to pay with multiple credit cards.  I realize how annoying that can be for any restaurant (esp. one where the prices aren't high at all), but they smiled and said it wouldn't be a problem.

Why only 3 stars then?  My gauge for most Vietnamese places has been the five spice chicken.  Golden Star is my #1 and this place didn't compare.  It was good, but had a more "soggy" type exterior (dunno how else to describe it) that I didn't like as much as at GS.  

It's very reasonably priced and my friends all liked their dishes (veggie pho, pho, and another chicken/veggie dish). There's a good chance I"d stop by again in the future if I'm in the area.
author: Naoko M.

description:
The shaken beef is really tender and flavorful.  Sometimes I order that, and that alone for dinner.

The garlic noodles are really tasty, too.  Just about everything on their menu is reliably good and affordable.  Great last-minute go-to place for take-out dinner!
author: Chris Y.

description:
It's rare that I leave a 1 star review. This place deserves maybe a star and a half.

We were seated right away. A minute later, the waiter asks us if we want to order. I know what I want, and my cousin who was with me appeared to be. We looked at each other and paused for like 2 seconds, and the waiter said "If you're not ready just say so and I'll come back." A bit rude, but they were busy so all is good. "Yeah, we'll need another minute or two."

My cousin decided what he wanted, and I waved to the waiter as he passed by. Ignored. A couple of minutes later, he walks by again, and I hold the closed menu up suggesting we're ready. Ignored again. Some new patrons two tables over came in and the waiter ignored me a third time to take their order before ours. Was this passive aggressive behavior a result of us not ordering right away? In his defense, he was the only waiter taking orders, with one other person serving and clearing. Definitely need another front of house person.

After a good 10 minutes, Mr PAWD (passive-aggressive-waiter-dude) takes our order. We get the chicken salad to share, my cousin orders the beef pho, and I order the lemon grass pork and imperial rolls on vermicelli.

The salad was okay. We were both feeling like eating some raw greenery and that hit the spot.

My cousin's pho was warm. Warmer than lukewarm, but  not after he added his bean sprouts, basil, and peppers. Lukewarm pho... yuck. Nowhere near as hot as it should have been. And it was bland. And in my opinion, pho should have tripe, tendon, rare steak, and brisket.  I shouldn't complain about this, because it's not listed on the menu, but that should have been the sign to stay away.

The lemon grass pork and imperial rolls on vermicelli was so-so. The imperial rolls were okay. The same as I'd expect from a run-of-the-mill Vietnamese restaurant in the 'loin or the avenues. The lemon grass pork, however, was way too lean and tough. And the fact that they overcooked the crap out of it didn't help.

I don't understand why this place gets so crowded. Oh wait, I know... Perhaps because reasonably-priced Asian food is lacking in the Mission. Looks like there's some good opportunities a waitin'... Maybe I'll moonlight with a pho cart.
author: J K.

description:
A small little place but with lots of review from yelp, so thought will give it a try.

I really wanted to order the lemongrass beef, but was afraid they will over cook the beef.  So I thought on the safe side  I should order  the Lemongrass chicken instead...  But I guess it wasn't not safe enough :( the chicken was still dry...  The string beans were a nice surprise...

But their sweet & sour soup that came with the lunch really saved the day! It reminds me of the yummy Catfish sweet & sour soup. It was the right  flavor with pineapple, and just perfect for a sunny day.
author: Coco L.

description: This is a local fave of mine. The main server here is sooo nice and has been very accommodating when I've come in very close to closing time. The food is always tasty, ready in a flash and the service is great. This isn't fine dining, so don't come here looking for that. It is a reliable, friendly, tasty place for Vietnamese with no frills. The price is right and the food is, too.
author: K H.

description:
Welp, I found it, the best veggie pho I've had so far. 

It is a garden variety of fresh delicious veggies and tofu chopped up and stuffed into a bowl which also happens to contain broth and noodles.

Eventually, after dutifully picking away sumptuous vegetables and tofu, my pho looked liked what I'd previously known as veggie pho. Veggie pho is dead, long live veggie pho.
author: Alan F.

description: Reasonably priced and delicious! The pho is delicious! The only problem is service is a little slow.
author: Mia M.

description: We stopped here for dinner and had a wonderful time.  Actually, we ordered to go but the food was excellent.  We love the garlic noodles with veggies and the beef fried rice.  We always ask them to hold the fish powder, and they use very fresh ingredients and quality meat.  The waiter is a great guy and alyas appreciates your business.  This and the location in Potrero is a wonderful place to eat.  Great lunch specials also!
author: D.c.g G.

description:
I love in Southern California; however, whenever I visit my friends up north, we always take a trip to Sunflower.
They have a large and small restaurant around the corner from one another, but sometimes the larger one is closed so you may have to wait for a table, but it's well worth it.
I've been going here every time I visit San Francisco, have gotten countless dishes & have never been disappointed once.
They're Fresh Spring Rolls & Fresh Vegetarian Spring Rolls are delicious and great to get together if you're in a group. I sometimes will get the Vietnamese Deep Fried Tofu as my meal rather than an appetizer & it definitely does the job.
Their Vegetarian Salad & all of their Pho are winners too.
Basically, you can't go wrong at Sunflower.
author: Manda S.

description:
My favorite dish: Garlic noodles with prawns!!!

Nice, attentive staff...a little cramped but the food is great!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Large portions, low prices.  The Asian in me loved it.  I was congested the night I went so I had the chicken pho which was pretty tasty, not too salty with a lot of stuff in it.  I don't think I got through half of it.  I also tried the spring rolls, garlic noodles, a grilled chicken and  a beef dish, maybe shaking beef.  Everything was really tasty and again, big.  

I'll be back to try other things, particularly the crepe.  I've been craving it.
author: Seong P.

description: Love the veggie spring rolls, the sunflower prawns with garlic noodles and shaken beef.
author: Alison F.

description:
I met a friend here last night for dinner and boy was it a treat!  Upon arriving, there were a couple of parties ahead of us in the main dining room, but a nice gentleman advised us that if we went around the corner on 16th street we could see if there were any tables in the smaller room.  Apparently, if you walk around the corner it's the same restaurant, just the other side of the kitchen (the place is shaped like an L).  It didn't seem as fancy as the main dining room, but it's the exact same food, so no biggie.  I overheard some other patrons saying it was the "take out" location, but there were still about 5 tables.  

The food was delicious and nice to my wallet.  I had the Lemongrass beef with imperial rolls over vermicelli.  The beef had a delicate slightly sweet and salty flavor.  And there were adequate vegetables hiding under the pile of vermicelli.      My friend had the vegetable pho.  It was a huge mountain of food.  I didn't try it since I was busy being a carnivore, but he said it was good.  

At the end of the night we both had enough food left for another meal, a great bonus!  I can't wait to try their other dishes.  I'll be back soon!
author: Nita K.

description: The bf and I live in the neighborhood and he's a pho-fanatic. We started coming here when we first moved to this part of town and now we come here more than any other restaurant in the Mission! The food is awesome and consistent, the server who seems to work there the most (calls us "young man" and "young lady" - ADORBS) is super sweet, and the bill is under $20 for two noodle soups. I get the seafood noodle soup and it's bomb.com. They don't have fish-balls in theirs like other places but the fish-cake is tasty. When it's crappy and rainy out, I dream of Sunflower.
author: Alexa V.

description: Solid Vietnamese cuisine, friendly service, very reasonably priced (noodle soups are less than $10), and generally not too hard to get a table (unless it's Friday or Saturday night).  I don't care for their potstickers too much - the sauce is bland and the dough is too thick.  But, I generally order their spring rolls and a noodle soup and I have never been disappointed with those.  Both locations are good and have the same food.
author: Preethi C.

description:
This place was really good.  We got the lemon grass chicken and vermicelli with pork and imperial rolls.  Both were good and i would get them again.  The vermicelli was definitely the winner though.  The service was really good despite having to try really hard to get our check.  

I would go back if I was in the area, but probably wouldn't travel too far for it.
author: Aaron L.

description: Yes the food is delicious and cheap but the service is beyond bad. The owner is rude and arrogant. We watched him tell a couple they would have to wait an hour to be served because they ordered wrong. What? He was slow to serve us for some unknown reason. When we told him we would never be back, he said he was lucky.
author: Sharon B.

description:
Very solid, fairly authentic Vietnamese food.  Like a cleaner version of Tu Lan.  The vermicelli noodles and imperial rolls are comparable taste wise, although the Tu Lan ones seem a little more substantial and meaty (but they also give me wicked indigestion so I think the point goes to Sunflower here).  

The "Vietnamese crepe" (Banh xeo) was very good actually-- I just had one in Vietnam a couple of months ago and this one was as good, if not better.

A great place to satiate your noodle craving at a reasonable price.  I heard a rumor they're opening another location in Potrero Hill and I am looking forward to trying the Pho and other menu items.
author: Kristin P.

description: I love this place.  A real Gem!  The Garlic Noodles are to die for.  Also terrific is the Pho.  Always comes through with good delicious food and never disappoints.
author: Daniel P.

description:
