The reason I'm giving this place 5 stars is the food.  Hands down delicious.  I've never ordered anything else but the lunch special, mind you, and I haven't ever been tempted to.  The lunch special is probably one of the best deals in town (7 days a week until 4pm!!! $8.50 for an entree, rice, soup, an imperial roll and cabbage salad!) If you order the lemongrass chicken or prawns lunch combo, it is an absolute perfect meal if you ask me (I'm a San Francisco native who has frequented many a Vietnamese restaurant in my life).  

Bring quarters for meters.  Parking can be rough.  Eat at either location (16th St. address vs. Val , it doesn't matter.  Same food, though I have had better service in general on the Valencia side.  There are a couple of very impersonal, rude-ish servers (one is a balding stocky man with a ponytail), and one real sweetheart of a waitress, but the service is not the drawing point at a restaurant like this.  

Give the lunch combo a shot.  You can thank me later!
author: Aurora B.

description:
Been here a couple times since my cousin lives a block away. I'm dying to try the imperial rolls, but I've never had them.  I tried to order them last night as an app, but Tyler M reminded me of how bad they are and how much transfat is packed into them.  So we opted for the steamed dumplings and spring rolls with shrimp instead of the fried goodness of the imperial rollz.

Steamed dumplings - delicious, and the peanut-esque sauce served with them is an A++
Fresh spring rolls - better than the ones at Out the Door, which were on the 7x7 SF's Big Eat list.

We shared a beef noodle entrée, a jumbo shrimp noodle dish, the chicken pho, and a crispy veggie noodle entree.  All were pretty decent, I liked mine and the pho the best.  I've also had the chicken vermicelli before and the five spiced chicken.  Those items were just OK.

There's always about a 15-20 minute wait here, even though they tell you 5-10 minutes when you arrive.  The service is pretty slow and you actually have to ask for the bill, your drink, etc.  The servers/owner are super friendly, though.  My favorite Vietnamese restaurant is still Cordon Bleu!
author: Jenny W.

description:
really nothing special. nothing was terrible, but nothing was impressive either.

given how many amazing vietnamese places there are in the city, it is not worth a try.
author: Danielle A.

description:
A few red flags upon entering.  Other than the help, no vietnamese present.  Only whites.  No chili, fish, or hoisin sauces on the tables upon entering.  And instead of bringing tea to the table, the bring out water.  Forks on all the tables as well, which was a bit disturbing, especially since the word "authentic" is in the restaurant name (which is a red flag as well).

Asked for tea when saw they weren't just gonna bring it out, and ended up having to pay for tea at an "authentic vietnamese restaurant."

With that said, the pho wasn't horrible, but wasn't good.  Not much flavor to it.  Small bowls, and only one size.  Chilies on the garnish plate were pretty hot, which was nice.  decent amount of noodles, but the beef was in little strips, and there wasn't much of it.

Would only go back if I were dating a smoking hot girl who really, really wanting to go this exact spot.
author: cheddar b.

description:
Good food, huge portions for very little money. What's not to like? 

We ordered the Shaken Beef. GOOD! 
Garlic Noodles. GOOD! 
5 spice grilled chicken. This was the only dish I didn't really care for. But everything else was good. 

Wouldn't go out of my way to come here, but if I were in the area and hungry again, maybe I would stop by.
author: Jen D.

description:
I am in search of a Viet place that does not charge me up the wazzu like the oh-too-popular Slanted Door.  Does anyone remember Golden Turtle of yesteryear?  Yeah, like them.  
I ventured in here for lunch and got one of the combo plates.  I found the soup to be delightful, as well as the imperial roll, but the green beans and shrimp to be eh.  Still, with the prices as cheap as they are, I am sure to be back.  I mean, please!  A full lunch with 2 glasses of house white wine and tip for $20?!  Done and done.  Yes, I drink at lunch, what about it?
author: e w.

description:
Easily accessible (a block from 16th St BART), small Vietnamese Restaurant. Tasty food and friendly staff. 

Cheap carafes of white wine for $12 (not 'great' wine but not too shabby either).
author: Anna R.

description:
This place is not bad. Foods at Mission cannot be bad or they will be out of business soon due to the fierce competition. I would give it a 4 star if their price is a bit cheaper. 

Their portion is HUGE by the way.
author: Lo Y.

description: I went here with a friend while on vacation several years ago.  I got the fish pot dish, and it was very tasty.  I wish I could remember more details to share, but I would go again.  I like the neighborhood and the interior was comfortable.
author: Wes F.

description:
A friend and I stopped by for lunch yesterday. It wasn't very crowded, which was perfect, so the food was ready relatively quickly. I had the Chicken Curry and my friend had the Seafood Noodle Soup. The curry was OK, the soup was awful. The broth had NO flavor (almost as if they'd poured tap water into the bowl) and the seafood was not fresh. My friend was ill about 2 hours later. And not just sick, deathly ill (from both ends, if you catch my drift).

YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED...
author: Anthony B.

description:
Short and quick review.

Too much wrapper on my Cha Gio, at one point it only tasted like wrapper.

Not enough flavor in my Seafood pho.

Pretty good Pho Bo.
Not a big enough selection, I miss my normal Dac Biet!

All in all, would come again if I was in the area, but does not deserve a special trip!
author: Winè C.

description:
Amazing and refreshing Vegetarian Noodle Soup. 

Pros:
- cheap
- soup is light and refreshing
- service is amazing. My friend and I were ordering what we didnt think was too much food and the waiter kindly told us that we should wait to see if we wanted more because what we'd ordered already was enough for 4. Good thing we waited. We took a lot home. 

Cons: 
- the place was a bit crowded and not well lit, but really who cares when the food is great?
author: Arti D.

description:
Went here last week. Got the Garlic Noodles. Simple, yet utterly satisfying. The end.

What's up with the 2 addresses? I went to the one that's on Valencia, not 16th. Is there a difference? Is there a secret tunnel that links them together? Maybe we'll never know. If you don't know, they are literally right around the corner from each other.

Next time, gotta try the Pho, and some Vietnamese Coffee.
author: Ken L.

description: Food is cheap and phenomenal. I'm from the east coast and have never had vietnamese food as good as this place ( this includes all of NYC). The servers are kinda rude but so is 80% of San Francisco so I did not mind. Gotta get the garlic noodles, beef cubes, crab fried rice, those Vietnamese egg roll things and a tall cold beer.
author: Owen M.

description:
Why hello super sized carafe of wine for less than $14.  I think you'll accompany my chicken vermicelli just perfectly.  

Great food (and service) at a great price.  No wonder there's a line down the block sometimes.
author: Laura S.

description: Returned to Sunflower after about a year last night.  Been going since the 80's.  Sadly I feel it is going down hill.  Had the vermicelli with chicken and an imperial roll.  The imperial roll was obviously old, my stomach has been rolling all morning and I can still taste it in my mouth.  The vermicelli was about the same, not fresh.  The chicken tasted OK but all in all nothing seemed fresh.  I have always loved Sunflower but I doubt I will ever go again.
author: Mike T.

description: I visit this place several times a week for a nice bowl of beef pho. It is just SOOOO tastey! The service is okay, but the price of the food is awesome. Other than the cooks constantly screaming in Vietnamese, the ambience is nice as well. Oh and if you happen to be looking for amazing imperial rolls, look no further!
author: Alex G.

description:
I'd like to make this sound like some cheesy Mervyn's - esque review that talks about value and at some point uses the phrase "in this economy" BUT...  I'm not a total douchebag (just a partial one).

Oh and unfortunately the above assertion is kind of true.  This is mainly based on my brunch experience.  Go on the weekends.  Yeah, the little room isn't everyone's favorite spot, but it was cozy enough for me and my friends.  Order one of the lunch combos.  For roughly $8 (not including beer) you can get a whole pile of food which included spring rolls, chicken, green beans, brown rice, veggies and some soup.  

I dunno about you guys but in my book, that is a deal.  One of my friends took the rest of hers to go and ate it for dinner.  Oh and everything was tasty.  It wasn't some half done or gross BS, this was good food.

I don't get the comments about the service.  Our waiter was ridiculously nice.  Maybe he was new.
author: Steven R.

description:
I suppose Sunflower does the trick when you're out to satisfy your pho craving and there's no other pho in sight (that is, within a short walking or driving distance). That said, the pho left much to be desired.

We had pho, garlic noodles with prawns, and sauteed vegetables with tofu. 

First the pho. Initially, I was excited to see the medium/large bowl of steaming pho approach. Upon its descent to the table my disappointment began. 

The good: a generous plate of basil, bean sprouts, peppers, and lime. The bad: a parsimonious serving of rice noodles and four slim slices of medium and well-done beef clumped together. Nevertheless, the broth had a hearty beefy flavor that helped to satisfy my craving. Bottom line: decent pho is sometimes better than no pho. 

Next, the garlic noodles. They served a generous helping of somewhat soggy, but garlicky noodles (refined wheat flour?) with five or six medium sized prawns. The noodles were tasty but too greasy for me. 

Lastly, the sauteed vegetables. The large plate arrived with a good variety of vegetables - broccoli, cauliflower, carrots, and onions - soaking in all-purpose brown sauce and "garnished" with several pieces of tofu. The veggies were fresh, but I could have dispensed with the greasy brown sauce. 

Over all the food was decent, the service was fast and friendly, and the meal was inexpensive.
author: Chris T.

description:
I had the shrimp vermicelli bowl with imperial rolls. The shrimp tasted a little over cooked and rather bland, but the noodles were good, fish sauce was a bit lacking, there were lots of veggies, the bowl was large and full, and the prices were right in line with most of the vermicelli places I go to (which has to be a plus for this place as I was eating out in the Big City, like a real grown up and wasn't paying a premium for the privilege).

My friend, the local, substituted her imperial rolls for a fresh roll when ordering - I had the opportunity to mimic her local knowledge but passed - that turned out to be a mistake.

Her fresh roll was large and looked super tasty - the imperial rolls I got had thick shells - almost like the frozen ones from the supermarket as opposed to the super think and flaky ones I've typically experienced with this kind of dish. 

Service was typical - efficient and a little brusque (just the way I like it) and the check actually came to the table (as opposed to the normal note your table number and pay at the counter).

We must have gotten seated just in time, as when we left there were plenty of city dwellers waiting for a table to become available.
author: Tim H.

description:
The food here is good, by no means not the best I've ever had. With the exception of the Sea Bass. Very good sea bass! 

The Chicken vermicelli noodle bowl was okay. The spring rolls were decent but not super fresh. The peanut sauce was decent but not exciting!

It's a tiny location, with just seven tables, they mostly serve take out.  We were practically kicked out as they were closing. I understand closing, but you could be nice about it. Not great service.
author: Marissa P.

description: love the pho, just a little thick for my taste, I love the broth.
author: Bryan T.

description:
Went here with the bf and ordered the garlic noodles with beef and vegetable vermicelli with tofu and mushrooms.  The portions were large for lunch.  The flavors were all there.  The only issue we found with the garlic noodles was that it was monotonous.  It always gets boring when eating the same greasy flavors over and over again.  Perhaps we should have added Sriacha or it would have been nice to have some pickles or kimchi or something.  

I would go back!
author: dublin a.

description:
Good beef pho.  Not the best I've had but I'd go back for it :) The bowl is huge and they give the usual beansprout/leaves/lime on the side.  

Super casual place and I didn't have to wait long at all before my food showed up.  Sorta dark in there tho.
author: S T.

description:
Dudes, dudes, dudes... who DOESN'T love this place????

The food is always fresh, fresh, fresh, and sooooo tasty!!! Everything I've tried!!! 

The crepes, the various iterations of the lunch special, the vermicelli, I mean, it's always great, all the time. Whenever I am in that neck of the woods, I always find myself slowly veering toward it... and I am so satisfied whenever I leave.

The prices are great, and the nondescript hole-in-the-wall thing works perfectly here. I feel like I have entered a cozy little happy world. There is something really sweet and old-school about it... makes me want to muse, chat, and otherwise engage in lost dining arts.

How glad am I to coexist in this universe with Sunflower. Indeed.
author: Dusty R.

description:
i will never come back there after the waiter called my girlfriend "stupid"! just because we already finished our dinner and two other friends joined us and took another chair from another table, this waiter started to yell on us "go to hotel"! "you stupid"

anyway the place smells like sweat, food is ok, big dishes, but what's makes it big is allot of chip noodles and lettuce! 

on friday night they give you the bill while your'e still eating and just want to kick you out after you paid

discrase
author: Jony G.

description: Good n cheap, what more could a gal want? No, you're not going to get gourmet spring rolls. But you will get a mountain of sinfully salty but delicious garlic noodles. They skimp out a bit on the meat and veggies, but I kinda don't care when I'm chowin down on delish noodles. Seriously, the portion size for the noodles is insane. Pretty sure most grown men can't finish them in one sitting. If you're hungry and don't feel like droppin a ton of $$$, hit up Sunflower!
author: Elise A.

description: Whenever I am in the mood for Pho I come here. I've been here about 5 times now and love everytime I come. The taste and the speed service go hand in hand and it makes for a quick, cheap, and nice lunch or dinner. I have yet to actually try something besides the Pho because it's really good. The wait staff is really nice too. I never have to wait for a table!
author: Ezequiel R.

description: THIS PLACE DOES NOT EVEN DESERVE ANY STARS. I went there for dinner with my friend and the waiter asked us to change tables. Since the restaurant was not crowded and there were other tables available, we asked if we could sit in our original spot. The waiter threw a fit, took our menus away, and threw us out of the restaurant. The end.
author: Seema P.

description:
We really went for the spring rolls, and although they are not quite traditional and I've had better, they are gluten-y packages of love in an easy location.  The decor is what you would expect from a cheap Vietnamese place, which isto say not outwardly dirty (although the lighting is super dim...hiding something, or saving on electricity bills, Sunflower?), but nothing that you would call your decorator about to demand replication.  We arrived at 6ish on a Thursday night, and the place was almost completely full, and service was quick and efficient--din took an hour, max--which was excellent b/c we were starving, but our waiter was completely MIA after we placed our orders.  Water was refilled ever so often; however, he would scurry away before I could articulate my desire for tea.  Perhaps he could detect that I'm a little HM...

Regardless, for mains we had the garlic vegetables and the vegetarian hot and sour soup.  Both were decent--the veggies were nice and crisp in the garlic dish, but the sauce was a bit heavy on the thickener and without the piquancy I would have expected from a garlic dish.  My soup was interesting/weird/probably wouldn't order it again but the more I ate it the more I kind of enjoyed it.  My spoon smelled aggressively of plastic, which I thought was the initial reason for my reaction to it, but upon pondering for a moment, it became clear that the flavor of canned pineapple (which was part of the soup) dominated all the other flavors.  Yes, I did read that this was an ingredient, but no, I did not expect my soup to be quite the tropical adventure that it was.  On the plus side it was a light choice.  They have a decent selection of vegetarian options (although all of the veggie dishes list a "secret house sauce" which I'm fairly sure must be fish sauce b/c no Asian restaurant worth its salt in authenticity can cook w/o it)--but I didn't want to ask, I just wanted to eat.

Are there better Vietnamese places out there?  Yes.  But dinner for 2 was cheap--$32 w/o tip--and the portions were generous.  Not a bad meal, but I think I'll continue my search for truly divine veggie-friendly Vietnamese in the area (suggestions welcome!)
author: Rachel N.

description:
This place is Ethnically Chinese, Culturally Vietnamese.  And does it show in the food?  Most Definitely.  My friend overheard them speaking Cantonese once day, and we knew instantly.  After all, it was the language of commerce in South Vietnam way back in the day.

I always come here after yoga for the fresh spring rolls with shrimp served with peanut sauce, chicken rolls with fish sauce, and fresh veggie rolls with soy sauce.  These are definitely lighter, healthier options.  The portions are big, and the price is right.  Overall a great choice if you're craving Vietnamese in the mission.
author: Tracy N.

description:
went to Sunflower Valencia St in December with my partner.  He is older than me and an attractive guy.  On being seated the waiter gave the menus to him and said how good looking he was.  We took this in stride and ordered.  Later her fatness came back with drinks and was rubbing my partners leg.  My partner asked him to stop as it made him uncomfortable.  The guy stormed away and refused to get us water and kept saying he needed the table.  He took the food before we were done eating.  When I insisted he not get a tip my partner slipped a five into the bill.  The waiter ran over to check the check and when he saw the low tip flipped out.  He threw dishes and yelled at us.  Everyone in the restaurant was looking and as we left my partner threw more money on the table in embarrassment ( this is still an issue with us as I wanted to throw a drink in the guys face.)
The food is great.  The hot pot of rice and sausage was incredible.  We will never eat there again as long as that rude and delusional waiter is around
author: Peter C.

description: Pretty good vietnamese food.  Very solid, and some of the better vietnamese you can find in the city.  Unfortunately that's not saying much...the vietnamese down in the south bay is so much better and more authentic than what you can find in the city.  Still, if you don't want to drive that extra hour down to the south bay, Sunflower is a solid, decent choice for vietnamese.
author: Cat L.

description:
Sunflower is an authentic Vietnamese restaurant in the heart of Mission district; really easy to get to by both MUNI & BART.  I am happy to have discovered this affordable, delicious and convenient nook. 

Sunflower is my personal favorite Vietnamese spot in the city. Authentic, spicy, well-prepared meal featuring a wide variety of traditional selection plus their own original dishes. The imperial rolls are worth the hype for a group setting appetizer. Order the Vermicelli sections if you are a weary traveler- pleasantly arranged with an assort of vegetables, savoring sauces and vermicelli done right. 

We had: 

Imperial Rolls - lightly fried spring rolls. Not that greasy. I think it's worth having at least once. 
Pho Chay - vegetable pho. WOW. For all y'all vegans out there, order this dish and be blow away by the plentiful veges including: mushrooms, carrots, snow peas, celery, sprouts, mint, basil, peppers, etc. 
Garlic green beans with shitake mushrooms- i like the type of green beans here cooked in savory garlic sauce. Good with jasmine rice. 
Vegetarian Vermicelli - cold-served with lots of yum veges. 

A Must try! Good for both vegans & meat lovers.
author: Jack C.

description: I am a fan of Vietnamese food and there are only a few options in the mission. They are super friendly and fast service. The beef noodle soup is my favorite!
author: Curtis S.

description:
Hands down one of my favorite places to eat in the mission!  Great food, affordable prices, and quite a bit of variety.  The one down side is they are usually short-staffed on waiters, but I think the pro's definitely outweighh the con's.

I highly recommend the garlic noodles (oh so good!).  The spring rolls and hot & sour soup are delicious!  In my numerous times eating here I've tried at least a dozen different entrees and I'm impressed with everything from the pho to the noodle dishes.  Definitely check it out!!
author: Adit V.

description:
Best part of my meal here:
the epic Vietnamese Crepe I consumed.  Seriously, delish.  And super cheap.  Meal for 2 = $16.  Not bad.

Second best part of my meal here:
My waiter got in a fight with another server.  No joke, it was AWESOME.  I'll do my best to reconstruct the chain of events that led to my entertainment:

Other Server (OS): Hello, you want soda?  You want tea?
My Waiter (MW): Phang, they my table! You go take care of your own!
OS: No, this one mine, you had four-top in front.
MW: (Shoves OS to the side) No, this my section!  (to us) I apologize.  I bring you some tea?
OS: (Aghast) Bng này là ca tôi, asshole!
MW: Nhn c off ca bn bn tay khách hàng ca tôi!
OS: (Storms off angrily) M ca bn hng v ca ci bp và donkey butt...

AWESOME.
author: Mari C.

description:
Some people have asked if The Ex reads the reviews that feature him as the Blanche to my Baby Jane.

And I wonder: Is this a serious question? I sure hope he does -- I EMAIL THEM TO HIM. Bitch, please. We're friends blah blah blah asshole blah. And anyway, what, do you think I'm some sort of fucking wallflower pussy afraid of confrontation? BUWAHAHAHAHAHA! FUCK NO. Let me be perfectly clear about this: I AM NOT AFRAID OF CONFRONTATION, so fuck you! What do I look like, Japanese? Shut up.

Anyway, all couples have their favorite restaurants and preferred hangouts. Perhaps it was where they first met, or fell in love, or fucked in the bathroom -- the permutations of this particular elective affinity are endless. For The Ex and me, one place was Sunflower. It wasn't the site of our first "date"; it wasn't close and it didn't have the "best" Vietnamese food. No, we were here because Sunflower was (and still is) cheap and the portions were (and still are) HUGE -- perfect for sublimating our problems and avoiding interpersonal issues by overeating. So Ex, you gonna go out drinking again, whore? I mean, PASS THE IMPERIAL ROLLS. You better not drag your drunken ass home at 2 am like this morning -- QUIT HOGGING THE FISH SAUCE, FUCK!

Speaking of the Imperial Rolls, they were always well-fried, plentiful, and brimming with shredded pork, carrots, and taro root. I usually opted for the BBQ Lemongrass Beef as my entree, which really should be known as BIG FUCKING PLATE OF GRILLED BEEF. The lemongrass was particularly strong in the marinade, and Sunflower was very generous with the diced peanuts as a garnish -- a plus in my book.

Also, we referred to Sunflower as "Very Nice" -- as in, "let's go to 'Very Nice'" -- because of a waiter who, I kid you not, said this as a refrain after EVERY STATEMENT if he wasn't asking a question.

"I'll have the BBQ Lemongrass Beef" "Very nice!"
"How is the Seabass Filet?" "Very nice!"
"I'm originally from Hawai`i" "Very nice!"
"I think I'm coming down with a cold." "Very nice!"
"Yes, this is my boyfriend." "Very nice!"

Needless to say, Mr. "Very Nice" was rather smitten with The Ex -- to the point of forgetting that I, too, was dining in the restaurant. HELLO?!? I wasn't concerned about this infatuation -- in fact I found it cute in an ABC Afterschool Special way -- and I knew The Ex didn't regard Mr. "Very Nice" in THAT way.

The last time we were there, Mr. "Very Nice" was chatting us up. It was December, and I had mentioned that I planned to visit Hawai`i for the holidays.

Mr. VN: Oh, very nice! How long you be dere?
Me: Around three weeks.
Mr. VN: Very nice! And you, you fly with him too?
The Ex: No, not at the same time. I'll be visiting later, in January.
Mr. VN: Oh, very nice!

After we finished our dinner I ducked into the bathroom. When I returned, The Ex was sitting rigidly in his chair.

Me: Er, what's up?
The Ex: ...
Me: Are you okay? You look like you just saw a ghost.
The Ex: Ummm. The waiter.
Me: Yeah?
The Ex: The waiter...gave me his phone number.
Me: WHAT?!?
The Ex: Yeah. And, AND, he told me to call him when you're in Hawai`i. So we can...hangout.
Me: Shit! ARE YOU FUCKING KIDDING ME?!?
The Ex: No!
Me: Well gee, Ex, maybe you should give him a buzz. I'm sure he's a 'very nice' fuck.
The Ex: Oh shut up.

I'm pretty sure I left a 20% tip.
author: d s.

description:
Sunflower is decent. It's a solid choice if you're in the Mission and want pho. I always get either the chicken or vegetarian pho bowl and it's flavorful and they give you lots. They also give you a plate with more than enough of the add-ons, like basil, soybean sprouts, lime, etc etc.

There is a gay asian waiter/host with ATTITUDE - some people hate him, but he makes shit happen and keeps that place running. He's also funny and nice but will definitely usher you out as soon as your plate is cleared, because this place is always crowded and people are waiting for tables.
author: Lina L.

description: I used to like this place. Food is decent but not great. Tried to go there tonight, but the waiter was very rude to us from the moment we walked in. We left before even getting menus. It's no wonder the place was empty. Won't be going back.
author: Wan T.

description:
The service is ALWAYS friendly--even when the two waiters, whom I secretly think are in love with each other fight like hell in the kitchen!

Their vegetarian pho is fucking amazing! ALL their salads are great- especially their calamari salad! 

their lunch special is the greatest deal you can find on food anywhere in the city! 

We also love their seafood dish on the dinner menu - I think it is number 56 or 65, can't remember! 

They are really cheap! But still, tip those waiters more because they really work their asses off!
author: Maddy S.

description:
EDIT 08/26/07:  I ate here tonight with a friend; it was charged to his card, and while he didn't leave a huge tip, one of the servers took a look at the receipt and asked him why he didn't give a larger tip.  He then left it at the table, as if to have him change it before he would accept it.  My friend didn't change a thing, and another server came by to pick up the check.  

Staff should never dispute a tip given by a customer.  You just don't do that.

---------------------  

My vermicelli bowl was alright, not as flavorful as I would've hoped.  But the portion to price ratio is definitely in your favor--prices are cheap and the portions are humongous.  I couldn't even finish my dish, a rarity.  There are several vegetarian options.  Service was quick and friendly. 

The dining area on the Valencia St side is more pleasant, less noise, less crowded, and more spacious.  Enter on 16th St, and you dine in the same room where the kitchen is.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
Honestly, when you walk in here, you think roach motel city coupled with oily and make shift V-food.

Wrong.  It's just mildly roach city (even though I haven't seen one, cmon, it's the Mission).  But it's otherwise OK looking - definitely divey with o.g. Asian grandmother wood collages on the walls.  The place isn't immaculately clean, but I haven't see a bug.  Some of the tables are a bit sticky though.

So I've been here 4 times.  That number alone reveals something.  It's not bomb V-food, but they do make some things good.  Chicken pho had like 4 chickens in there.  Broth is a bit light, but it's hearty enough for a cold SF day.  The dry vermicelli noodle dishes are boring.  Shrimp was hard to find and it was just Plain Jane Tran.  Nothing to write home about.  What was worse was the beef salad.  We thought it was supposed to be carpaccio, but man, I wish it was.  The beef was baking soda tender and gritty, warm at best, and kinda chewy like a Jelly Worm.  Not cool.  Not even a little cool.

BUT, I did discover a rare treat.  The lemon grass string bean with shrimp with rice.  OK, now this simple dish was such a surprise.  Yes, you can't really get these ingredients wrong, but man, there was perfect amount of lemongrass, garlic, white onions, and the string beans were perfectly cooked - snappy, beautiful looking, and super fresh.  They were a bit stingy on the shrimp.  I mean, c'mon 5 pieces of shrimp?

The one waiter that I saw working 10 tables - that was a major feat.  He looks a bit Tales from the Crypt, but the dude is super cool and friendly.  He was humble and quick to answer any questions or requests.
author: Isaac L.

description:
It's an average neighborhood Vietnamese joint.

*Good food
*Good prices 
*Lunch Specials are a great value
*Flavor & taste are ok
author: Christina D.

description: Went there during lunch and ordered the lemon grass beef lunch special. The food was excellent, my lunch special was huge and came with a little taste of everything. The lemon grass beef was recommended by the waiter and it did not disappoint. The rest of my co-workers at the table were very satisfied with their meals (especially the garlic noodles). This place is great, good food, good service, great prices, we will definitely be going back.
author: Jones E.

description: Hipster prices, good quality. I got the lunch special with soup, rice, salad, and spicy lemongrass beef... it was quite good and I wolfed it down. Some of the beef was not hot but room temperature, which was disconcerting as I rarely eat meat in restaurants and get sketched out due to the food-poisoning potential.
author: Cooper S.

description:
It's small, kinda cramped, and not the best service I've ever seen...but the food is effing delicious!  They have a great selection for vegetarians.  The appetizers were out of this world.  We ordered vegetarian fresh spring rolls and Vietnamese deep fried tofu and they were both awesome.

I also had the vegetarian soup which I think is great for a girl on a diet.  The oil was almost nonexistent, it's full of veggies and tofu, and it tastes great!  Cootie and Basil were with me and the total for the three entrees and the appetizers was around $30...and we had plenty of leftovers.

I'm totally craving this awesome place.  I'm close to begging Cootie to meet me for lunch and then sitting in the BART for an extra half hour one of these days just to get some spring rolls.
author: PrincessPeac H.

description:
So I may have a few drinks prior visiting this fine establishment, but I doubt it skewed my ability to detect top notch food from Nam.  As say in the mission this place is Mucho Deliciouso (I took five years of French... I was in the honor society... dork - or is it geek? maybe nerd??)

They rushed us to order 'cause the kitchen was closing, but then let us eat at a leisurely pace.  The veggie spring rolls were some of the best I've ever had and the shakin' beef was like a party in my mouth and all the epileptic cows were invited.  

Come here and let that Slanted Door fall off its hinges.
author: Trevor F.

description:
1. Cheap and decent quality.
2. Not authentic (try speaking Viet to a staff/chef here and see if anyone knows what the hell you're saying).
3. A friend got food poisoning and I got diarrhea here once (out of the 5 times we've been here).  Agree with reviews of 3.5 stars but will subtract 1.5 stars for this.  :/
author: Gleason M.

description:
I had set up a first date of sorts at Truly Mediterranean; a first date, that is, with potential roommates found on Craigslist.  I was a bit twitchy,  wondering things like what my jacket choice said about me (khaki?  too mililtant?).  Well, I thought, at least I'd get some good Mediterranean food even if my date, I mean meeting, sucks.  

When I arrived outside Truly Med, the friendly enough-seeming dude & dudette gestured instead towards a grungy looking hole in the wall, saying "We thought we'd do Vietnamese instead."  Sure, guys.  No problem.  I've just been having sordid baba ghanoush fantasies all day, but yeah, bring on the fish sauce.  Not.  Happy.  Did I mention I'd never had Vietnamese food, and did not want to stress about poor menu choice on this awkward first non-date date?

Sigh.  We walk in to the tiny space and claim a table in the corner. awkward first date-like menu perusal ensues; "What did you major in?"  "Hm?  American Studies?  What's larb?"  "Larb?"  "Yeah, it was a multidisciplanary major.  I have no direction in life.  Larb, yeah.  What is it?"

And so it went, chit-chat stumbling on until my chicken salad arrived first in a vessel the size of a toilet bowl.  It looked suspiciously like an Asian rendition of a Taco Bell chicken salad, with ground meat, weird chips soaring out of the sides of the bowl, and no greens visible.  I peered over its height until my companions' dishes arrived, and the pho one of them had ordered had what looked suspiciously like a cocktail frank atop.  I eyed my chicken salad warily; this could be a huge zero.

First bite:  DELICIOUS!  (Oh, like you didn't know how this story would end).  I lavishly poured on sriracha, my new favorite condiment, and muched away at the zesty fresh melding of flavors (was that cilantro?  thai basil?) and knowing how much cheaper my meal would be than the mini-weener pho across the table.  Munch, munch, munch. Lots of greens at the bottom of the bowl.   "Sure, I believe in a home, not a house."  Munch, munch.  Would it be too awkward to ask to have the rest wrapped, I wondered halfway in and filled to capacity?  Would that illustrate my stinginess, my near destitute status?  Would I look like the type not to lend an egg? "Sure, I'm flexible about sharing groceries."

No worries.  The quiet yet attentive waiter brought over a to go carton and bag without nary an eye catch.  Four stars, sold to the girl in the khaki jacket!  Truly Med another day--I was an adventurer, someone who tried new things and LIKED them, and Sunflower was my first SF restaurant with a bit of grunge, a lot of taste.

And the roomies weren't too bad, either.
author: Ellie L.

description:
Minor update .... I've learned that there two different addresses for this place.  I went through the door on Valencia, and some have said it's a much different atmosphere.

My new favorite meal when I don't want meat .... and that's been for two whole days straight.  Now, I am not going vegetarian, but have decided to lighten up my meals a bit, and cut down on meat.  And I think I might have to make it one more day, as of this writing, it's Friday, and Lent, so we are not supposed to have meat on Friday, right?  Just one more day ... that's what I keep telling myself.  Steak tomorrow!

This is a place that you might think twice about stopping by.  16th and Valencia, is not, shall we say, a corner that you would think of when it comes to Vietnamese food.  You'd be thinking burritos, tacos, and pizza, right?  Well think twice, and head into the pastel colored neon signs of Sunflower.  Just do it.

I've been wanting Garlic Noodles since I started a thread a few days ago.  This place was suggested, so I got off BART a few stops early to get some.  There are many choices for meat eaters and vegetarians alike.  I ordered the Garlic Noodles, Imperial Rolls, (meat and vegetarian), and the Chicken Salad.  I got everything to go, and went on my way

The Garlic Noodles make me want to go back just for that.  They come with egg, and some "special ingredient", according to the menu.  I don't know what that "special ingredient" is, but it must be crack, as it's that addicting.  I could have eaten a whole order on my own.  The vegetarian Imperial rolls are some of the best I've had.  I could not even tell they were meatless.  (but I did dip in the fish sauce based dip .... did I cheat on the "no meat?")  At least I didn't have pork or chicken!  

I did try the salad, making sure to not get any chicken.  It was good, and comes with dressing, and the same fish sauce based dip the spring rolls come with.  I was looking for more peanuts in my salad.

I will go back for the Garlic Noodles, and the grill entrees again.  Even my roommate who must have meat with every meal thought everything was great, even the veggie Imperial rolls.
author: Michael M.

description: I have quickly become addicted to this Vietnamese restaurant. I love their lemon grass tofu wth spicy green beans and their veggie imperial rolls. The people who work there are also sweethearts. Admittedly, sometimes they get busy and take a little while to grab your credit card and the like, but they're always on top of it with good ordering recommendations, and are always fast to seat me. Also the prices are very reasonable for the quality of the food.  Whenever I'm in the area I can't help, but stop in.
author: Jessica T.

description:
Not a great experience, my friends. The food was all waaaay too sugary, and we ordered innocuous-sounding dishes like the sunflower prawns and spicy string beans.

Also, overpriced for cheap Vietnamese. Thirdly, the waiter was kind of a rude man. I'd go with Thanh Tran II next time, or perhaps just cook at home yourself.
author: Devin S.

description:
Seriously, this place RULES!

As a graduate student, this place is TOPS on my list of eats.  The servings are huge and absolutely delicious.  It is a drag, because I always get sucked into getting the same thing-  the BBQ pork with spring roll.  I like to go with a group, so I can mooch some of their items, and branch out.  I just adore the BBQ pork so much, I have a hard time going to Sunflower and breaking away from it.

The service is always fast and very friendly.  This is one of those spots that I try to bring out of towners to.  They always understand why Americans are so tubby after a visit.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
The barbeque-beef bun here is the best I've had, and I continue to search other restaurants for its peer.

The lemongrass beef is also extremely tasty.

I've found the chicken here to be dry and stringy at times.

Tu Lan has WAY better imperial rolls.

New Loi's on Taraval and 19th has much better pho.

Still, the beef dishes here are so good that it deserves 4 stars.
author: Matthew M.

description: One of my favorite Vietnamese restaurants in the city. Garlic noodles epic! Sizzling seafood platter awesome! Cabbage salad great! Imperial rolls fantastic! One thing you should not do if there are a lot of people in line waiting, is sit there and yap it up with your friends well after paying the bill. You will be asked to leave. Other than that this place is great for herbivores and omnivores alike.
author: Ethan S.

description:
WHAT NO ALCOHOL?!  

Well I'm assuming this was a glitch in the system....they had signs posted last night indicating that no beer or wine was to be served "for temporary."  Sooo we didn't get a buzz on at dinner, we were surprisingly well rested this morning! 

We intended to go to Tu Lan but the line was just to damn long.  We ended up at Sunflower in the Mission and were pleasantly surprised.  The wait staff is amazingly nice, we were really impressed with that.  They offered suggestions which we followed.  We got the spicy beef and prawns which was pretty delish, it comes with lettuce and rice paper to wrap up your own concoction.  We also got the BBQ Pork vermicelli bowl. The pork was amazing.  

I will admit that when everyone else's veggie heavy dishes wandered by we were a little envious, I wanted a big pile of veggies on my plate. So next time we've vowed to do only one meat dish and another veggie. 

All in all this was a great find after being depressed and sad at seeing the line at Tu Lan.  We will def be back, hopefully their liquor license will kick back in asap!
author: Claire C.

description:
I can say that this place isn't that bad. 

Shaking beef is 1/4 what you would pay for at Slanted Door and has just as much flavor. Go to the door on Valencia, the one on 16th will leave your hair and clothes smelling like kitchen grease.
author: Mark B.

description:
The place with the little counter is better, but I hate the one with the carpeted dark interior.

A. The owners of this one are not Vietnamese. They are CHINESE. And yes, it makes a difference. The pho is watery, it is not Pho. Go to Turtle Tower on Larkin instead.

B. They overcharge by secretly adding the tip to your bill, so you tip them twice if you're not aware.

C. The waiters are jerks. Totally racist towards actual Asian people that eat there. As they think caucasians will spend more money or something. So, the service is pushy, and one of them is super bitchy. I don't care how much water you pour me, if you are rude otherwise. 

D. And yes, the food is crap. The vegi spring rolls in my vermicelli were twice cooked so I couldn't even bite into it, so hard. And they do this because they're not fresh. The salad was yellow and brownish, again old. 

I WILL NEVER GO BACK HERE. THERE ARE PLENTY OTHER RAD CHEAP PLACES TO EAT. I don't need elegance, I'd rather eat at Yamo where I can see the food being made.
author: yuri s.

description:
I wanted something healthy for dinner and heard that sunflower had good Vietnamese food.  When we got there the only seats available were right next to the door.  It took a while for the waiters to come and give us the menus.   A couple of minutes later, a homeless woman come into the restaurant and started yelling at the table next to us.  The waiter immediately came over and told her to leave.  She eventually left but also left a horrible foul smell.  We were about the leave feeling sick from the smell and the table next to us looked horrified. We ended up staying after they aired out the area.

I ordered the pork bun vermicelli and it was quite tasty. I think a little overpriced for Vietnamese food, and i most likely won't return anytime soon.
author: Yummy E.

description:
If you're a big fan of Vietnamese food, don't take my review seriously, as I haven't had very much Vietnamese food.  I'm from Southern California, and everything down there is pho, which I don't eat because I don't eat meat.

When I tried Sunflower for the first time, I was blown away.  The ingredients were really fresh, and the service was good, if overly persistent.  It's been the same the two other times I've come.

Sunflower makes this part of the Mission that much better.
author: John S.

description:
I always get the veggie vermicelli (sometimes called veggie bun at other vietnamese restaurants).  It never fails to disappoint.  The portions are ridiculously huge.  I've had their curry dishes, also very very good.  I wasn't feeling the garlic noodles, it was good, but nothing memorable.
Every time I go, they have the same friendly happy waiter (is he the owner too?)
author: SF D.

description: Found this place on Yelp search:) Tasty Garlic Noodle was yummy, and Fried Rice my friend ordered looked good and was good. The server was very friendly and helpful of what to order. Want to try Soup Noodle next time!
author: Maitai N.

description:
I feel like I had a completely different experience from many of the reviewers. So for starters, the service was a bit rude and our waiter was creepy. I usually overlook these things, but then I specifically ordered my fried rice without egg. If I eat egg, I will get sick, plain and simple. Our waiter brings us our food and says "Here's your meal, no egg." It's a good thing I looked at me food before digging in because sure enough there's egg in it.

I think they must have been pissed that I sent it back, because I swear it came back tasting like they'd scraped it off the floor. My boyfriend and I both felt queasy all night. He ended up going home early because he was so ill. Ugh. Never again.
author: Sharon T.

description:
We went for dinner @ this place today. The service not good, the waiter recommended some really crappy soup and he did not even ask us if we wanted chicken and shrimp with our garlic noodles. But the garlic noodles by itself was great, not that good after adding the chicken.

Not bad, but not recommended for the service. But you should try the garlic noodles for sure.
author: Aussfchi R.

description: Love this place the food is really good found the restaurant on "Yelp" and it was as good as everyone said it was. I have never been disappointed in my choices, we always try to order something different each time we visit here.
author: Nancy L.

description:
Yea sunflower!!!
  I ate here last night and was really happy with my meal.  The main dishes are all around 6-8 except seafood stuff, and boy is it worth it...  We shared the lemongrass tofu, which was just the right amount of spice and was delicious.  Also shared grilled prawns with pan fried noodles - not the most flavorful but with siricha it was excellent.  Also a full house caraffe which was only $12.  An excellent meal with booze for under $30??  Amazing even in the cheap-eat central of the mission.
   We took our leftoevers but gave them to a bum on the street outside who said he was so excited to eat sunflower, his favorite place to get gifted leftovers....
author: amy b.

description: Decent location, great prices, big portions, best garlic noodles ever!
author: Irma R.

description: Cheap and tasty. Great local pho house.
author: Steven W.

description:
I love their garlic chicken noodles!!!

...sometimes my mind wanders away to find me craving a large plate of delicious Vietnamese food from Sunflower...then when I start drooling and realize that im nowhere near 16th and Mission I get sad =(

Oh yeah, the rest of their food is pretty awesome too...I just gave it one less star because every time I leave that place my hair and clothes smells like fried food. So a better ventilation system would def bump them up to 5 stars.
author: mariana m.

description: Friendly service, huge vermicelli bowls! They have 2 dinning rooms which can be confusing, we sat on the kitchen side and smelled like food for the remainder of the night. The veggie vermicelli bowl was awesome! Filled with fresh veggies, like cabbage, and tofu its very refreshing on the rarely-warm summer nights. I'd love to try the veggie pho next time.
author: Cori W.

description:
Sunflower's Fried Tofu Appetizer with Lemongrass is SO amazingly delicious! Somehow the paste of Lemongrass is in between two squares of Tofu, not sure if it's fried WITH the Lemongrass or not, but it sure tastes like it! 
Food is fresh, delicious, not greasy and affordable--what's not to love?
Also, if they're too full at location on Valencia, walk around the corner on 16th and pop in there!
author: Rebecca C.

description:
I ride BART every day, many of those days to the 16th and Mission station, putting me right next to Sunflower. There's nothing like a BBQ pork vermicelli bowl after a long day at work. Good spring rolls to start if I'm extra hungry. The cheery waiter with the sparkly stud belt has to be my favorite server. People, mostly in duos, trios or quads, are always having fun, intimate conversation.

Authentic or not, the food here is in the same style as every other Vietnamese place I've tried in the Bay Area, but slightly better. Bigger portions and much better service than you'd expect. Don't want cucumbers? You don't even need to specify: they'll ask if you want them removed next time, if they end up alone at the bottom of your bowl.
author: Tara R.

description:
When you're craving the Pho and spring rolls (which happens to me on a pretty regular basis during the cold winter months) and you don't want to travel far to scratch that itch, Sunflower works just fine (this is assuming that you live in the Mission or nearby, which is right, right?). 

I agree with many reviewers who say that the broth is a little bland. But isn't that what the hot peppers and sriracha by the truckload is for? Easily fixed. The cold shrimp spring rolls? Oh man. Do I like them for them or for the peanutty goodness that comes on the side? Good question. 

It's a cheap Vietnamese restaurant in the heart of the Mission. What do you expect? I give it 3 stars for the location alone. And the full bottle of sriracha on the table. Seriously. I use that stuff on everything.
author: Rachel F.

description:
Even though there is a Vietnamese restaurant across the street from San Francisco General, we decided to celebrate the end of 2008 by venturing further afield for our year's last lunch. One of our coworkers had eaten at Sunflower in the past and highly recommended it. After a few forays around the block, we managed to find parking just across the street. Feeling amazingly lucky, we celebrated with an order of Nep Chien, Vietnamese pot stickers of deep fried sticky brown rice with minced pork, shrimp, carrot and mushroom. Yummy. We also tried an order of vegetarian crepes which were also very delicious.  In fact, when a waitress removed the plate with one still remaining, we let out a yell that could be heard on Valencia.  She immediately came running back
with the tasty morsel, full of apology.

For our main course, three of us ordered the same special lunch for $7.95. We were amazed at the huge plates that arrived. Each held a bowl of a savory soup, rice, an Imperial roll, barbecue pork and a thinly 
sliced cabbage salad. Our Vietnamese restaurant, across from SFGH, 
has definitely been surpassed! 

Another colleague ordered the seafood soup, a huge bowl chock full of assorted seafood and noodles which she declared "very flavorful" and our other colleague had a vermicelli dish. It was definitely worth the drive for this terrific meal at such a low price!!!
author: Carmen H.

description:
Pho is one of the best ways, in my opinion, to enjoy noodles.  The tragedy is that it is quite rare to find pho made with a vegetarian broth.  Hence, I was eager to try Sunflower.  
The are two sections of this restaurant, a fancy one on Valencia and a smaller, cramped section on 16th near the Roxie theater.  We chose the smaller part of the restaurant due to the shorter wait...and the fact that sometimes the crowded, cramped, environment is conducive to eating hot, spicy, Asian food.

The food:
The veggie pho was delicious and full of fresh veggies and tofu.  The garlic string beans were awesome, crisp and hot, and the mixed veggies and garlic dish was okay...it seemed like the ingredients from the pho minus the noodles and broth.  The portions were large.  Our meat-eating friends seemed satisfied with their beef pho as well.

Service: pretty good.  The waiter was attentive and quick despite the fact that he was the only server working our side of the restaurant.

Price: great.  Everything veggie was between $5.50 and $9.00 approximately.  The meat items were about the same, maybe a tiny bit higher.

Hours: open late!

Caveat: I was not a vegetarian when I had my first several bowls of pho, thus I know what I am missing by ordering the veggie version.  However, if you cannot bring yourself to ingest animal flesh or just want to sample the veggie food, Sunflower is a good choice.
author: Valerie L.

description: Great food! Great service! Real traditional Vietnames cuisin. I came here for my Launch special #1 five spice chicken. It was the best dish ever. I got five spice chicken (half chicken breast) with 1roll, salad on the side, a small bowl of sour soup. It's very healthy and delicious. I really love it. So I give this place 5*
author: Thyra K.

description:
Delicious Vietnamese food and value.  

It's great for eating in and impressively well packaged for take home.  Take the Pho, for example, which is a very hands on eating experience.  When you order Pho to go, Sunflower packages the noodles and meat, broth, and string beans/chili/basil separately so you can assemble at home and enjoy an equally delcious pho experience.  Equal care is put into other to go packaging, ensuring you will get a whole variety of sauces to dip your things into.  You don't get Sriracha in your bag, so have a bottle at home.

Oh, and I find the Pho yummy.

I also enjoy the shaking beef, papaya salad, spring rolls, chicken salad, vermicelli options, and the pricier Vietnamese Lemon Grass Chicken.

In the words of one particular waiter there, "very nice."
author: Trent B.

description: I came here again after many years and now, I love this place.  Had lunch here yesterday with a friend and we both had the vegetarian salad ( delicious and healthy!!!) and shared the spring rolls ( also delicious and healthy!!! ).  The prices are so low for how much food you get.  The place is nothing special but the food is delicious and I thoroughly enjoyed my lunch here.  I will be back, hopefully soon and hopefully with my lovely friend Susie D. to eat more of the delicious vegetarian salad!
author: Nilu r.

description: My GF and I have gone here before and the service was nothing spectacular and the food was on par for this particular corner (Valencia and 16th).  Why I'm compelled to write a review is that the service was absolutely deplorable.  Like Marieta C. the waiters were extremely rude and demanded payment before we were even done with our meal.  Insult to injury, the waiter interrupted us while we were still eating to demand a tip.  DEMAND!!  I'm sorry but as a fellow server, you earn a tip!  Never eating here again!!!
author: Shane M.

description: Had the garlic noodles with chicken and veggies. It was delish! Quick service, cheap eats and awesome Vietnamese coffee, whats not to like?
author: Amy S.

description:
Sunflower is one of my favorite spots to grab  "authentic" Vietnamese food in the city. Located in the middle of hipster town- VALENCIA - I guess Sunflower's use of the word authentic invites patrons to see how good Vietnamese food is not always found in the tenderloin or inside a San Jose strip mall. And if that is their strategy, then it works!

I love Sunflower! What do I usually get? For starters, their fresh spring rolls with shrimp. AWESOME. The peanut sauce is off the hook. Yum! Next thing on the menu, the Vermicelli bowl with imperial rolls and BBQ pork. AWESOME. If you're still hungry, GARLIC NOODLES. Even more tasty. And if you still aren't full, top it off with the fried ice cream. Damn, you are set! 

The only thing that doesn't make Sunflower authentic is...that their place is actually clean! I am not afraid to drink the tap water! I don't have to reclean my utensils with the tea! And that's why I love Sunflower! =)

Recommendations: 
Beef Pho 
Vermicelli bowl with BBQ pork & Imperial Rolls 
Fresh Spring Rolls w/ Shrimp
Garlic Noodles 
Fried Ice Cream
author: Lisa T.

description:
Oh, hello, Vietnamese Pot Stickers.  These golden brown deep fried balls are so delicious.  Seriously, they are so good, and I haven't seen them served anywhere else quite like this.  Yum.  

Plus, you really can't beat the price.  I usually get the Shaking Beef, but I got the Clay Pot special last night, and that was great too.  Unlike other places that might skimp on the special sausages, this clay pot was chock full with chicken, shrimp and sausage.  So good.  

But, to recap, you've really got to try those deep fried balls.
author: Julie B.

description:
I was very impressed by Sunflower.  

I tried the veggie spring rolls and was so excited.  The sauce they came with was great but we also had the peanut sauce which made it even better!  They were fresh and delicious.

For my main course, I ordered the lemongrass chicken.  The green beans on the side were perfectly cooked al dente and the chicken was really good.

If you're in the Mission, definitely try Sunflower.
author: Lauren C.

description:
Lots of pluses, very few minuses:

* Tasty tasty food
* Big portions
* Reasonable prices
* They're willing to make things differently if you need
* Open until 10:30
* Two locations so if one's busy, you can find a spot in the other (or if you feel like "fine dining" or "greasy spoon" you can pick either)

Minuses? They're so busy sometimes you have to wait to get a table. *fake dramatic sigh*

I stayed away from Sunflower after being diagnosed with a gluten allergy and realize now I shouldn't have. There are some dishes probably made with wheat, but they don't use soy sauce in -anything-, and that's huge. I am definitely becoming a regular again. Yum Yum.
author: Beth W.

description:
What is it with me & Vietnamese restaurants lately? 

Went here with a group of 6 and were very graciously accomodated. Loved the crepe, the beef salad & spring rolls. the shaking beef was just ok compared to others I've had. 

A very casual, hole-in-the-wall atmosphere. Good for groups & kids too. Not necessarily a destination restaurant, but good if you're in the hood.
author: N B.

description: This restaurant is so delicious I want to cry. The prices are excellent...cheap for a whole lot of food. One of the first places I ate when I moved here, and fell in love!
author: Jasmine B.

description:
What's not to like  here; a huge bowl of Pho noodles, or a plate with BBQ pork skewers over rice noodles with imperial rolls and spicy/ tangy/ sweet fish sauce to dip them in.  

Or is it the cold shrimp rolls with fresh basil or is it mint  leaves with dollops of yummy peanut sauce atop a bed of romaine lettuce.   Five spiced chicken over rice anyone? Don't know what 5 spices are used but you're gonna crave it more than you think.  Claypot catfish...wasn't all too keen on the name but it sure went down well.  I can go on and on, they are lucky it's not an all you can eat joint because they'd have to arrest me and drag me out kicking and screaming.  

I've heard food-snobs ask if they use MSG...I'll answer yes, and I don't care get the f**ck out of here ...crowd up some other place...folks are hungry here!

Nothing more uplifting than a caffeine jolt with a cafe su da (sweet slow dripped iced coffee) not the best thing to have for a late dinner, but so what... I'll drink to that!

There's this flowery lil' cubby waiter there who could be a little short with you if you rub Buddha the wrong way, but he means well, things get stressful when the dinner rush arrives.

10 dollar dinner budget? You can do it here!
author: B H.

description:
I crave the food from here. I don't really get to go too often cause for some strange reason Hubbie don't care for it even though they have vegetables & make me happy. 

The vermicelli bowls are an incredible amount of food for such a relatively small price [like 7 bucks--I know!] They're really good about not bringing me fish sauce when I tell them I'm allergic. 

The lunch specials are a killer amount of food for cheap too! 

In a a campy way I also love the two locations. It makes me feel like I've gone to two different places even though its really just one. 

& My most favorite part? The flamboyant waiter with his Versace belt. One of my old bosses said he touched him in a way he didn't like once. 

He's worth the price of admission alone.
author: Rebekah K.

description:
It is good in a pinch for affordable, decent Vietnamese food.  The service is often barely acceptable.  
I do enjoy the garlic, lemongrass and green-bean dishes are all great.
author: Barb S.

description:
Eaten here twice...gotten sick both times.

I enjoy eating Vietnamese food, and this place was highly recommended. The food tasted great, but the post-dinner experience was not as pleasant. Believing that the problem was something else I ate earlier, I decided to return to this restaurant a second time. I had a second unpleasant post-dinner experience. I'll admit the food is good...bet it's even better if you don't get sick afterwards. I'll attempt a third time if I am feeling brave. Hope you have better luck.
author: Mike L.

description:
The food here is good, but unfortunately there have been insects in the food on two separate occasions. yuck. I gave them the second chance because accidents do happen, but two is enough for me.

5/07: Update: My roomate just got food poisoning from this place!  Like I said, the food usually tastes fine but you take your chances when you eat here. I stopped risking it a long time ago.
author: Veena S.

description:
Damn,

I was wandering around trying to find  a spot to eat, and I passed by a KFC. But then I thought "Nawww..... " and kept walking until I stumbled upon this place. Should've chose KFC. 

I only had the pho. The broth was good, the rare steak was good, the pho noodles were good. The bad part was the the beef brisket, which was super hard and chewy. Had the consistency of rubber. 

I chewed it for about 2 minutes until my jaw started getting sore, and when it still didn't break apart enough, I spit it out. My dumbass thinks that it was just an anomaly, this one bad piece. So I picked another piece of beef brisket and tried again. Nope. Still hard and chewy. And I tried again with yet another piece. And again. By the end of the meal, I had 5 clumps of nasty partially chewed globs of meat on my table. Gross, I know. 

Plus, this "large" bowl is about the same size as a "medium" at most other restaurants. And it also cost 2 bucks more than most other pho joints. The INSOLENCE.
author: Jay W.

description:
I love this place.

My sweet angel and i come here relatively often because it is always quick and convenient. The hilarious waiter who always wears the studded belt always recognizes us.

They have really good imperial rolls, and they don't skimp. They give you a lot of them. Not like that damned Lotus Garden (see review). Also, they have really good Pho here! So I can get either one, depending on my mood. I wasn't so in love with their rendition of the fresh shrimp spring rolls (too much rice noodle in the middle and not enough shrimp!) but I am content with the other selections.

Always our go-to place for an inexpensive meal!
author: Audrey K.

description:
Sunflower is delicious. If you're looking for a good Pho place, this may not be where you want to go, but many of their other menu items are amazing.

Most recently I had shrimp spring rolls, shaken beef, and spicy lemongrass chicken along with some brown rice... SOOO good! The shaken beef was very tender and had a good flavor (it smelled so good that the table next to us had to order it as well). The spicy lemongrass chicken wasn't really spicy at all, but it had a really good lemongrass flavor, and the green beans in it were crisp and delicious. The brown rice was great - it was actually sticky purple rice, not what I expected, but it was fantastic. A very rich nutty flavor to it, a little sweet too - I had never had this before, but will definitely have it again! Ah and let's not forget the spring rolls, granted I feel like it's hard to get these wrong, but they were right on par with everything else.

The inside is OK - nothing too spectacular, a little crowded, but it's worth it for the food. The service was pretty decent, nothing to write home about, but certainly not bad by any means - very friendly, and the food came out very fast (despite a full house).

Check this place out! Again, if you're looking for Pho I would probably go somewhere where it's more their specialty (although I haven't tried it here, it could be good). If you're just looking for tasty and inexpensive Vietnamese cuisine, Sunflower is great!
author: Ben Y.

description:
My girl Chelsea introduced me to this lovely little place. And I do mean little. They are usually packed tight for dinner, especially on weekends. There's not much room to wait and they don't usually make a wait list, so it's all up to you to make sure you keep your spot. Once you get in, the prices are great ($8-12 per entree) and the service is friendly and fast. At lunch time, you can get a giant lunch special for $8 that comes with soup, salad, rice, an imperial roll, and your entree. Mmmm.
Not a fancy place by any means. Cozy low lighting and great food--I haven't had anything here that isn't delicious. Lemon grass chicken, spring rolls, hot pot, imperial rolls, vermicelli bowls=yum. Sometimes I crave this place. They get 3 Noms in my book.
A block away from 16th/mission BART.
author: Brandy E.

description:
The Tofu Curry is the best ever, the veggie pho is bland and boring- don't bother!  Fried tofu stuffed with lemongrass is strong & flavorful. Oh and the veggie vermicelli huge but flavorless. The garlic noodles (add tofu & veggies) is amazing but not gluten free.


But OK real talk. A series of stressful and personal events, on different occasions have happened here for me and I now associate this restaurant with stress. Nothing personal Sunflower, I have conditioned myself to dislike you.
author: Shannon Z.

description:
I was very impressed with Sunflower.  

I found their web site and pasted the URL below.  The prices have changed, but you'll be able to get a general idea about the kind of food they serve.

http://www.sunflower-restaurant.com/

I went to the one on Valencia Street and it totally gave me hope that food at reasonable prices can still be had in the city. 

(We've been priced out of so many of our favorite restaurants recently that I was getting depressed!) 

I ordered #4 Beef Noodle Soup $5.75 and it came with lots of thin slices of beef.  They weren't kidding when they said "tender."  I didn't have to fight with the food, and I didn't have to run home and floss like mad.  The noodles were snappy still (not soggy or clumpy or slimy) and the broth was satisfying (not too salty, and almost buttery-tasting)... I actually drank some broth, it was so good.  Usually, I leave the broth behind because I think boullion or Swanson's or MSG city.

The price is very cheap for such good food.  

I was very full after my bowl of Pho, but I did eye longingly at the imperial and spring rolls on the plates of other diners.  The imperial rolls were large, not taquito-sized like I've been seeing recently. Since taquito is the diminutive of taco, we should have a diminutive of the imperial roll, something humble.

Also, I saw a lot of people ordered rice plates -- the woman I was sitting next to had the #7 Vegetarian soup, vegetarian imperial roll, salad and spicy green beans.  The lunch menu says that it's $7.95.  

I'm going back there as soon as I can.  Now that I have work, the next available time slot would be Saturday!  I'll probably have their lunch plate with the BBQ pork.

***********************************************************************
The first available chance I got, I went there and ordered the special lunch plate with the BBQ pork, and my husband ordered the curry chicken over rice.  It was marvelous!
author: Priscilla L.

description:
Every time my sister brought me out here, we'd always get garlic noodles. They are so addicting! I don't remember much of the other dishes we ordered since the garlic noodles was the one dish that stood out the most for me. They're even better as leftovers. Their thai iced tea was decent, too.

The only thing I didn't like was how crowded it got. It was really interesting when they tried to fit our party of 8. I'd never felt so claustrophobic.
author: Mylene A.

description: I thought the food here was great, as were the prices. I had noodles and found them heavenly. Our server was cordial and crazy in the way that you want a waiter to be.
author: Andrew K.

description: Not only the best Pho in the city, but also great food in general.  The Bun or vermicelli bowls and imperial rolls are delish!!
author: sam m.

description:
SQUISH SQUISH IS THE SOUND of the mediocre, soggy food they serve here. Even the crispy noodles were completely waterlogged.  (It's true though, also strangely garlicky.)

I have a feeling it's also the sound of one's soul after doling out sad Vietnamese-style food to clueless Mission types for so many years.
author: Daniel S.

description: Food is super great! One of the best Vietnamese(?) restaurant in the city! Unfortunately the service sucks! The waiters are so rude. Yes! Waiters with "s." Every time I come here I get dreadful service! Takes forever to seat us, when they do, takes forever to get your order, and gives you an attitude like eat up and go! They should fire all their waiters and start a new cause if not for their garlic noodles with prawns, I would have been dining somewhere else.
author: Chris S.

description:
I get this location and the one on 16th mixed up, so pardon me if I am reviewing the wrong one but both serve the same food and have very similiar cozy, hole in the wall setup.

The first time I visited I had an extremely satisfying experience, my dish, the Vermincelli with Chicken and Imperial rolls was a-delice!  The price was just right at around $6 per head.  I also ordered a cococut drink and it was a fresh coconut that was handed to me.  Yum!

Second time, not so good (the one on Valencia), I ordered the lemon grass chicken and rice dish.  DON'T get that one.  The chicken was tough, dry and cut in big chunks that I could barely take down.  The brown rice was tough too.  Maybe I'm just getting old and need my tender cooking but sigh.. I expected better.  

I think I'll stick to ordering noodles, vermincelli and pho with my Vietnamese cuisine and save the rice dishes for the Chinese.
author: Jackie G.

description:
"Ah! sunflower, weary of time, who countest the steps of the sun, seeking after that sweet golden clime where the traveller's journey is done." - William Blake, Ah! Sunflower (excerpt)

(see the end for an excerpt from Allen Ginsberg's wonderful Sunflower Sutra, pretty much a must if you've ever lived in SF)

We were out with my gf's agent friend and the writer he was on a book tour for - Steve Toltz, if you're wondering, and we can't wait to get started on A Fraction of the Whole (shameless plug) his writer client and some of their friends, and we found ourself in the Mission - Jen I. was with us and she recommended Sunflower.  Outstanding recommendation indeed!  

It just doesn't get any better for vegetarian under $10 if you're in the Mission - except maybe a great big burrito, but gone are the days where I went for a 50-mile bike ride and came back for a huge Mission burrito.  I had the #58 coconut curry sauteed vegetables, and I pretty much had the whole garden in there, with tofu - broccoli, yellow squash, onions, red pepper, all in an excellent curry sauce, and good and spicy.  Wash it all down with a vietnamese iced coffee and that's one mighty pleasing meal.  According to signs on the wall, "beer and wine are gone for temporary" :-D but that just gave me an excuse to have a delicious coffee.

The servers are friendly and accommodating, and service was pretty fast.


"Poor dead flower? when did you forget you were a
flower? when did you look at your skin and
decide you were an impotent dirty old locomotive?
the ghost of a locomotive? the specter and
shade of a once powerful mad American locomotive?

You were never no locomotive, Sunflower, you were a
sunflower!

And you Locomotive, you are a locomotive, forget me
not!

So I grabbed up the skeleton thick sunflower and stuck
it at my side like a scepter,
and deliver my sermon to my soul, and Jack's soul
too, and anyone who'll listen,

--We're not our skin of grime, we're not our dread
bleak dusty imageless locomotive, we're all
beautiful golden sunflowers inside, we're blessed
by our own seed & golden hairy naked
accomplishment-bodies growing into mad black
formal sunflowers in the sunset, spied on by our
eyes under the shadow of the mad locomotive
riverbank sunset Frisco hilly tincan evening
sitdown vision." - Allen Ginsberg, Sunflower Sutra
author: Joe B.

description:
It was decent.

I mean, it was tasty...for the most part, but that's about it.

It was crowded. Really crowded. And they seated us in a shit spot, even though there were a few others (please tell me why you gave us the dirty table people JUST left when there were READY tables in more-desirable locations than right by the door?).

The service was horrible. Seriously, really bad.

They didn't have wine or beer, even though the menu said they did.

It got super-crowded by the door and we couldn't even hear ourselves talk while people waited for tables. We had to walk UP to the server to get attention and pay our check.

We were going to take our leftovers home. He took away our plate and piled stuff ON TOP of the food before we could even utter that we wanted a box.

Save yourself the trouble and just forget it. This place sucks. The food wasn't good enough to warrant how shitty everything else is. I can't fathom why there were even people here.

Places like this remind me of why I prefer to cook at home.
author: Danyell K.

description:
You know, I used to really like this place.

Something just happened that made me feel a bit embarrassed and angry at the same time.

You see. I had to get up to ask for a check.  It was getting busy.  So I wanted to do these folks a favor and leave as soon as I finished my pho.     

I gave the moody waiter 25 dollars for a 22 and change meal with my siblings.  I paid, and he became irate that I didn't give him a 15% tip.   He became furious and bickered about not getting enough.  I threw him a few more dollars and went out.


You know,  I worked as a waiter (bus boy, dish washer, etc) for 10 years and never did I demand a tip even though I think I deserved it.  Had he pulled chairs, asked about my meal, asked me if there is anything else we wanted, got my check promptly when waived down, then I would deilghtfully give him a 35% tip.  

But, sorry, this is TOTAL BS!!!
author: John L.

description: Absolutely love it here!  Everything is delicious, from the spicy green beans in lemon grass tofu, to the amazing huge soup bowls.  There are two entrances (one on Mission and one on 16th).  My friend and I like the funky aspect of the 16th Street side.  We go after dancing our you-know-what's off in a class at ODC.  It's the perfect fulfilling lunch after a tough workout, on the healthy side.
author: Mikey S.

description:
Sunflower makes the most delicious vegetarian pho that is filled with lots of fresh vegetables. I also love the Sunflower Prawns on garlic noodles with crunchy broccoli. I've never tasted prawns like theirs, but you have to love garlic.
The only down side of the main restaurant is the lousy service they give to customers eating alone. I've introduced friends to Sunflower and used to come there often, but I was turned off by the very different service when I came in alone. I had to wait way too long for food and the check. Still, the food is great.
author: Susan G.

description: Great value for the money. Huge portions, comes out quickly and never too long of a wait.
author: Emily L.

description:
Do i like vietnamise food.... the answer would usually be no. This place is different. 
First off my freinds like to come here. So I tag along. It gets crowded and the tables are right next to each other. The service is decent, which is nice. Though occasionally you do have to flag down your waiter for water/soda/check etc. 
The best part about this place is the cost and the quality. The food is relatively cheap. Especially by san francisco standards. Also, everything seems to be fairly fresh. 
I recommend the sunflower prawns for sure!!
author: Wes P.

description:
I like the ambiance and service - very friendly and buzzy.  However, I was a bit disappointed with the food - we ordered the spring rolls,  Pho chicken noodles, beef noodle dish, and the shaken beef dish.

The spring rolls were the best - hot and flavorful.  The pho was a bit bland ...I usually love Pho, but ended up skipping this dish and let the others at our table eat it.  The beef noodle dish was good but a bit greasy...same for the shaken beef - funny taste and a bit too greasy for my taste.

This was my 2nd time coming here and I thought it was good for a quick bite, nothing fancy and average tasting food.
author: Gina C.

description:
my bank statement for the last 6 months:

ATM Withdrawal: $20.00
Sunflower Restaurant: $7.05
Amazon.com: $12.96
Transfer to ING Direct: $75.00
Sunflower Restaurant: $7.05
Sunflower Restaurant: $7.05
OVERDRAFT FEE: $28.00
Transfer from ING Direct to Wells Fargo: $75.00
Sunflower Restaurant: $7.05
Bi-Rite: $19.36
Sunflower Restaurant: $7.05

i love the bbq beef vermicelli w/ imperial rolls, in fact, it's the only thing i order. they're fast, friendly and close - can't ask for more...except for one of those "Buy 9 meals get your 10th meal FREE" cards.
author: Brittany E.

description:
I had the lunch plate with vegetarian soup, tofu and a roll. The food wasn't bad but it wasn't amazing either.

The fried tofu with garlic and ginger was probably the best of the plate. The tofu was well done and the green beans were crunchy. The downside was that the garlic and ginger was obviously from a can and it showed in the flavor.

The soup was overwhelmingly sweet and had a very distinct tomato taste, event though the broth was clear. Not for me, but others might enjoy it.

The vegetarian spring roll was bland and uninspiring.

The upside is that the service was fast and courteous and you get a ginourmous amount of food for ~$8, so if you are starving and just want to stuff yourself this is a place to go. Just don't expect amazing flavor.
author: Martin H.

description:
The Mission has become way to pricey for my poor little tummy and am always on a hunt for cheap eats. Sunflower is definitely a go-to-place for a quick and cheap meal that serves BIG portions. This ain't no fine dining establishment or a place known for their customer service, but if your in the mood for a good hearty meal and are on a budget, this will keep both you and your wallet pretty damn happy. 
P.S. I recommend going during lunchtime and ordering their specials, as they jack up their prices during dinner time hours. Oh yeah, Sunflower is vegetarian friendly.
author: Kitty K.

description:
Big bowl of yummy Pho for $5.95 - sweet!

Seems to be a good go-to place for no-frills Vietnamese fare in the Mission.

I omitted one star because the interior of the restaurant could use a little TLC.
author: Julianne H.
