description: Beef pho.... a bit pricy and no options when it comes to cuts of meet but excellent flavor. They offer a full menu but I only go here for the pho. Would have given it 5 stars but without options and a price on the higher side I had to stick with 4. I will go back.
author: Shanna T.

description:
This is one of the greatest things about this city...great food for a great price!

So I'm doing some freelance work at Comcast on 16th and Folsom and some people invite me to go with them for lunch. We get a seat immediately for 5, drinks are in front of us within 2 minutes and an order of spring rolls gets to us in about 5. Cool. I order the lemon grass beef with brown rice and when the orders come out I'm blown away by the size of the dish! It came with its own spring roll, soup and cabbage-style salad as well. The meal was huge and I had more than enough to warrant a "to-go" bag for later. I think the lunch special was $7.95 and enough for two meals...that's my idea of a good deal.

I will most certainly be returning here for lunch soon!
author: Gabriel R.

description: We love going here. The fresh spring rolls are wonderful.
author: Benjamin T.

description: My friend was hungry for some Pho, but unfortunately I was still full from drinking beers earlier.  So I ordered spring rolls for a quick snack.  Since eating at Turtle Tower, Ive been hooked on the northern style Pho.  When the time is right, I'll step back into the southern style arena again!  So I'll leave it at 3 stars for the spring roll, and will update based on my next visit for Pho.
author: Shad B.

description:
*stands up*
Hi. My name is Jessica. And I am an addict.
My vice? Garlic noodles.
My other vice? Shaken beef.

I sit down there and I know my intestines are going to get a good rub down--and no, not in that special way.

The iced coffee is to die for and the staff has always been fast and friendly.

The prices are so reasonable, I'm ashamed that I haven't been there more in the past few months. Every dish I've sampled I've enjoyed. I've even braved the rain, the wind and drunken stumbles from Zeitgeist for this joint. 

And that's sayin something.
author: Jessica P.

description:
I've never been to Vietnam, and I've broken up and gotten back together with Sunflower a few times over the years. But we're back on, have been for about a year, and this time, I think it's for good.

Everything I've tried at Sunflower has been good, from vermicelli rolls, to fresh spring rolls, to lettuce-wrapped pork (forget the name of that dish), to pho.

It's cheap, and service comes with a smile. They're actually quite good at getting you seated, so despite a tiny dining area and what seems like a lot of people in front of you, wait it out.
author: Jeff H.

description:
Disclaimer: I have not eaten at too many Vietnamese restaurants in the city. P.P.Q. and Cordon Bleu are among the few.

But... I really like Sunflower. I am not the authority on Vietnemese food since I am pescatarian but I do know that the best Vietnamese I've ever eaten was in Little Saigon (in S.J.)

Sunflower is delicious and very vegetarian friendly. My friend and I went there several weeks ago and got the lunch special which consisted of a pineapple-flavored soup, an imperial roll and an entree. Mine was lemongrass shrimp and rice. The portions were huge and the price was not too steep ($7.50) for the amount of food we got.

I've been craving Sunflower ever since. I think I might just go there tonight!
author: L. L.

description:
I'm all for hole in the wall dining, sticky menus, and questionable service. But honestly? Sunflower's not that worth it. It feels just a bit too dirty, and not in that decrepit-yet-you-know-it's-gonna-be-amazing way.

The 16th St. location, however, does serve alcohol ($3.25 for an Anchor Steam), and has a boombox still in its original cardboard box that's somehow plugged into the wall. 

While the chicken salad and Vietnamese crepe were alright, the lemongrass chicken was surprisingly good...  but not good enough to make up for the hipsters giving us the evil eye through the window to try to make us finish dinner quicker.
author: Carla C.

description:
Always busy, but always good, possibly great. I tend to order the same thing most of the time and it's always the same: delicious! 

Chicken noodle soup with vegetables is like home cooked: veggies are crispy and chicken is soft, and its all fresh! 

And that kinda applies to everything I and my friends have tried!
author: Rusty B.

description:
I only had a quick lunch here during work week: pork chop vermicelli with spring rolls. It was decent. It was above your average cheap lunch, I thought it was tasty, had good amount of fresh herbs and bean sprout ingredients. Vermicelli noodles were warm and contrasted the cool herbs/sprouts, which is what it's supposed to be - tasting vietnamese food should be a balance of cool/hot, sweet/sour in your mouth...The chili fish sauce, nouc mam is supposed to be hotter and more authentic. I find this happening at every vietnamese restaurant these days. But I realize it may be too smelly for some patrons.

Overall had nice lunch and great on the wallet.
author: Lola L.

description:
Pretty good!

There was a line at the fancier part on Valencia, so we ate at the little cafe part on 16th.  I've read that some people think it looks really run-down & sketchy -- I disagree.  I think it's about par for the course in terms of little locally-run mission eateries.  I mean, not fancy or anything; it's florescent lighting, plastic discount diner furniture and a radio playing out of the box it came in (seriously), but it certainly didn't look as if they were breaking any health codes.

For an appetizer, we had the spring rolls, which were ENORMOUS (ie, you could make a meal out of them if you weren't absolutely starving) and pretty tasty, though they were a bit heavy on the noodles and light on the shrimp.  For my entree, I had the combination noodles, which had chicken, shrimp, celery, cabage, bok choi, carrots, broccoli, squash, bean sprouts, and a TON of onions.  It was very tasty!  Admittedly not the bed I've ever had, but not bad at all for $7.  And there was a royal fuck ton of it.  I think I took home half the dish as leftovers.  My boyfriend had the beef pho, which was, much like my dish, quite tasty, though not the best we'd ever had.  

Reasonably tasty?  Check.  Reasonably priced?  Check.  Enormous portions, making it that much more of a good value?  Check.  But 'Authentic' is, perhaps, going a bit far.  It doesn't really both me, but people who are actually looking for 'Authentic' Vietnamese cuisine should be warned that this isn't what this is.  It's a tasty, reasonably priced noodle bar -- no more, no less. :)
author: Angela B.

description: The food here was decent. I go here sometimes after yoga with my friends to get Fa, which is always some of the best I've had. The service is pretty good and I like the atmosphere fine. I'll be back!
author: Kelsey B.

description:
Great Vietnamese, Low Cost, Friendly service.

I have been a frequent eater here for years.  I feel I should do them a solid by writing a good review.  Their food is solid, nothing too fancy, or too crazy, but their prices are amazing and their food is always fresh.  Take-Away is quick and amazingly good, so add this place to your list of places to stop by on your way home.  I recommend the chicken or pork bûn. (Vermicelli bowl)

Now on the other hand, If you want true, really good Vietnamese, go to Oakland.  No contest here.
author: Chris P.

description:
I've still never tried Pho. What I did order was good, cold noodles and an imperial roll. The portions are huge and very cheap. My friend ordered the 5 spice chicken and I liked it better than my dish. The place is really tiny and colorful. It's got charm and I loved walking around and checking out all the cool shops near Valencia. I would go back and this time order the Pho. Maybe when it starts to get cold outside. 

Hearty portions of comfort type food and very low prices......definitely not gourmet in taste but not half bad either.
author: Nina C.

description: I was a little bit weary when my friend wanted to go here because I've always had a bad experience with Vietnamese food.  I'm glad she talked me into going here because it was actually pretty tasty.  Two of my friends are on strict diets and they still managed to find something to eat.  That's quite a feat.  The prices are good and there are plenty of great places to go to afterwards.  Yum Yum Yum.
author: Amy J.

description:
I love you vietnamese hot and sour soup. You make my sniffles all better. You make me smile. You make me happy and warm.

Love the veggie steamed spring rolls, too. and the chicken salad. 

oh! and not only is this the same owners/same restaurant as the other sunflower, it's the same kitchen. But this one is roomier.
author: Margie L.

description:
This place is my go to restaurant whenever I am craving garlic noodles or after I get my taxes done, which is just down the street.  Everyone I have recommended this place to loves it.....even my mom, who doesn't like anything except her own cooking.  

Although the service can be a little slow on the weekends, I am ok with it because the garlic noodles are worth the wait.  On the flip side, even after not coming back for over a year, the server asked me if I wanted the usual, which I thought to be very impressive since I hadn't seen him in so long.  If ever I am in a rush, I can always go to the 16th Street side which tends to be a little faster and where you can pick up the "to go" orders.
author: Will F.

description:
Got takeout late last night.  

Fresh spring rolls with shrimp - they were damn HUGE.  I couldn't even finish half of one.

Vietnamese crepe - I was told it was good.  FULL of bean sprouts, which I don't particularly care for.

Pork and imperial roll bun - the meat was very very good, as were the imperial rolls.  However, the vermicelli was a bit underdone - not sure if it was due to the late hour.  Maybe they wanted to cook it fast and get me out the door.

Overall an okay experience - huge portions (two people could not finish two appetizers + bun), great seasoning.  I plan to go back earlier in the day to verify the noodle texture.

-------------------------------------------------------
Update 7/9/2007

Went back tonight, earlier in the evening, noodles were definitely better.  The calamari salad was good, and the chicken bun was great (as the pork one had been before).  Once again, we couldn't finish all our food.  

Even though the noodles were better this time around, I'm not changing my star rating because there was lipstick on my glass, which I didn't realize until after I had taken a sip.  Ew.
author: Kerrie L.

description:
Just delicious, period. The curry vegetables are the best curried anything I've ever had, and I get withdrawal symptoms lately if I don't have the Imperial Rolls over vermicelli at least once a week.

Some folks seem inclined to complain about the service but in all honesty the only time I've ever seen the servers actively be rude to someone is when the customer was rude first. Most of the complainers probably have similar track records with other establishments that don't kiss their ass or take abuse with a smile, too. This place [thankfully] doesn't charge enough money to take sh*t from morons, so let the buyer beware...
author: Ronzlo L.

description:
I have been to this place many times.  I think this place is better than overrated slanted door.  My favorite dishes are:

shrimp spring rolls
shrimp and pork salad
Vietnamese crepe
sea bass

I have tried their pho once.  It would not be their signature dish in my opinion.  Service is good when they are not busy.  But when the place is packed, they seem to get short handed.
  
Dinner for two would be around $30.  Can't beat that!
author: June K.

description:
I have come for lunch on numerous occasions and have not ever been let down. Here are the items I recommend to have a worthwhile experience:

Appetizer: Cold shrimp spring rolls (these are not fried people!)
served with a peanut dipping sauce. These rolls are stuffed with soft noodles, poached shrimp, lettuce, mint and are excellent.

Entree: Grilled Chicken over rice noodle
Grilled, excellently seasoned chicken...think of a type of five spice, star anise and garlic, served with lettuce, steamed rice noodles. They give you a small bowl of a sauce made of light fish sauce, water, carrots, sugar which you can pour on top (its really good, trust me). Or you can do what I do and mix the sriracha (hot sauce) and Hoisin sauce (sweet sauce) and then dip the noodles there.

The good thing is...the fast service, friendly waiters, huge portions, tasty food and constant refill of water, keep me coming back to this place. I always leave a 20% tip, because I appreciate all they do.
author: Charlene C.

description:
i love vietnamese food, and sunflower has just that.

the service was nice. the place was hot (inside was so stuffy and hot, outside was perfect). the portions were large. the prices were low.

there's sorta two locations, check that, there's two different entrances. same kitchen.
author: Ameer N.

description: Damn good garlic noodles.  Usually just get takeout because it's a small space.  Occasionally I will throw a little tofu and veggies in.  Nice and spicy house chili sauce.  Quick and pretty cheap.  Big portions so split it or eat for lunch and dinner.  Perfect timing after walking around the Mission all day, hitting DOLO, or before a show at the Roxie.
author: Maggie M.

description: This place nice!  Usually quiet, with a steady stream of customers, never TOO busy.  The five-spice chicken is really good, as well as the curry chicken and of course, the rolls!  Plus, I am automatically a fan of any place that serves thai iced tea....the drink of the gods....I am addicted to it. Anyways, really comfortable atmosphere, servers are friendly, it's just comfy.
author: Caitlin D.

description:
What happened? Sunflower used to be my favorite restaurant! I used to go more regularly, but the last time I went, about 2 months ago, I ordered the vermicelli bowl to go and it was a disappointment!!!
My friend's roommate had something else with chicken that was horrible, and my friend's Garlic Veggies were just OK for me.
Now every time I want a vermicelli bowl, I go to Emerald Garden in Sunny Alameda. They have awesome service and live Jazz every Friday and Saturday night. 
I still drool every time I pass by Sunflower, but don't think I can afford to pay for crappy food or service (no matter how "cheap"). I guess it is a hit-or-miss kinda place.
author: Cristina R.

description:
Went here for lunch on a friend's recommendation.  We need to stop taking his advice.  What a disappointment.

Ordered the vermicelli rolls (ok, a bit bland), lemongrass beef, and vegetarian spring roll (fried).  Maybe we had totally different expectations and that was our downfall.  Honestly, the dishes tasted like Americanized Chinese food.  The lemongrass beef had no lemongrass flavor.  And the fried rolls had no other vegetables besides cabbage.  I felt ill after the meal.

On the other hand, service was good...
author: Goodbers G.

description:
"Hello young maaaaaang!" is the friendly greeting you're almost guaranteed if you're male and under 40.  If you're lucky he'll put his hand on your back and lovingly ask you if you want a drink.  Adorable.

This place has been a staple of my weekday dinnerfare for over 5 years.  They just jacked up their prices by about a buck - the first increase i've seen - and redid the dilapidated menus, but not much else has changed.  This includes the staff.  

It's pretty standard Vietnames fare, but there are some definite standouts.  They include:

Vietnamese pot stickers - delicious balls of fried rice filled with pork and shrimp and i think chicken, served with a few dipping sauces.  

Shaking Beef - wok flashed cubes of steak in a savory, spicy sauce

Hot & Sour White Fish soup - WOW.  So good.  It actually makes your mouth water for more each bite.  It's sweet, spicy, citrusy, savory, crunch, hot, cold..... amazing.

Love it.  I'll be back another 293 times.
author: Jon B.

description: I love this restaurant so much!  Been here for three times and it never disappoints me.  The food is well priced and the waitresses are always attentive.
author: Moko R.

description: Good comfort food. Occasional weird smell. I've gotten good service every time I've been here.
author: Charles B.

description:
One block from the 16th/Mission BART stop.  We only waited 10 minutes. I am thinking the waiters know how to speak "Cantonese". I have never eaten VIETNAMESE FOOD in the mission district before and this was place pretty good compared to the Vietnamese places down in San Jose.  Will need to come back to evaluate the taste of the Pho. 

Banh Xeo (#8) Vietnamese crepe. A lot of ingredients for $7.50. I wish they provided more exotic Vietnamese greens aside from the Romaine/Mint/Cucumber/Carrots/Daikon.  Usually the Banh Xeo's I eat in San Jose provide a lot more veggies.

The Imperial rolls were really good ---- it has a heavy garlic flavor.  $5.95.

The spring rolls are HUGE - I have never seen this gigantic spring roll before.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
if you go there, sit down.  
Do not even attempt ordering to go. specially NOT in person and NOT during lunch time. 
They told me  "tenh minute tenh minute.."  I waited over 25' and decided to take off. This happened three times. Last time I got the wrong item. Hella wrong item, not even vermicelli or rice on that thing.. it was all bbq pork. not that this is bad or anything. i tend to love vietnamese-style bbq pork with all my face, but this time I was mad. 

That was the last time I step into that restaurant for take-out. F*ck you, Sunflower. I win.
author: Tomas V.

description:
This place really packs em in and packs on the garlic. We had green beans, shaken beef and spring rolls (fried) as per other yelpers suggestions...and boy were we happy ! Our food came quickly, we didn't have to wait for a table (saturday night) and we had enough leftovers for the next evening! Wow.

On second visit....was bothered by the atmosphere...not the cleanest...
author: Kyla L.

description:
I have to agree with the people who say this is not authentic Vietnamese food.  Not only that, it just isn't good.  

When we went here, I placed my order in Vietnamese and the waiter (Asian guy) was rude about the fact that he didn't speak Vietnamese -- as if I should have known to place my order in some other language (such as English or Spanish?)  

Nevermind the food, I guess Authentic Vietnamese doesn't mean Authentic Vietnamese waiters.  Silly me.  Just for the record, this was the first Vietnamese restaurant I have ever eaten at where the waiter does not speak Vietnamese.  Authentic Vietnamese my ass...
author: Spicy T.

description:
I had the best Vietnamese meal here at Sunflower...because I'm a vegequarian, it's difficult to choose good food from a menu (yes, I can hear you carnivores now screaming - just eat meat!).  I had their vermicelli and they graciously substituted the pork imperial roll for the veggie version.  In fact, the first place I've been to with a veggie imperial roll!  

Their service is a little lacking in that there is literally 2 people running food out and taking orders - so from that standpoint they can do better.  Does anyone know if the one around the corner - the smaller one - have better service?

Anyway, I thought it was great and really glad we tried it!
author: Square P.

description:
The worst service, and food to go
I love hole in the wall places, but the male server is the wost server I had seen in my life.  Not one smile, and do not remember his menu by numbers.  It will take you 10 mnutes to get him to serve you, and my 5 spice chicken was dried out.  Food is oily, and there are plenty for better service and food around the neighborhood.
author: S S.

description: So delicious.  FYI the pho is labeled as noodle soup, I use that is the Americanization of Vietnamese spots.  Regardless, it is delicious, do your self a favor and go get your pho on.
author: Rayna B.

description:
I love Vietnamese food! I don't love Sunflower. I've had pho and a vermicelli plate there and both weren't really up to par. They are pretty decently priced however. 
The decor is strictly no frills and it's tiny--I actually like places like this. Usually that's a good sign, but alas the food dissapointed (except the imperial rolls--those were okay). The chicken and beef were both a little too dry for my tastes and overall there wasn't anything that would drive me back.
author: David C.

description: Pretty yum! I go there often when in the mission. Pho and spring rolls are pretty awesome.
author: Monster L.

description: My friend who lives in the mission decided to take a couple of out of town friends and myself to this really cute Vietnamese place. The service was friendly and fairly quick, although it was a jam packed super busy Friday night. I ordered the seafood noodle soup, which is usually one of my favorite dishes, but was disappointed by the bland broth making my meal less than exciting. BUT, one of my friends ordered the Sunshine Prawns (which the server said was his favorite dish). Now that was AMAZING and my friend was kind enough to share with everyone at the table. Basically you get 4 gigantic prawns cooked to perfection with the shell on served over a bed of delicious garlic noodles. Perfection. I forgot all about my boring bowl of soup. I'll be back to order this dish to enjoy all to myself :)
author: Laura L.

description:
We ordered the Vietnamese Crepe, Beef Pho and the BBQ Pork with Imperial Rolls over Vermicelli.

Vietnamese Crepe- Crunchy on the outside, fluffy on the inside.  Perfect appetizer for two or three people.  The only complaint I have is that I wish they would have served us the fish sauce in a bigger dish so that we could dunk the crepe instead of using a spoon to scoop tiny dollops.

Beef Pho- The broth was incredibly delicious especially combined with the fresh basil. Unfortunately, the beef just felt rubbery with little flavor.  But, jesus, the pho was so good.

BBQ Pork and Imperial Rolls- Pork was just right.  A little on the fatty side, but I think that ultimately added to the flavor. Imperial rolls fried to the right crispness. I thought the portion of this dish was spot on.  I would order this again.

We sat next to a couple who ordered the Shaken Beef and that looked so good.  It had a dark redish look, glazed with sweet sauce.  And they give you a shit load of it.

My quip with this place is that they try to cram a bunch of people in too little of space and no one can really sit comfortably to eat.  Especially if you're sitting in ear shot of a whiny girl trying to impress some guy.  Also, the people who ordered after us got their food before us and that was sorta lame.  But, in reality, it's all about the food and the uncomfortableness is worth it.
author: Allison R.

description: Their vegetarian meals are impressively delicious and filling.  I have tried both vegetarian lunch specials, spicy green beans and lemon grass tofu.   The vegetarian spring rolls are among my brother's and mother's favorites.
author: Coyote B.

description:
Order the Vietnamese Crepe, the Crab and Corn soup, and something with BBQ'd pork and you will not be disappointed.

It does get super crowded, but you can always get take-out and hermit it up like me. 

Oh, and the Fresh Shrimp Spring rolls with peanut sauce are SO yummy. 

Go eat!
author: Irene T.

description:
pros: Great value for the price, food taste good and never disappointed. 
Cons: No dessert offered and the Vietnamese coffee is always cold.
author: Carl T.

description: The flavor of the "lemongrass" part of my lemongrass chicken dish was delicious. However, the chicken tasted like it had been cooked hours earlier with zero spices and then thrown into the lemongrass seasoning. It was too gamey to eat.
author: Christen J.

description:
So there's a spectrum of Vietnamese food that I've been exposed to - on one end there's Tu Lan (I've eaten there once, got creeped out when I saw chopped meat that was left out on one of the tables and in buckets in one of the upstairs rooms), and then on the other end is Slanted Door (good but pricey, killer views) - in the upper middle spectrum there's Out The Door (as good as Slanted Door, but still expensive). 

Sunflower hoovers around the middle, with their reasonable pricing, generous portions, fast service and decent food.

A recent visit had me sampling a few notable items: fried tofu stuffed with lemongrass, crispy vegetarian imperial rolls and the monster portioned vegetarian vermicelli (which comes with a vegetarian spicy vinaigrette - woop!). Everything was delicious! My dinner mates liked their chicken and seafood based entrees too.

I personally like eating at their 16th street location around the corner for something more lowkey, but for anything larger than two I'd recommend eating at this location.
author: Sean G.

description:
My friends had good things to say about this place, but once I experienced it, I wasn't very impressed. 

Appearance-wise, the entire restaurant could use some serious renovations, as it looks dingy and dated. Food-wise, their portions were large, but I found their menu to be deceiving. As someone who isn't crazy about spicy food, I ordered one of the only things on the menu that wasn't listed as such. But when I finally tasted my salad, it was quite hot. Grr! 

Best thing about this place (aside from the adorably gay waiter who hit on my friend throughout our meal) was the coconut milk. They actually stick a straw in a coconut and plop it right there on the table for you! Fabulous!
author: Jordan K.

description:
Vegetarian Hot and Sour Soup!

Get it.
Got it?
Good...

It's better than being tickled by the one you love.

There's one waiter who's EXCEPTIONALLY flirty...I swear I practically got a neck rub while slirping up dat fantastic soup!  He did it right in front of my boyfriend too, who was too preoccupied with his own slirping to even care (we'll have words later).  Now if Omar had been the one massaging my neck whilest I was slirping up this liquid manna - well I suppose I would have just love-hiccuped.

Did I mention the soup?
author: Mc Matty b.

description:
for the most part, i've been a serial creature of habit and a cave dweller until relatively recently.  ...shielding my eyes from the brilliance that the first steps from my cave induced, i quickly fluttered my eyes open and breathed in the slight scent of adventures to come.

an outing w/the lovely jessica t. was long overdue.  after hitting up another notable establishment, we needed a little nourishment, so jessica suggested that we go to sunflower cafe.

first impression?  not fancy.  not divey either.  just perfect for this evening.  there were several tables that were in the middle of their meal, and my sideways glances resulted in a momentary, subtle, celebratory, 'yesss!' when i saw the sizable portions of their entrees.  

i decided on the vermicelli w/bbq pork (lemongrass marinade) & imperial rolls ($7.95).  the wait time was very brief, and the portion was big.  the imperial rolls' wrapper was nice and crispy, but not greasy (SO important), and the pork was cooked and marinated nicely.  the chopped greens and cucumbers at the bottom of the bowl weren't soggy and seemed like they were cut fresh to order.  the fish sauce that also came w/the dish wasn't overwhelmingly fishy, which was good.  

sure, i may slip back into cave dwelling habits, but it's unlikely that i'll want to stay for very long in the dark, knowing that there are quite a few places out there that beckon w/big, tasty portions that will easily give me four meals.
author: Ting A.

description:
Look at all the people being hard on Sunflower.  
Ok, so maybe "authentic" is a little strong for serious followers of Vietnamese cuisine, but in my ten to fifteen experiences here, I have not been disappointed.  My one disclaimer is that this is a vegetarian's review, so I can't speak to the meat question.  But my girlfriend loves the seafood noodle soup - gets it every time we go.  

The vegetarian spring rolls are very fresh with just the right touch of mint and very tasty tofu.  Share them with a friend, and you'll have something nice to snack on right up until your quickly prepared entrees come out.  

Vegetarians have several good options.  I usually go with the spicy green beans, which are not actually that spicy, but very flavorful with the garlic and shiitakes.  Add tofu for an extra dollar.  The garlic vegetable and garlic eggplant are also very solid, as is the lemongrass tofu.  I have also tried the eggplant curry, which had a good taste but was a little too heavy and oily to compete with the aforementioned options for a repeat performance.  Portions are large; I usually have leftovers.

The service at Sunflower is great; all the staff are among the friendliest in the city, and that's what takes this beyond being just a 4 star review.  The gentleman who seats customers has to be the nicest and one of the hardest working restaurateurs in the city.  
If that doesn't count for anything with you or if you're a real "authenticity" fetishist, maybe Sunflower isn't for you.  Thanks for making it easier for me to get a table.
author: Josh C.

description:
Two words: vegetarian pho.

Forget everything else on the menu.
Order the pho.
Eat the pho.
Go home both happy and with half the pho to eat tomorrow.
author: Erin P.

description: I can't help but order the veggie noodle soup and veggie Vietnamese crepe when I come here. The soup is way more than enough for two full meals and the bean sprouts/lime/basil are plentiful on the side. The crepe is crispy goodness. I'm always impressed with the freshness of the vegetables.
author: Robyn M.

description:
Good food, Great smells!

The Shakin beef is good, not great though, just doesn't have that power punch of flavor that its smell and appearance would lead you to expect.  Shame too since I have so been looking for a place that does it right.

The garlic noodles are good, I'd say it was the best of the three things I had, flavorful and tasty.

The garlic eggplant not so great, it tasted good, but the eggplant wasn't top notch and the flavor was not spectacular.

I think I'd go back, but I'd have to be in the mood for garlic noodles.
author: Stephen H.

description:
Everyone and their mother recommends this place to me when I mention that I love vietnamese. Problem is I lived about 5 steps from it for a year, and tried it about 3 times....it was just soooo bland, every time.
The food is ok, it seems pretty fresh, but there is just absolutely no flavor at all. 
One big BLAH. 
(Go to Tan Tamh II, across the street if you want some good vietnamese)
author: Jessica T.

description: They have the best lunch special $8.50.  Soup, salad, rice, imperial roll and entree.  I had the special with 5 spice chicken.  There was so much food I couldn't finish it.  The Bun and the vietnamese crepe are excellent also.  Friendly staff, quick.  Always a great experience.
author: Mark C.

description:
I consider myself to be a "beginner" when it comes to Vietnamese food.

Needless to say, I liked Sunflower! I had no preconcieved notions about this place at all - just that a friend said it was good. We went to the tiny place a few doors down from the Roxie - the tiny one on 16th street. We sat close enough to hear that the couple next to us was talking about "safety words"...so it was a little cozy.  We ordered the beef - "shaken" I think? Way tender and yum. Spring rolls had tons of garlic, which was fine by me. I'd eat garlic on toast for dinner. I liked it. I'd go again if I was in the neighborhood. I wish they had one where I live!
author: Kristen O.

description:
Yuk. Bland Pho, bland fresh spring rolls (with gritty, sandy basil that obviously wasn't washed). And the grossest, soupiest, funkiest dipping sauce I've ever had the misfortune of dipping my food into.

Yes, it's cheap. But you get what you pay for.
author: Maureen G.

description:
My wife and I went to that restaurant when we were still dating. We had a late dinner there and while chatting didn't realize it became past 10pm (or whatever closing hour they had that day).
The waiter came to our table and in a rude way told us that we have to leave now while his colleague started to shut down some of the lights in the room.
Once out my wife realized she forgot her purse on a seat inside. Since they had locked the door we knocked on it seeing that they were still inside doing some cleaning. No one replied or came over even as they were moping the floor relatively close to the door.
After repeated attempts to get their attention failed I pulled out my phone and told them loudly that I was calling the police. They came right away to the door and hand us over the purse.
This place is dead to me.
author: Jean T.

description:
Yum yum lunch specials.  Large portions that will help you add your contribution to America's obesity epidemic.

(Even if you don't want to finish your entire meal, you'll still enjoy whatever percentage you consume.)
author: Sanjeev B.

description:
I got take out. They were very fast in preparing my food.

For $7.05 (they accept cc with no minimum charge, score!), I got the beef noodle pho that had the rare slices of thin steak. Very good sized portion with lots of green onions and sliced red onions. Gave me two limes, basil, and a lot of bean sprouts. The beef was packed raw (YES!) with the noodles so you can pour hot soup on the meat to cook it, even when you're at home!

As for the taste...the noodles were a tiny bit on the soft side for me. The soup was decent, but sweeter than I like. It didn't seem too greasy, which was nice. I feel like it was a little msged. Meat was good and lean. They don't have any other options it seems for the beef (i.e. tendon, brisket, tripe, etc.).

All in all, decent bowl of pho. I would go here if I was dying for pho in the 16th St. Mission and couldn't manage to go to the Tenderloin for a better bowl of pho or to 18th/Harrison for a more decent bowl of pho.
author: Angela H.

description:
Was very busy on a Friday night-- we got their just before the rush and only had to wait 2 minutes for a table-- we had a larger party of 5 so we had to wait for them to put two tables together. 

When we all ordered, the waiter was kind and told us we ordered too much food. He was right!!! They give you huge portions. 

I tried the Garlic Noodles with beef and The BBQ pork with brown rice-- both were EXCELLENT!!! 

Had a bite of a friend's Eggplant Curry and that was good, too!!! Other friends had some of the vegetarian dishes and raved about them.
author: Heather L.

description: This place is frickin' awesome.  I always get vermicelli with pork and imperial rolls.  It's super cheap and a ton of food.  The service is no-nonsense but pretty fast.  I crave this place at least once a week.
author: James D.

description:
Sunflower is definitely one of my favorite local eateries.  I always crave the Vietnamese crepe.  It's crispy and delicious, filled with chicken, shrimp and bean sprouts and comes with lettuce to wrap it up in and "magic sauce", as I call it: the sweet fish sauce mix that comes with almost everything.

I could go for that right now, actually.

On one occasion, while waiting for our take-out delivery, our favorite waiter brought us Thai iced tea gratis.  He always makes it a point to be very friendly with us, even when he's clearly slammed with orders.
author: Xtina C.

description: All I have to do is walk in and the waiter says "Veggie Noodle Soup?" and then I sit down and get the best Veggie Pho in SF! No fuss, no pretension and the price is right. This is not fancy and the wait staff won't kiss your a**, but the service is fast and efficient. And well the soup is perf.
author: Mara S.

description:
Since they share a kitchen and it's a given that both locations have some of the best low- to mid-priced Vietnamese food in the city, the question then becomes, which location offers the better experience?  I make a case for the Valencia St. door, because:

1.  The dining room is WAY nicer than the 16th St. location; carpets, wall hangings and soft lighting as opposed to formica, linoleum and fluorescents

2.  Valencia St. actually has a bathroom

3.  If you're male, you can get relentlessly hit on by the world's most hilarious Vietnamese blow-dried queen waiter, who will unfailingly call you "young man" and make obvious pass after obvious pass.  

Don't miss out!
author: Jefferson C.

description:
What makes a good Vietnamese restaurant is 1. the griminess, 2. the grimy looking workers, and 3. the large unnecessary flat-screen tv's that just show pictures of food on the menu. This place doesn't have any of these. However, the food is delicious, so I'm torn. 

The bun thit nuong cha gio (that's vermicelli, pork, and egg rolls for all you Topher Grace-looking honkeytonks) contains the perfect proportions and will leave you feeling nice and greasy, but in a good way. I've been Vietnamese for 22 years (my roommate's Korean) and I can vouch for the authenticity of this dish. 

Worst part though was trying to order in Vietnamese, only to be denied by our Pinoy server. What?!? Are the Philippines even IN Asia?
author: Steven H.

description:
Decent Vietnamese joint in a good location, well, not for parking, but cool area none the least.  There's one around the corner that is comparable but the only reason I come to this place is for the Vegetable Noodle Soup.  

Don't eat it plain!

Add:

Sriracha
Hoisen Sauce
The other Chili Sauce
And all that Jazz.

I'm not a vegetarian and typically I rather have a bowl of pho, but the above mentioned is the best thing on the menu, and one of the cheapest.

You will make the perfect hang-over cure and it's perfect after yoga.  Well, at least I think so.
author: Justin C.

description:
The food is really good  but i can't go back because the one time i ate here i took the leftovers home and found a extra little eight-legged friend in my to-go bag.... he was a baby, and he was already a dead baby... and of course he has cousin's in every restaurant in the city... 

but all things being equal, i have to pass on eating here again :(
author: Steve B.

description:
Authentic?? not even close.  I've been to Vietnam.  I've had real Vietnamese food.  this is not it.  Though it isn't the worst thing that i have ever tasted, it is not great Vietnamese food.  

I haven't been to the one around the corner, but i think they share kitchens.  The service at this spot was horrible.  I was waiting in line for 15 minutes while staring at an empty table that i could have been sitting at.  The people behind me and I started joking about how ridiculous it was that we weren't being sat.  Finally I got my seat.  Some people rave about the flamboyantly gay hostest/server that works there.  they think that he is funny and nice.  I found him odd and not polite at all.  

If you want good Vietnamese food in the area go to Will's on 14th and Church.  Otherwise head to Little Saigon for better Vietnamese.
author: Andrew r.

description:
I only gave it two stars because its a fun atmosphere and its conveniently close to my apartment. Otherwise, UGH...So hey, if you love flavorless food, check it out. I found myself pouring two little bowls of sauce on my noodles due to lack of taste. I left full, but not satisfied. 
They accept credit cards for any amount. The guy who serves you is fabulous, and a wonderful singer. Only if the food was good. Dang.
author: Shaina P.

description:
Okay yelpers, this is the single worst dining experience in my twenty three years of life. 

Yesterday evening I met two friends for dinner & drinks at Sunflower, intending to give them some company (and have a beer) as I had just gobbled down a super burrito an hour ago. The dinner got off to a foul start as I got the stink eye from the waiter for just ordering a drink. I sampled the dinner, it was somewhere between mediocre and good (the vegetables tasted a bit uncooked). As the waiter took the dishes, in a hurry he dropped a coconut curry covered piece of broccoli in my black leather Member's Only jacket. Needless to say, I was upset! I get the waiter's attention, and I get a yelling "what you want me to do??!?" Uhhm, apologize? At some point shortly thereafter, I walked out to a yelling "you the worst customer I had in twenty years!"

Watch out!
author: Baiju B.

description:
Good pho, atmosphere notsomuch.  But the pho is exactly what you want it to be.  The steamed veggie potstickers are really good.

I was confused by the two entrances, seems odd.  I've only been to the 16th side of the restie.  It's not exactly cute but it serves it's purpose.
author: Emily T.

description:
Very tiny place on 16th street. it is great for lunch, sometimes quick dinner. perfect for take out. I am a fan of this place for a long time.
I am addicted to their fresh shrimp rolls that i consider the best in SF. and of course, the beef Pho noodle soup is just to die for. Love it!!! I also tried their grilled octopus salad that sometimes is a little bit to grilled :)
Prices are very cheap so you will leave full and happy!
author: Maria B.

description: I went here for dinner on a Tuesday night with a friend. I had gotten Vietnamese Iced Coffees here before so was excited to try it for dinner since the coffees were so good. It was happenin' for Tuesday though we were able to get a table without waiting. I ordered the pan fried rice noodles with tofu and vegetables and my friend got the garlic vegetables. My noodles were okay - a little dry like it was just heated from the microwave and the veggies were coarsely and inconsistently chopped. There were huge chunks of bell pepper and squash next to tiny mushrooms. The garlic veggies had a nice sauce to them which I used for my noodles. Overall, I would consider coming back here to try something different but I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here again.
author: Amy N.

description:
I really like this place. It's not fancy, it's not pretentious and sometimes I think the waiter hates me, but I still really like it. It's cheap as you can get a decent dinner for, and you will most likely leave with some leftovers for lunch.

My usual staple is the vegetarian noodle soup, which is good and fresh, if a little bland. Just add hot sauce I say! Alternatively there is the hot and sour veggie soup, which I would love except for the pineapple. I don't like pineapple in my soup. I'm weird.

Also super yummy and fresh are the spring rolls with shrimp and the (fried) imperial rolls are a tasty treat. Their lunch special is also pretty amazing and comes with a ton of food for a penance.

Just hear this - this place is not amazing. Not phenomenal. Padma and her BFFs from Top Chef would probably call it uninspired and even a little bit boring.

But they would totally slink back over on a rainy day when the cameras weren't rolling for some warm, noodly goods.
author: Melanie D.

description:
If you come inside out of the cold, and stand there watching amazing plates of food being brought out one after another, all of them emanating  wonderfully fragrant aromas, then you've come to the right place. Waiting there, we seemed to be ignored, but I think they were just busy, and knew we were there, and perhaps thought we knew they knew, but we weren't sure.... if that makes sense. Anyway, because I didn't know that they knew, I went to ask to make sure they knew, and indeed they did. Who knew?

Well, when we got our seats, the waiters were exceedingly polite and accommodating. The decor is pleasant and neither fashionably hip, or ethnically gaudy. The food came out in good time, and was fantastic. Here's what we had.

Fried Tofu Appetizer - delicious! crispy on the outside, tofuy on the inside, with a savory ginger and lemongrass infused sauce
Spicy Green Beans - not very spicy, and very fresh and not overly cooked
Steamed Sea Bass - the highlight of the night. Succulent and delicate, with a subtly flavored broth around it.
Garlic Prawn Noodles - simple yet memorably good

If you go, keep in mind there are no reservations, and it gets busy after 7 on a Saturday night. Public transit is the best way to get here. Come with a healthy appetite and eat slowly to savor each bite. Enjoy!
author: Boris C.

description:
The prices are up my alley of affordable and I must admit the spring rolls and  imperial rolls are satisfying. The rest is just plain satisfactory. After asking the couple next to me what was good, they replied that they come for the garlic noodles and butterfly shrimp. A heaping plate came out full of spices, bits of garlic and deep fried crustacean, about 5 of them. On top of the vermicelli bowl, my stomach became intimidated from the noodles galore and persuaded me to take the rest home. 

I wish I could've finished that meal drunk because the last couple days I haven't had time to go to the grocery store so I've been eating portions of the noodles. I feel ill and the worst part is I knowingly eat that quality of food when I'm sober just because I hate wasting food. It must be the impending doom I felt when mom expressed at dinners that "God's gonna get you"

p.s. I say this after writing my last review of Thanh Long so it may be partial to them
author: Kim G.

description:
Great for lunch  or dinner. 

Only gets 4 stars cause the male waiter has a habit of touching me while I eat. Please don't do that !!!!
author: Joe G.

description:
I don't think I have ever just decided to go eat here as a plan. 

However....when ever I go by it I always want to stop there and have a meal. I really like their food a lot. The last time I went there, I was with my friend coming back from a long day of drinking at the Dickens Fair and we wanted to get something to eat and maybe suck up the last dregs of the beers we had been drinking all day. Since we took Mission back from the Cow Palace we happened to pass Sunflower, and naturally I yelled STOP! Do you like Vietnamese?

We went in, and were seated immediately. Our waiter was pretty over bearing. He handed us our menus and then stood over us while we read them. when we looked up he said "Are you ready to order???" There seemed to be a little manic behavior going on there, since the restaurant was full and he had the time to stand and watch us choose our food. Hmmm. Strange behavior...

I ordered the Lemongrass chicken and my friend ordered a fish dish. Mine was good, but his was FANTASTIC! I wish to Gods that I could remember what he ordered so that I could have my own. But no such luck for me. What was lucky was that he didn't finish his and left it for me to eat the next day. YAY!

Someday I will know which dish it was.....
author: Marz W.

description:
Sunflower has been one of my fav places to go since my high school days.  It's good food, with huge portions, and for a reasonable price.  For those purist out there I warn you this is not an authentic vietnamese place.  

As of late though the food has been hit or miss.  I'm not sure if it's the economy and them having to cut corners, but it's not the way it used to be.  Two years ago I would have given it a 5 hands down, but now a days I feel like my jaw is going to break from the shaken beef.  It used to be cuts of tender beef that melted like butter...now's it's mystery cut that scares me.  

I'll stick with my garlic noodles!!  That has still been very faithful to me.
author: Bella P.

description:
Yum! I heard through the grapevine that Sunflower would be light on the pocket but also good. That was also the beginning of a vietnamese food craving. It was all I could think about - noodles, soup and noodles, carrots and bean sprouts, more noodles. Finally, meaning the next day, my friend and I were famished, looking for a late lunch, and the first thing to pop out of my mouth is "sunflower!" 

My my, the bbq pork and egg roll vermicelli came and it was HUGE. I really enjoyed the flavor of the pork, the tasty egg roll, and those pickled carrots. You can't beat it for 8 dollars. Julia had the seafood pho that was also tasty. The broth was enhanced by quite a bit of hot sauce and a dash of hoisin sauce. I have to admit that I was slightly disappointed that they use thin rice noodles as opposed to flat rice noodles. But it's nothing to quibble over. My craving was momentarily sated and all the noodles sent me into a food coma. But now I'm just craving more vietnamese food! This is a vicious cycle.
author: Faye P.

description:
HOLY guacomole!  I am literally changed...I will never eat anything else again

Here is what I would like to say regarding my lunch/dinner last night:
1. I had the veggie spring rolls & veggie salad with tofu: WTF why is vietnamese food so DAMN delicious...I mean really.  I had food coming out of my ears yet here I was chomping away at this delicious cabagge salad. I ate myself retarded due to their selfish good food making
2. This place is cheap.  For $12 I got both a HUGE salad & delicious spring rolls...this place allows me to eat out on a regular basis instead of eating diet coke & microwavable popcorn for dinner
3. Whats up with the graffitied bathroom? came out of left feild and further who really tags "poop penis vagina" these days...are we in the 3rd grade?  didn't phase me tho
author: KT F.

description:
I wasn't completely blown away but this place is certainly an improvement over Will's bland bland BLAND pho.

The place was busy but the service was quick and efficient. 

Share the garlic noodles with a friend ... HUGE portions!
author: Joyce S.

description:
One of my favored lunchtime dining spots, Sunflower gets my business about once a month since it's a quick drive down 16th and there's a parking lot about a block away if you can't find a spot on the street in this neighborhood of notorious tow-aways. My boyfriend and I liked the fact that it was far enough away from work but close enough for us to make it back to the office for our meetings.

Their vermicelli bowls (bean sprouts, shredded lettuce, chopped mint and peanuts on the bottom, a layer of dry (not in soup), plain cooked vermicelli and then your choice of meat/non-meat) is my standard fare here, with my preference is the grilled prawn/impreial roll combo. I like that they don't go crazy with the cilantro unlike most Asian restaurants, causing me to want to make a "Calvin & Hobbes" face (you know the one I'm talking about, the *ACK* face). I can't detect any real noticeable lemongrass, but the prawns are topped with some cooked green onions which makes for a nice flavor break. 

I used to get their lunch special, before I began noticing how sleepy I got when I was back at work. This comes on a gigantic platter and has a fried imperial roll, a decent sized red leaf lettuce salad, rice and your choice of meat or veggie entree-and a small bowl of soup. At the nice price of $7.95 you will be sure to get your money's worth. I think I switched to the prawns because I found the beef retained a bit too much cooking oil for my tastes.

 If we're feeling a need to throw in some veggies that day, the veggie spring rolls are a nice addition since my boyfriend almost always gets the pho bo, occasionally broken in routine by the pho ga and I always get on his case about the lack of veggies in his diet. The pho is alright, I I prefer pho ga from Turtle Tower and pho bo from my Oakland establishments, but I'm sure if you had a red hot burning desire for pho and you're in the Mission, this place will take care of it for you.
author: Mortiche W.

description:
I like this place a lot and eat here and get take out often. Really like the hot and sour fish soup and crispy crepe. I also like the slightly surly, pony tailed waiter. When relatively cheap and tasty is in order, I go to Sunflower.

EDIT: I miss you Sunflower. Especially the 16th street side.
author: Raj T.

description:
Haha, I just found out that this is the same place as the one around the corner!  This one is the more ghetto version for sure, but when my friends and I weren't able to get a seat at the nicer one we settled for here.

The BBQ beef with imperial rolls in vermicelli is AWESOME.
author: Corey C.

description: I'm not a huge Vietnamese food fan and this place didn't change my mind. Good service though and my friends all loved it
author: Greta M.

description: Authentic.  You will smell when leaving but will be especially pleased with the good food.  Highly rec the beef!
author: Kevin H.

description:
I had the lemongrass beef.  Decent but would be better with a sauce.

More importantly, signs were posted all over the walls about the lack of alcohol and I paraphrase "No Wine/Beer For Temporary"

Nice grammar. Must be real Vietnamese!
author: Zé M.

description:
So one random night I wanted a bowl of pho. So I yelped up places near my area and I found sunflower. I drove, even though its like 4 blocks from my condo (ya I was lazy that night). I walked in and was greeted by this really Fugly guy. He was staring me down like I was a piece of cheap meat. Er!  So I sat down, looked at their menu and found what I wanted. It didn't take long for my food which is good but what bothered me was the table wasn't set for someone to sit until someone actually sits down. BAD! I also got a thai ice tea which was really bland. The fugly guy kept looking at me while I ate, so I kept my head down and just looked at my food. 

All in all the food was ok but the fugly guy creeps me out, so I don't think I'd return!
author: Lucky M.

description: Decent Pho...nothing spectacular, but I have to give it its proper due for helping me get through a cold last week.  If you're coming here to eat some tasty pho, then I don't recommend this spot...but if you're coming here to fight a sinus infection, then you've come to the right place.
author: Jeronimo L.

description:
The Pho was delicious (I had seafood, my friend had beef).

The service was fast and friendly.

The lemonade was exceptional.

I just have to take a few stars off for the roaches I saw running around on the floor.  I know this is San Francisco, but, yuck.
author: Zoe H.

description: we go here at least twice a week. the vermicelli bowl is my favorite and the imperials are some of the best i ever had.
author: Melissa R.

description:
come here if you want:
-horrible service, extreme short staff on a saturday night
-standoff-ish, rude, sassy ass waiters (oh hell no)
-slooooooow cooking, serving, getting anything
-americanized "authentic vietnamese food" 
-get your entire days worth of sodium in one meal (SUPER salty dishes)

i don't know why i decided to get vietnamese food in the mission. i should've known better, i DO know better. after trying the other small vietnamese joint across the street and being disappointed, i suppose I attempted to see if sunflower could redeem the mission viet food street cred. but no. you guys failed, miserably. next.
author: Jennie L.

description:
Question: What has two seperate addresses but intersect at a 45 degree angle and share the same kitchen? SunFlower Of Course!

Seriously, one is on 16th and the other is on Valencia, but they share a kitchen and connect in the back. How Kewl and confusing for those who don't know.

That kewl factor aside, the food was very delicious and the people that work there were very attentive and sweet. The Prices were awesome too!
Rock your world (and theirs too)...SunFlower will make you smile ;o)
author: Venatius P.

description: This was my first restaurant visit after moving into the Mission this weekend (yes, I am no longer in the East Bay, but will still frequent my favorite stops there often). Very solid Vietnamese, extremely friendly staff for decent price. The hot&sour soup had a hint of pineapple, which I wouldn't think I'd like, but did. One downfall was the fresh spring rolls had too many rice noodles and were lacking in flavor. Also tried spicy lemongrass chicken/green beans which was tasty.
author: Kristen R.

description:
Third time eating.... trying to eat their food.
Chicken Pho - bland, not flavor
Lemongrass tofu - oily and too much garlic (the overwhelming flavor)
garlic vegetables - Soggy, overcooked, cornstarch sauce

Yuck
Almost uneatable - am I eating at the same restaurant or just picking the wrong dishes?
author: Ken H.

description: BEST vegetarian pho in the entire city! Actually, best vegetarian pho i have ever had. I went vegetarian about 4 months ago and i couldn't have kept it up if it wasn't for their delicious broth and veggies.
author: Katie G.

description:
A family friend introduced us to this place 3 weeks ago. I was expecting a family run Vietnamese cafeteria, but instead I considered them more of a gourmet Vietnamese for the foodies.

Everybody was raving about the Garlic noodle, which I tasted from a leftovers 2 weeks prior.  And of course we ordered this garlic noodle ( 3 orders) and some other dish.

At this point other dish we ordered that day - did not register in my brain. The only things that's imprinted in my mind was - guess - was the GARLIC NOODLE.

Its served in a big plate - good for 4-5 people. It has big thick noodles with reddish brown sauce that a bit sweet and a tinge of garlic - perfect for my taste buds. Also included in the dish are huge SHRIMPS, covered with that Sweet garlicky sauce. Yum-E

I gave it five stars - for being a neighborhood gem with affordable price, gourmet viet food and friendly service.
author: Noel T.

description: The portions here are very generous. I come here often to get garlic noodles for take out. Delicious and Dinner + lunch for 8$? YES! The shaking beef and imperial rolls are both awesome as well.
author: Mars C.

description: This place is definitely getting more crowded than a few years ago. I love their chicken vermiselli with spring rolls. The service is super fast and friendly.
author: Yoko S.

description:
Gaaaaaahrlic Noodles!!!!
I haven't been to the mission in almost a year...didn't quite miss it so much (PTSD tends to kick in once I set foot there), so what could make me trek out to the city? Well the only thing that I could think of was the most amazing noodles ever--garlic noodles from Sunflower.
They were everything that my little taste buds needed for the unusually warm Saturday afternoon. I think that they are the best, best, best, best--best!!
author: Hilda Z.

description:
Got takeout food here tonight.

House fried rice.  The dish was ok, but not great.  The price was fairly low.  Overall the value was fine, but the service was the pits. They totally went out of their way to be rude, first when I ordered and paid, then again when I picked up the food.  Inexcusable.
author: Tom C.

description: After a night of drinking with friends, we came here for a late night snack. I had a crepe and my girlfriend got a vermicelli dish. My girlfriend, being Vietnamese, said the food had good flavor and tasted authentic. I thought it tasted good as well (but for me, wasn't sure if it was the alcohol talking or not).
author: Leo C.

description:
Sorry guys. Gotta add this to my small list of bad reviews (so far). 

How could you do this to me? I was on a roll. I thought nobody could ruin pho for me... I guess I just got lucky before. I got the chicken pho... the meat I already expect to be a little bland and I'm not crazy about the texture the way they cook it... but at least it wasn't too dry. But the broth! I hear it said and it is true! IT SHOULD STAND ON ITS OWN! All others have...sadly this one did not. I had to toss in tons of hoisin and basil and sriracha... it was one of those "I'm cold, this will warm me to the core" moments... and I was let down. 

*tear
author: Marcy F.

description: I don't care if their service sucks, I'm addicted to the vegetarian Vietnamese crepe!!!  What could be wrong with wrapping fried dough in crisp table salad.
author: Miriam S.

description:
Location: There are two store fronts at their Mission location. The 16th Street location is very small. If you want to spread out, enter on Valencia. The decor is nothing special but that's definitely not why you'd eat here, the food is the draw!

The food: This was my first time eating Vietnamese and it was delicious. We ordered the Vermacelli, Lemon Grass Chicken, and Garlic Noodles. The flavors were interesting, the chicken was good, and the vegetables were fresh. Every dish that I saw being served looked awesome. I look forward to try new dishes (through take-out, I don't see myself returning to eat at the restaurant because of the service).

Service: I wish I could give a fully positive review of this restaurant but the service was really disappointing. When I arrived at 5:30pm on a Tuesday the restaurant had numerous empty spots and the server asked me to wait for my party (I was waiting for two friends). I understand the policy but  when the restaurant is almost empty, it feels a little rude. The same server pressed to take our order. As we verbalized that we weren't ready, he was turning away before we could get the words out. Clearly his priority was pushing people in and out. The table next to us was a two-top and the customers had apparently been there for two hours. Let's not forget, the restaurant was barely full and it was 5:30pm on a Tuesday. The server was SO rude to the customers and kicked them out. These were two quiet ladies sipping Diet Cokes after their meal. I have never seen anything like that at all. As they left quietly he continued to berate them, pointing out the video camera and yelling as they left. I swear, these were two quiet ladies in their 40s just hanging out after their meal. They didn't argue with the server, even as he was yelling behind them. I've never seen anything like that before. For this reason I will consider take-out here well before I consider returning to table service.
author: Eliz M.

description: A vegetable pho that's tasty. Yay.
author: Jack K.

description: Lemongrass Pork Vermicelli bowl was delicious. THe pork was so delicious and the imperial rolls were excellent, not greasy and very fresh. Our server was hilarious and sweet and the food came out very quickly. I am looking forward to going again to try something new!
author: Thomas K.

description: Been here three times now. I love this place. Friendly staff, some of the best Pho I've had. Good prices!
author: Ryan O.

description: I've been in that restaurant about 50 times in 5 years and every time the food is soooooo good!! I always get the seafood noodle soup and the rolls. My husband is a fan of the seafood sizzling and the special clay pot!! The food is pretty cheap for it's quality. I dont think they have more then 2 or 3 servers over there. Every time we go, it's always the same one:-) He always gives us 1 or 2 thai teas for free:) yummmmm!! You definitly should try that spot... Really worth it:)
author: Christine L.

description: Fresh ingredients meet a simple atmosphere, very simple, and yet you feel at home.  I've been six or seven times, each greeted by the same gentleman who then waits on many of the tables.  He's consistently warm.  The only aspect better is the tasty food.  A real vegetarian's delight, not to mention inexpensive.
author: Patrick B.

description:
So here's the deal. I get out of work at 5, I run an errand or I go to the gym or what have you, before I know it its 8:12 and I am feeling lazy and hungry and my usual thing is to grab a burrito in the mission, but, damn, I love my burrito and all but it gets to be a bit too much after awhile...

SO. Here's my new thing:
I go to sunflower and I order the #28(vermicelli with imperial roll and beef) and a number 4, fresh spring roll with chicken.
I take it home and divide it up into three meals.
Then I eat my half chicken roll, mmm, fresh mint! and My #28, red meat to die for, fresh cucumber and lettuce and carrots and some sort of spicy love I cant identify but I am obsessed with.

Even eating only 1/3 I'm completely full, PLUS its all so fresh and crunchy and healthy and low fat, PLUS I have 2 more meals of love waiting to go into my tummy PLUS they are always really nice, very trustworthy about leaving Peanuts out of whatever I order due to my allergy to such.

Fabulous. Just fabulous.
author: Ellen S.

description:
How is it that I have heard about Sunflower for nearly every single person in San Francisco and ye when I finally came here, the restaurant was practically empty? Do you think that they have so few seats to push people into the take out route? 

Anyway, I really like their pork, noodles, and friend imperial roll dish - it was delicious. I sample several of the hot soups and they were all quite delicious. Nothing blew me away - good hearty traditional Vietnamese.
author: Alicia J.

description:
This restaurant always confuses me why there are 2 doors with 2 addresses but the SAME kitchen.  Estoy muy confidido!

Regardless, the times I've been here with a group it has been easy to get a table and the waiter is super attentive.  He wears a sparkling belt and serves me with a smile.  

The bo loc lac (shaken beef) is alright, slightly overcooked but good flavors.  Curry chicken has excellent flavor.  My favorite is the pan fried rice noodles and all the vermicelli dishes w/imperial rolls are sooo tasty! My friend ordered the pho w/no cilantro and ended up with just broth, noodles and beef.  He said it was good but put his own spices in.

It's a good food, friendly and makes great leftovers!
author: Christina C.

description:
1. Ginormous Shrimp Spring rolls (fresh) I havent seen them this big Ever.

2. Fast Service.

3. Pho tasted okay, not the best. But For a Friday night at 10:45. They earned half a star for being open that late.
author: Larry L.

description: Although I've only been here once, I had a great experience here; the food was great, service was fast, and the prices were very reasonable.  Our fun eccentric waiter was very entertaining and made us laugh throughout our experience.  Def going to be back
author: daniel p.

description:
We go here A LOT, it's so delicious and having someone fall all over themself to keep you hydrated is a nice time. I always get the Vietnamese coffee even though I don't drink coffee, something to do with a cup of sweetened condensed milk .... drool.
Also, the fresh spring rolls are some of the best in town, I can't go to Sunflower and not have them. Had almost everything on the menu thanks to the family style tradition and I don't think I've ever been disappointed by a dish.
author: Colleen B.

description:
I haven't eaten too many dishes from here because I always end up getting my faves -- shaken beef, garlic noodles and vegetarian curry. I think it's the best place to catch dinner in the area of 16th/Valencia without breaking the bank. Also, service is prompt and only a couple blocks from 16th Street BART. 

It really hits the spot for that craving for garlic noodles!
author: Elsie M.

description:
Getting past the Starbucks-like oddness of having duplicates of the same restaurant just around the corner from each other, there is some mighty fine addictive eatin' at whichever one you choose. Personally, I prefer the spaciousness of this location. The imperial roll/vermicelli meals are a delight AND a bargain. Plus that one waiter guy is so cheery, I feel that I absorb some of the cheeriness. I'm pretty introverted when out alone, but when he comes over to ask how everything is, I get all smiley "It's SO GOOD!" 

And it is SO good when you regularly leave a restaurant feeling full, cheery and only slightly lighter in the wallet.
author: jessica s.

description:
Ate some pretty good Vietnamese there tonight. The wait staff at 9PM on a Sunday were surprisingly cheery and cool.  The food also came out promptly and in huge portions (more than I could've ever had eaten), which they gladly wrapped up for us at the end of the meal. 

+1 point b/c the server dropped off a huge pitcher of water for us to keep on our table (as well as also making his rounds and topping off our glasses). I know it's a small thing, but when you're thirsty it's a godsend.
author: Mike S.

description:
Shaking beef is the cat's pajamas! So tasty and tender. I ended up devouring 2 servings of rice since I didn't want to let a drop of deliciousness escape my lips before leaving the table. The tofu and veggies were average, but I will be back again to try the fried rice and the imperial rolls! 
Service is a bit shoddy, but then warms up quickly. Don't expect fine dining and you won't be disappointed.  
**temporarily out of beer and wine when i went.....**
author: Stacy T.

description:
Truly a diamond in the rough!

Came here tonight with a friend...  I'm still recovering from the flu and thought soup would hit the spot!  It certainly did here...

I ordered a Vegetarian-noodle soup...  5 minutes later, this ENORMOUS bowl with veggies shows up.  Only $7!  My friend had a beef stew and after I sampled it, which I was in the mood for beef  ;-)  Their hot sauce was also amazing..  None of this gringo-caliber stuff you get all the time...  But sauce that will wake up taste buds that have been dormant for years.  Hot, but great.  Heck, they even had hotter sauces available  8-|

It's a really cute place where you can chat up with whoever you're there with and the surrounding neighborhood isn't too bad either.  It starts to get really busy after 6:30pm.  Service was 'okay', but hey, if you're outwardly friendly to them, they return the kindness.  Good peeps!

$20 for two big-ass soup bowls, a chai-tea?

I'll definitely be back...
author: R G.

description: I heard a lot of great things but I was not thoroughly impressed. My co-worker and I had dinner after work. We shared the vegetarian spring rolls. Not too bad. I like their peanut sauce, but it didn't have a good balance of the hoisin sauce. I ordered the Vegetarian Imperial roll Vermicelli bowl. They give you a LOT of food. But the Imperial rolls were not good at all. I pretty much ate everything else and was very full.
author: Kathleen T.

description: So lately I've become obsessed with Pho soup. I was introduced to it about a year and a half ago, and became more and more hooked on this as the months gone on. I've been to seven Pho restaurants in the Bay Area, and this one has the worst quality in meat, and the most oily broth. One positive attribute at Sunflower, was the generous amount of fresh basil and lime for the soup which was a pleasant surprise. This place sucked pretty hard though, and we left smelling like fried good.
author: Melody H.

description: Very popular place!! We ate in the 'annex' which is right around the corner from the original location. Small and cozy place. We were able to score a table in the corner. I had the seafood noodle soup. I burned my mouth a few times!! I was just really eager and hungry. I felt very satisfied after my large bowl of soup. Friend ordered chicken and imperial rolls over vermicelli noodles mmmm! If you are in the mood for good Vietnamese food at a no fuss type of place then come here. I wish I lived closer so I could go more often.
author: Adriana G.

description: I've heard a lot of good things about this place but had never been here before til yesterday.  I had the vermicelli w/ BBQ & imperial rolls.  It's hard for any restaurant to live up to my beloved Bayon in Stockton, CA (I know, right!) but this restaurant did a good job.  The service was fast and friendly and my guy & I had a good laugh over the "Hung Phat" placard above the register in the kitchen... not sure if this is the real name of one of the owners or a joke.  Either way, it made me laugh and if it really is your name - well rock on!  I took half of mine to go since it was so filling & the owner even brought me fresh vermicelli and nuoc mam to-go - major points for that, I've never had that happen before.  All in all, fast & delicious, I will definitely come back next time I'm near 16th & Valencia (which is a lot ;p)
author: Suzanne V.

description: Great options for Vegetarians, tasty lemongrass eggplant!  The food is very clean and fresh.
author: Katie L.

description: I'm not a big fan of cilantro, fried stuff or pho, so I don't frequent too many Vietnamese places. I really enjoyed Sunflower though. Lots of choices, fresh flavorful food and SUPER cheap. I got the shrimp with spicy garlic green beans for $7...that kinda thing is usually at least $11 at most places. It was super garlicy-gingery and delicious. I also tried some of the vegetarian soup which was unlike any other Asian soup I've had, filled with fresh veggies with a complex, almost sweet broth. Their lunch specials are $8 for a crazy amount of food, entree, soup, spring roll, rice & cabbage salad. Plus, lots of good veggie options. I shall return.
author: Lauren T.

description: The food is good, the portions large, and the prices legit.  It seems crowded here all the time, so they're definitely doing something good.  But unlike pretty much every other vietnamese restaurant I've ever been to, you have to wait too long after you order your food to get it.  It was bizarre.  Maybe I've been spoiled with nearly instant gratification at every other place, getting my food within seemingly minutes of my order. But here, we were waiting a long time.  Too long... my stomach had started eating itself.  But the food itself was good.  The pho was big with a hearty broth and my crepe was filled with so much deliciousness, even though it was too crunchy on the outside.  I'll definitely come back simply for location and convenience, but I hope it's more speedy next time.
author: Jenn H. H.

description: Let it be known that the vitriol I released on Yelp! earlier today in regards to Slow Club was served back to me in the form of disappointing Pho. I didn't know such a thing existed...until I tried Sunflower Restaurant's seafood Pho. Just know that the "seafood" in the soup is basically all fake and pre-frozen...including processed fish cake. Yup. Gross.
author: Liane G.

description: Sunflower has shown me a new world of bad Vietnamese food that I never knew existed.
author: Paul K.

description:
The food here was terrible.  Who knows, maybe I caught them on a bad day, but I ordered the "five spice chicken" lunch special, and it really should have been called the "tastless slab of low quality chicken parts".  The spring roll and soup served alongside were mediocre.

Having lived in Minneapolis (huge Hmong population), I know both good and bad Vietnamese restaurants.  This is worse than any of the bad ones there.  The food here was one star, in my opinion.

I gave this place two stars because the waiter was really nice, and when he saw that I didn't eat much of the food, he offered to get something else for me and was very nice about it.  I politely declined, and I tipped him well.
author: Mike F.

description:
I love vegetables. I love soup. This place has a great vegetable soup, it's cheap, and the service is quick.

On the down side, the fresh spring rolls could be better. They're a bit on the boring side. 

For a cheap, healthy, fast meal with friendly service, it's awesome!
author: Jen M.

description:
This place is really good for a quick Vietnamese food fix.
I really like their fresh spring rolls with shrimp and the pork and shrimp salad with chips is excellent.

Other good items here includes the fresh steamed fish and the enormous crepe. Yum !

Spoke to one of the waiters (the bigger one) and he said he has worked there for every day for eight years now to save up to buy his house. I have been there 5-6 times and he has always been there so I guess he may really be...
author: Rich S.

description:
Sunflower is a basic Vietnamese restaurant, but it always feels like a bit of a treat to go there. It's one of those places that's so good you don't want to go too often and spoil it.

The Sunflower around the corner on 16th actually has the most amazing dish between the two locations: giant tiger prawns (truly massive). At the one on Valencia I stick to the staple fried imperial roll and vermicelli. Great flavor, well-constructed rolls, and fresh veggies. The table servers are great. I am typically greeted with, "why hello young man!" They rock.
author: Blake E.

description:
totally an awesome and delicious spot. I'm glad Debbie Y. knew about this place!!!!

Update:

Vermicelli is really good. I love the dumplings. The lemongrass tofu actually had taste of lemongrass. Imperial rolls are to amazing.
author: Anita C.

description:
I go here at least twice a week. I know, I should cook at home more but its on the way home and I am in love with the SunFlower Prawns. There are actually 2 restaurants, one on Valencia, which has the "overly friendly" waiter and his quiet sidekick then htere is the one on 16th with the no-nonsense waiter. Both are great but the one on 16th makes your clothes smell like shaken beef as this is where the kitchen for both restaurants is. 

If you order take out I suggest waiting for it on the sidewalk to save your clothes. Also, the old man behind the register can be a bit honery so watch out for him...

Best dished are the fresh spring rolls with shrimp, the vietnamese potstickers, shaken beef and sunflower prawns. For soem reason the coke tastes super fresh there too.

WORD!
author: A W.

description:
I didn't see one asian person in a place populated by art school drop out hipsters and a bit over priced Vitnamese food. 

there are better and cheaper places than this. esp. in sunset.
author: Derek Alistair J.

description:
You know that you have found a good thing when you find yourself driving from one end of the city to the other just to pick up an order to go!

my favorites are the garlic noodles, five spice chicken, the imperial rolls, the prawns, the sweet and sour catfish soup.....Oh my.......
author: Jeannine V.

description:
Pho Sho!

I like Pho. Vegetable Noodle soup is great. I love the extra veggies on the side to add, the hot sauce, the sweet sauce, and the spring rolls, and the beef.

Sunflower is a staple of cheap Vietnamese food in the city. I love to go here on an overcast, chilly day. Get a big bowl of soup, spice it up and warm my belly. 

I just recently tried the #38 on the menu...rice noodle fried with chicken and veggies and it was fantastic....very similar to Chinese hong-kong style chicken  chow mein, with the fried noodles.

Oh yeah, and its really cheap.
author: Jimmy L.

description:
The pot stickers are one of my favorites!! The spring rolls are pretty good also. Pretty much everything is in the $7-$10 range. My main course was the chicken and imperial roll vermicelli. While the chicken was pretty good, the imperial roll was more chewy than crispy. 
They also couldn't serve any alcohol - some problem with their liquor license, so it was Thai iced tea, instead of tsing tao.
The service was fast, attentive and friendly. 
On the whole I give it 4 stars, but I think I would get a different main dish. I'd like to get the BBQ pork next time, which I've been told is fantastic.
author: Russ C.

description:
