Just like the review on the window of the restaurant says about this place, "The Best Vietnamese Food in the Mission". Let's face it, there isn't any good Vietnamese food in the Mission to truly represent for good Vietnamese food in the Mission and this wouldn't qualify to set an example..

Food comes out slow, but the workers are very nice.
author: Dao C.

description:
Actually 1 star for the pho (ugh)
3 stars reserved solely for the crispy rice ball appetizer (nothing else on the menu)

Before my "living in the Avenues" days, I sauntered into Sunflower for pho. I didn't remember much, except it was totally forgettable -- bland and unexciting.

Of course time heals all wounds (and sins), and on a totally desperate night to get some beef pho in my Mission neighborhood, I decided to give Sunflower another go, especially since I couldn't remember what I didn't like about their soup anyways. Well... NOW I remember.

Let me preface this to admitting that I am totally spoiled by great pho joints back home, my ex-boyfriend's Vietnamese mother (a great cook), and those years of pho in the Avenues and now the Tenderloin aka Little Saigon. 

I was disappointed by a number of things:
1. You can only order one cut of meat -- namely "tender beef." No tendon, no tripe, no brisket, no beef ball. Just small strips of beef, not larger, paper thin slices, barely swimming in the bowl.
2. Soggy noodles. Perhaps I got a rogue bowl, but damn those noodles were too, too soft for my liking.
3. The soup did not arrive piping hot. If you serve soup, please serve it hot! This may explain my soggy noodles, which I imagined were waiting around for service, while slowly sponging up the broth.
4. The broth again. It was meh. A whatever broth. Just -getting-by type of broth. I couldn't pick up much essence of seasonings, or soul of beef or pork or whatever. I'm convinced part of the lost taste was due to the broth temperature. And here I circle back again to meh broth and soggy noodles.

So thumbs down on the pho for me. Mind you this is based on the beef pho, and I can't say I'll be back to try the chicken, but... I did have something very tasty here which I would come back for: a crispy fried rice ball filled with pork and glass noodle. It was absolutely delicious! The rice balls are about the size of meatballs with a super crunchy rice-cracker exterior, and savory filling. I loved the sensory pleasure of this dish -- the toasty crunch, yummy pork and noodle interior, cut with the sweet, salty, sour and fishy dipping sauce. Will definitely return just to order these, but am skipping any soup or noodle dishes entirely.
author: Antoi C.

description:
The vegan options rock!  Love the food here - it may not be authentic, but yummy - love the veggie imperial rolls over bun....

Have not had the service issues, but usually go during off hours....
author: Melissa G.

description:
"Hello Young Mans!"

I love this place, I love the food, I love the wait staff... 

Everything I have had here is amazingly good, but if you're not feeling well and want something hot, pass on the pho and get the hot and sour fish soup... now that's a real treat.
author: Darren R.

description:
I don't know how anyone in their right mind can choose one thing to eat while desperately hungry in San Francisco. While trucking around the city on foot we must have passed a thousand restaurants from each corner of the world. We ended up passing Sunflower by a couple blocks and ran all the way back. 

There was one open table that JUST got cleared, and we swooped on it. The place was packed so we knew it had to be a great place to get some food. Excited, we got our menus and made out choices and were then greeted by the coolest waiter ever. 

Friends and I ordered: Vermicelli with Imperial Rolls, Lemon Grass Beef with rice, and Sunflower Prawns with Garlic Noodles. The Imperial rolls were delicious with a great garlic flavor. The beef was wonderfully marinated and tender, but the Sunflower prawns were freakin amazing! A special spicy chili sauce is spilled over the shelled jumbo prawns that lay atop garlic noodles. The most amazing flavors came out of that special sauce.. OMG! 

Anyway.. in conclusion. The place had fabulous food, excellent staff, huge portions, and for extremely reasonable prices. Make sure you get there at the right time or else you will be standing outside waiting for a table with 30 other people like there were when we left.
author: Cheeks L.

description:
Wow. Huge portions of very good food for very cheap prices. We (just my husband and I here) ordered an appetizer (fried spring rolls), a soup (something vegetarian with cellophane noodles) and two entrees, and the waiter had to relocate us to a table for 4 to accommodate all of the food--that's how large the plates are, and the servings fill the plates! The fried rolls were wonderful: packed with vegan goodness, and easily twice  the expected size (they looked like small burritos). The soup was good, but my husband felt that they'd skimped on noodles proportionate to the veggies and broth. But not to worry, because the heap of pan-fried veggie-topped noodles we'd ordered was the size of a small housecat! Plenty of leftovers to go around, and I think the grand total was $36. 

We are definitely coming back here!
author: Ramon E.

description: Friend and I felt like pho after work. And I'm usually not a pho person, because no pho place will ever taste as good as mom's!! But this was 1 of the few places that offered vegetarian pho for my friend. OMG, they loaded hers up with so many fresh veggies. I was a bit jealous. Mine, was delicious. It wasn't all fatty and greasy like most places I've tried. So, we'll definitely stop by. Oh, and the waiter was a slightly bigger maybe Vietnamese guy. He was just too cute for words! I'm sure we play on the same field, but everything from his demeanor to his posture had me cracking up. Makes up for having to stand around in the middle of walking traffic just to get a seat.
author: Lola D.

description: Easily the best vietnamese for your buck. I have been here numerous times with my boyfriend and we absolutely love it. Not only is the food delicious, but you leave feeling full sans the ingestions and full stomach that accompanies  a full belly. For 10$ we split the appetizer combo. It includes a generous portion of lemongrass beef, imperial rolls, and bbq shrimps over a bed of vermicelli noodles. The noodle soups are also very generous and delicious! I prefer sitting on the 16th street side as it gets more sunlight.
author: Selvi H.

description: Place is always packed! and there's a reason.  Besides the reasonable price and great portions, this is one of the best vietnamese restaurants i've tried.  With many variety and unique dishes, I come back at least once every 2 weeks.  Try their garlic noodle prawns and spring rolls.  Delicious!
author: Francis L.

description:
I've been eating at Sunflower for a few years now and I still haven't found another vietnamese restaurant to beat them for bbq beef with imperial roll.  I can't remember if the price has changed since 2003 or so, but you still get tons of food for your money.  My recommendation is find someting you like and they do well and stick with it.  It's not a place that I'd say has "range" on the menu, but the soup bowls and appetizers are solid.

Plus, call me a little too comfortable with stomach disorders, but these guys just barely getting by on health scores is endearing.  Case in point:  I took my girlfriend there when we first met with only one caveat - "honey, don't look for... problems."  Sure enough, when she moved the sauce trolley on the table a little critter shot out from underneath and she hasn't gone back since.  Ha!  

That just tops the time I saw them cutting string with scissors and then using the same pair to cut a fish head.  Multi-tasking at it's best if you ask me!
author: joe z.

description: Food so fresh, so local organic lovely, so special-order savvy.. Renders this farmers mkt maven eclipsed by satisfaction. No reason I can report to skip it, assuming you find parking (ok, reaching for a bone ;). Mission foodies of all walks: disappointment is highly unlikely and.. (wait for it..) potentially suspect.
author: Rachel S.

description: This is a standard fall-back for a good meal when I'm in the Mission and hungry and don't want to make a big deal out of it. You can dine quick and informal at the 16th Street spot, or go around the corner to the slightly fancier location, especially if you're with friends and want to sit at a bigger table.
author: Jaina D.

description:
The beef pho was really good and so were the imperial rolls. The prices and portions are truly user friendly which explains the wait even at 10pm. 

I can see why people gave the garlic noodles such rave reviews, but it was a little too greasy for my taste. To be sure, it's really good when eaten ins small amouns but it's too greasy to be had in full. I ate less than 1/3 of it and was able to eat it in large part because I had it with the pho stew to wash the grease down. Maybe the addition of some vegetables would help it become more palatable.
author: John Paul H.

description: The restaurant was packed.  After a short wait we were seated and the food and service was very quick.  Everyone loved their food and the price was right!
author: Lexi F.

description:
Great value. If you're in the neighborhood just step around the moustached, plaid shirt wearing hip kids (and that's just the women) and get your arse in here...if you're with friends, great, but if its a solo visit at dinner just plonk down at the counter inside the 16th st entrance and be entertained by the crazy chaos open kitchen. Its great...pyro poetry in perpetual motion...
Great grub though....spicy green beans....noodle soup...mmmmmm and then afterwards you can step into Blondies next door on the Valencia side for a martini and an easy barfight with a fashion victim. Three thumbs up.
author: fergaldo f.

description: This is probably my favorite Vietnamese joint in the city. I could eat their vegetarian Vietnamese salad EVERY DAY. I actually had it for lunch AND dinner last night. It's fairly simple: lots and lots of shredded cabbage, carrots, mushrooms, baked tofu and that delicious vinegar and chili pepper sauce on top. I add a little Rooster Sauce to bring up the heat, then it's perfect! YUM! They also have a fantastic vegetarian noodle soup that can feed you for like, three meals! All of their portions are huge and they are really inexpensive. LOVE this place! And, once again, WALKING DISTANCE!! Hooray!
author: Susie D.

description: If you haven't eaten here you've been missing out! Great service and even better food!! If you come here definitely get the Sunflower Garlic Noodles with Prawns!!! *drools*
author: Christina T.

description:
I ate the leftovers the next day.  And I rarely do that.  (I claim I will, but then I think that they won't taste as good heated up a la microwave, so I just throw them out.  Its like taking restaurant food on a vacation.)

Plus, the waiter was such a queen, it was fabulous.  He gave me good tips on where to buy bamboo too!
author: Hannah N.

description:
Sunflower is really delicious and very inexpensive.  Their Pho is what I always go for, and I always conveniently forget how filling it is and order appetizers as well, like the spring rolls (fresh not fried.)  Their shaking beef and lemongrass beef are also really delicious.  I love the laid back feel of the place, even though it gets really crowded and can be a bit minimalistic (nothing fancy here!)

A definite Mission must.
author: Amy H.

description:
Awesome food, awesome prices, super friendly staff.  They get extra credit (an invisible half star i guess) because they let me in and fed me even though i came barging against the locked door with my two midwest parents right behind me, when they were trying to close (for the lunch to dinner cleanup/break.)  

The springrolls and thai iced tea were good, but the vietnamese crepe was scrumptious, and huge.  Any kind of food you roll up in lettuce and eat with your hands is pretty fun, but this was just awesome, with the hot omelete/crepe filled with whatever amount of sizzling bean sprouts and  mint and carrots and sweet dipping sauce all rolled together in one.  The garlic eggplant and curry vegetables were really great, too.  Big servings and enough left over to box up and take home!  One of the best deals for great food!
author: Today Y.

description:
Wow...never have I had such flavorful Vietnamese food at anything close to these prices. The Catfish claypot was a delight, and the lemongrass tofu gave a whole new meaning to lemograss and tofu :)

Highly recommended...
author: Nikhil B.

description:
This is a neighborhood comfort food joint for me; the four stars goes somewhat to the usually decent and sometimes excellent food but mainly I like the owner (Michael) calling me by my first name when I walk in.  

One night I was kicking it with a friend real easy and we ended up talking at our table until after the restaurant closed.  As we left Michael handed me a bag of my favorite rolls as a good night gift.   Another time, I was taking my order to go and instead of the veggie rolls I had ordered they had mistakenly given me the shrimp rolls...when I came back two weeks later, Michael handed me my order and said, "No charge Coleen, last time we gave you the wrong item..."

Talk about class.

The beef pho, or beef noodle soup, is almost always great.  (If it comes to the table less than piping-hot--in my eight years here it's only happened twice--politely ask for it to be taken back.)  I get it to go when I'm sick (they don't deliver, alas).  

If I'm on the run, I'll stop by and pick up a set of fresh spring rolls (the vegetarian ones are super yummy, with tofu and seasoned veggies sauted and warm in the wraps--the regular shrimp vermicelli rolls are a bit blander but still good).  Fairly healthy, light eating on the go.

The lunch specials are great and cheap: get the grilled shrimp with vermicelli.  Oh, and the fried imperial rolls (with pork) are super heavy but highly addictive.  

This is a small, friendly joint with harried but kind-at-heart staff.  Last I heard they got rid of the desserts, though.  If you don't want to smell like the food, go through the Valencia Street entrance and sit there instead of going through the 16th Street entrace and sitting by the open kitchen.
author: Coleen B.

description:
For the misson, Sun flower is an pretty good vietnamese dining experience. 
Went there last night with some two of my buds. 

The good: Vietnamese pot stickers: a unique variation on fried rice dishes, interesting and tasty. Also the vietnamese coffee: some of the best I have had in the city.  Barbeque pork was very tasy and succulent.

The okay: the garlic noodles tasty but pretty easy to make me thinks. 
I was not particularly impressed with the fresh spring roles.

Overal service was good and the setting is okay. But I was a little perturbed by our waiter due to his wearing of latex gloves which he wore while clearing the table. I associate latex gloves with either the need to avoid disease or potentially hazardous biological or chemical materials. Did the waiter see us as a health hazard or the food. Latex gloves are tacky and a big no no in my book. -1 star for this.
author: Christopher R.

description:
Ya the food is good! 
Any time I am in the city it is a struggle where to go, but Sunflower wins 38% of the time. It is always good and always fresh.
PHO PHO PHO, PHO PHO well and everything else...
author: petra g.

description:
OK so the hype of this place was high with appropos expectations BUT....perhaps it was b/c it was a sunday night...dunno. Nontheless I wasn't overly impressed.
Decent food but not amazing. Prices were ok but not great

Coi Cuon (fresh spring rolls with shrimp)
Bun Thit Nuong
Spicy Green Beans
and Cafe Sua (iced v'nese coffee)
1 side order of rice 
ALL FOR 29 bucks before tip(???) 
NOT A BARGAIN. IN THE LEAST.

i may go back 1 more time to check out the Lemongrass Chicken that gets good airplay here or the tofu dishes but those dishes above are some of my staples (except Pho whihc i usually also like to try as well (and hence I'll order that if I go back) ...

I'll give it 3 stars as a bit generous. Service was friends albeit not particularly prompt ...FOOD is much better at PPQ's on 19th and Iriving and much cheaper too... SUNFLOWER YOU CAN DO BETTER.... I KNOW IT... (sigh)
author: A K.

description:
Decent Vietnamese food in a mostly hole-in-the-wall setting with somewhat grumpy service. Really generous portions, though, and it was certainly tasty enough.

If you're walking around for a quick lunch or dinner, you're hungry, and you like Vietnamese fare, it's an easy choice, for sure. There will be something on the menu for anyone. And you probably won't have to wait for a seat.
author: Matt M.

description:
Nice simple place to grab some Vietnamese food.  Great place to go when the weather is cold.

Tried the pho it was pretty good, though I wish they would have put in more beef slices.

Tiny place so if you go around normal lunch or dinner time there might be a little wait.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
SF Food Inspection Score: 94

Two words: LUNCH SPECIAL!

Prawns, rice, soup, salad, and veggies for $8?!?!?!

Hells yes!
author: Kristina C.

description:
The food was yummy and the prices are right, but we saw three bugs crawling on the wall over the course of one hour.  Ew!

We had the Five Spice Chicken, with lots of anise (delicious, especially for those who enjoy licorice/anise flavor!), as well as the flat rice noodles with veggies.  Good for comfort food.  

They're not serving beer and wine at the moment.  I think they lost their liquor license, because they definitely had beer stocked - just weren't serving it.
author: Ann F.

description:
I've been a regular diner, and have sung this place's praises in recent years. We returned last night to a full house and long queue, so I presume its popularity is not in question.

I have noticed however a subtle degradation in quality of the food lately (new chef? new "economy" choices?)  

The Imperial Rolls had been obviously made some time earlier and were stale and tough. (0 stars)

The Shaken Beef was definitely not up to standards. It was ok. (2 stars)

The Crab and Asparagus soup was insipid and tasteless. (0 stars)

The Garlic Noodles were clumpy and caked and we hardly touched them. (0 stars)

The Five Spice Chicken was sensational. (4 stars) If it weren't for the chicken the meal would have been a total disaster.

I am really not sure whether I will return to this place again. Given so many good choices in the City, I am going to have to forget this encounter, perhaps it was an off-night, let's hope so, but I am not so sure. By the way service was slooooow and disorganized. Trying to get a glass of water or a cup of tea took an act of congress to accomplish.
author: Marc K.

description: I probably eat here more than any other restaurant in the neighborhood and not just because it's inexpensive and less than a block from my apartment. Those are perks, but it's actually really good too. I stick to the vegetarian menu so I can't vouch for it as far as their meat dishes are concerned, but everything I have tried is great. There is small dining and pick up location on 16th and then around the corner on Valencia is the entrance to the bigger (but still not huge) dining area. Oddly enough, I'm not surprised to see such mixed reviews even though I like it here a lot. I can see that it wouldn't be for everyone, but if you're okay with a casual and decent dining experience, you won't have too many gripes.
author: Natalie R.

description:
This is not only my favorite Vietnamese places in San Francisco, but also one of my favorite restaurants as well. The food is always good, the portions are enormous, and the service is always friendly and fast. I've brought many people to this restaurant who loved it and goes back often.
Just be sure you come in with an empty stomach!
author: Hans H.

description:
Truly mediocre food.

 "Quirky, impetuous" wait staff quickly turned snarky and impatient when I actually needed something more than a bare minimum of service. 

Hands down the most bland pho I've ever had.
author: Frank H.

description:
You see the 2 stars and you're like "Oh great, another post-teen American hipster that's complaining because the waiter doesn't treat you like a flawless god."  Maybe...but I have my reason why I brought my 5 star review down to a 2.

My 5 star review from 2009, simply put:
"Good pho.  Go get some good pho.
Get beef, chicken's ok."

because it was.  For $7.50.

Now in 2013, before going into the price first (otherwise I will sound like a whiny little b****), the noodles are consistently stuck together, the broth more mediocre than before, the meat dried up a couple times looking like prosciutto, and you're paying $9.52!

For those of you that don't know, pho is a Vietnamese noodle soup that is very common to have for breakfast.  In another words, it's Vietnamese peasant food for nearly $10.  Sunflower has lost all its blossoms.


Pho in other locations that I recommend is Ti Vietnamese in SOMA, Turtle Tower (where ever they're moving), and.........heck, even some of the middle level pho places in Portola District.  Sadly my go-to pho place in the Mission has become a shriveled up scrotum.
author: Winton W.

description: This place has turned into one of my fav TO-GO food places to bring home after a long day at work... or on a rainy day. Inexpensive and your food is ready in 5-10 minutes. I usually get the Beef or Chicken PHO and I suggest adding the vegetables for the extra charge.
author: Albert Paris W.

description: This place is the grub! Better value if you get the lunch special, but it's a good day if you eat here. The 5 spices chicken and green chicken curry are great!
author: Kurt H.

description:
a bunch of my friends and i came here, on a tues night, and it was packed! we had to wait a good 45 minutes to eat at this cute little hole-in-the-wall.

it was very warm in there, i felt just like i was in vietnam...haha.

food was very decent, and cheap! can't go wrong there. it was slow service tho, and it took us a while to get food, and the check after. but all in all, it's cute and very affordable. their circa 1992 printshop menu is adorable as well!
author: Hannah L.

description: This was by far the rudest, most harrowing experience I have ever had at a restaurant hands-down!  The three of us sat down and were harassed into ordering about 30 seconds later.  Halfway through our meal, an older man comes over and takes half our plates.  As my one friend is not done eating, we cover the plate and let the waitor know this.  He comes back 12 seconds later and takes our water.  I am pissed at this point because I am a waitress and this service is appalling.  I get what can only be assumed as a stream of insults hurtled at me in Vietnamese and when I sit back down, we are amidst conversation and the young waiter comes over and starts YELLING at us. Full blown yelling at how we are going to sit there for 4 hours.  We had been there 1 hour and 15 minutes. (On a Monday night) with open tables all around us.  He continues to yell at us in front of the entire restaurant.  If he needed the table, which he didn't, asking would have been sufficient.  Needless to say, he ruined our dinner and I will never be coming back. If you would like to avoid being treated like utter shit for your money, don't come to Sunflower, not worth your time or money.
author: julie r.

description: pho is OK, not great (broth is off).  Shaking beef is slight better.  It's a level up from being a hole in the wall, but not by a ton.  And the people that work here aren't Vietnamese (not a bad thing, but I find that the Vietnamese people generally do a better job making Vietnamese food).
author: Tiffany C.

description: I come here for the Garlic Noodles, and to be called "young man". Both make me feel good inside.
author: Derek M.

description:
This place really produces some great dishes. One can chose from a quicker meal on the 16th Street side, or a more relaxed lunch on the hipper Mission Street side.  Cannot leave without trying their Vietnamese Potstickers. Please.

(alsogreatPho)
author: E.Mo. ..

description:
Full disclosure: I judge every Vietnamese restaurant by their bun--that delicious mix of vermicelli noodles, shredded lettuce, julienned carrots, maybe some bbq pork and imperial noodles with a mini bowl of fish sauce. 

Sunflower's bun rated okay except I really didn't like the noodles they used! Too stringy and starchy and it absorbed all the fish sauce. Boo! I couldn't get past it, and thus, only three stars for you.
author: Genevieve R.

description:
I've lived in the Mission for 10 years now and this place has always come through.  It used to be a good place to go to when Slanted Door was overflowing and now that Slanted Door is in the Ferry Building this place is a great place to go to period.

I love their Shaken Beef.  It is by far the best value on the menu.  Excellent flavor and the meat is oh so tender!  I like to have it with the noodles instead of the rice.  Also, their Pho is very tasty...!
author: Joe O.

description:
Had the shaking beef (the could slice the tomatoes thinner) and the roast chicken (dark meat rules), very decent. I think I liked the shaking beef from Mangosteen better, it's all good

Oh yeah I saw the "friendly" dude, hahah
author: xo x.

description:
I highly recommend the Vietnamese potstickers here -- they are amazing!  A nugget of flavorful meaty goodness surrounded by rice and deep fried.  Heavenly.   

The bun and pho are good, but not awe-inspiring.  The lunchtime BBQ pork plate is something else though.  Everyone at my table was wishing they had ordered it.  Very impressed to get a delicious canh chua here too with lunch. 

Service too has been sparkling every time I have been here.
author: saudade s.

description:
Always a good bet! Cheap, super tasty and a whole lot of value. Definitely one of the better Vietnamese restaurants I've been to.               

The Valencia St. location has a bit better ambiance/atmosphere than the 16th St. location directly around the corner...although they both serve the same menu. If you do go to the 16th St. side, be sure to take note of the music coming from a boombox still encased in it's original cardboard box. Somehow that was a pretty funny site to see while slurping hot Pho.
author: Autter Pop ..

description:
I had a "just OK" meal here.  I probably won't be back unless someone I am out with really has a desire to try the place or if I'm just really that tired of the other great options in the neighborhood.    

They (temporarily) aren't serving any wine or beer.  I'd probably give it a solid 3 stars if I could have enjoyed a beer with dinner.  

An out-of-towner (who, sweetly, thought this was the best vietnamese food he's ever had!) and I split an order of imperial rolls (not quite crispy or hot enough, but OK), lemongrass chicken (tender chicken, green beans were a tad undercooked, overall not very spicy but I doctored mine up with some Sricacha), and the best part of our meal: sunflower prawns.  There were 4 giant prawns and an enormous serving of buckwheat vermicelli noodles in this dish.  This plate stood out from the others- the prawns were (did I mention just how giant? I was thinking "How did the creature from Cloverfield end up on my plate?"  and: "Yay!") cooked perfectly and had a sweet/tangy/spicy sauce that I loved, but then the "prawn-to-noodle ratio" was kind of wack.  I had enough noodles leftover to feed a couple of hungry people later.   

And I did.
author: Conchita R.

description:
Great place for quick, good Vietnamese with a group.  Delicious veggie options and good Thai iced tea.  I've never waited for a table, but the service can be touch-and-go (servers and disappear for quite a while).  But the food is consistently delicious and the atmosphere is low-key and fun.  I love the lemongrass tofu with rice vermicelli noodles.  
The food is also quite reasonably priced, and there's always plenty for take-home leftovers.  Really tasty for breakfast the next morning!
author: Christy T.

description:
Jeeeeeez this place. 

 Looking for Fo one afternoon we wandered in here. Hoping for a warm welcome and a hot bowl of soup. 

 Instead we were left standing at the door for a good five minutes wondering if anyone was ever going to even acknowledge us as having entered the establishment.  When we were finally acknowledged and seated, we were promptly asked what we wanted by our perpetually in a hurry to be somewhere else host,and then half way paid attention to when the order was given. I remember thinking "was he even listening?" as he hurriedly ran to the other end of the restaurant.  
The food came out separately, my friends arriving first. She had ordered a "noodle soup" but apparently this one came without noodles. She asked nicely if she could have noodles added to her order, and this is where things got really interesting. 
Our host/server became extremely agitated with our table. Including stomping away, and  pointing at our table while yell talking at the cook.  I know its annoying to have to take an order back in to the kitchen, but come on..... you run a restaurant this cant be the first time this has happened? Your supposed to be prepared for this kind of thing. That's what you do.
My soup was still not out, and we sat waiting....and waiting ...and waiting for our soups. My friends soup arrived once again before mine. 

 Finally we both had food placed before us and were ready to eat. The soup was an entirely new experience. Large chunks of vegetables to big to eat comfortably. Thrown in a bowl with some noodles and a crap veggie broth.  If this is safe Vietnamese Ill take my chances elsewhere. 
When we weren't picking out the huge chunks of broccoli and whole hearts of cabbage from our soups, we were wondering where the condiments were. No chili paste, no pepper, nothing.  To boot when we tried to flag down Mr. speed racer our server he ignored us completely and flew right on by. 

 As the meal came to an end, we needed to pay. As you can imagine this took quite some time considering our server was ignoring us. 

 My friend got food poisoning and that pretty much sums up what I think of this place. 
 Wont go back. .... cant believe people actually hoard in here for food when there are so many other great restaurants in the city.
author: Charlie B.

description: Fresh, delicious & inexpensive.  One of my favorite places to eat!  Good for take-out too.  Lots of yummy veggies that aren't overcooked.  I've never had a dish here I didn't like - it's all quite good and consistent.  The service is pleasant, efficient and no-nonsense.  Yes, they will nudge you if you linger too long when there are people waiting.  Fair enough.  High turnover ensures they can keep their prices low.  Deal with it.
author: anneka i.

description:
we've had some wonderful vietnamese in SF and this wasn't one..
maybe cheap and plentiful but not vietnamese
you folks should go to in the tenderloin,,,now that's authentic!
author: jaime r.

description:
Seriously, why do people wait in line for this place?  Because it's "safe" Vietnamese?  I had a number of friends rave about Sunflower, so when I finally got the chance to try it, I was stoked.

Unfortunately, the meal had so much salt on it that I was bloated for the rest of the night.  But I had to smile and pretend I liked it for the sake of pleasing my friend.  I hate disappointing people when I don't like their favorite restaurants.  Go to Jasmine Garden if you want safe Vietnamese.

The upside was the service.  Great service, everything came out on time, and the servers were pleasant.
author: Melissa P.

description: It's decent authentic Vietnamese food. We usually order the garlic noodles with chicken which is a big portion you can share. The BBQ pork vermicelli with imperial rolls is good but sometimes the meat is fatty. The husband doesn't like eating south east Asian food but he enjoys these dishes here.
author: Mason M.

description:
Food here is good - especially like the crispy potstickers - but certainly not good enough to compensate for the poor attitude.

Service in the other hand is DEPLORABLE. Have been there three times now and the waiters always have attitude. They act like they are doing you a favor by serving you. Tch, Tch. The last time we went there, the waiter gave us bad attitude and then when the bill came he added a 20 percent tip - but only on the credit card bill, not on the original bill that came. He said that it was because we were a party of five. However that policy was not stated on the menu as is the norm at other restaurants that have this policy. Additionally it should have been on the first bill that came. Very dishonest.
author: Nick K.

description: This place is sick! Right on 16th where people tend to join hands. Good food, one of the best places in San Francisco to get vegetarian Pho. They're quick to seat you, take your order and have you out of there as fast as you wanna go. Def one of my spots
author: Dave M.

description: Best vermicelli I've had in a while, number 23 pork and imperial rolls... And a great lunch special price! Cheap at under $8. I'll definitely be back.
author: Julia K.

description:
Having eaten Asian food my entire life, I can tell you the Sunflower Garlic Prawn Noodles are amongst the top 3 most delicious noodles I have ever had my entire LIFE!  Go here for that dish if you like or even kind of like garlic.  They put in their special garlic chili sauce and it is one of a kind.  I literally get excited when we go here just for that dish.  

Also great: Imperial Rolls, Five Spice Chicken, Shaken Beef.  The place is small and the wait can be a bit rough sometimes but MAN, the noodles are AWESOME.  

As with any Asian restaurant: go for the food, not the service.  So all those people complaining about the service: get off your high horse and get with the program.
author: Andrew I.

description: Really good food, and really cheap.  Would definitely go back and is great for a group.  Friendly staff.
author: Alex P.

description:
Cheap. Delicious. Warm. Music playing from a radio that will surely get you singing along. If you go around the corner to the one on 16th, you will most likely get to eat faster, but the one on Valencia has a little more oomph to it in decor and ambience.

I suggest the vegetable pho. If you get chicken, you don't get all the veggies?!? And you can bet that you have guaranteed leftovers for lunch tomorrow.

Happy Belly!
author: J F.

description: Have only eaten the curry vegetables and vegetable pho (without tofu) here, but both were delightful.  As a near vegetarian, it is always exciting to find a place that offers vegetarian dishes that actually have vegetables in them.  The pho was so good, and was presented with a plethora of colorful veggies.  I have never before ordered veggie pho that arrived with broccoli, bell peppers, summer squash, button mushrooms, carrots, cabbage.  My favorite part about my meal here this evening was that the manager (I think) sent me home with a fresh young coconut on the house.  Now that is the kind of service I like.  Very nice waitstaff, even though they are busy.
author: Frankie S.

description:
Indeed, I am a huge fan. Whenever I have many guests and visitors in my house (and I do have many from Brazil!) and they ask me for some different and yummy food I take them there. Since the currency (Brazilian reais x dollars) doesn't help a lot, they love it even more cause it is cheap. 

There is a lot of creativity in the dishes, many tasteful sauces and is still the most authentic Vietnamese food I have ever had in SF. Try the tasty rice balls with prawns and lean pork in plum sauce and the delicious garlic eggplant. The brown rice is amazing and for some seafood try the seafood sizzling dish (my memory is very fresh since I just left the restaurant! ;)

I just didn't give Sun Flower a 5 star in this review cause I really think they are understaffed. The most active waiter there is very nice and friendly but it is just too much for him to handle alone, so you end up with some wrong dishes or waiting really long for just a glass of bear. But it is definitely worth the patience!
author: Camila E.

description: Before I say anything about this place, I just want to say THANK YOU for having vegetarian options!!! It's not every day you walk into a Vietnamese restaurant with vegetarian vermicelli (with vegetarian instead of fish sauce!). However! This place is all-in-all quite average. I sat in the corner of the restaurant and my view was..the corner of the restaurant. Hahah! Funny, but not very enjoyable for lunch. Service was quick, the vegetarian vermicelli was alright...it was warm though; typically the vermicelli I have is cold..? Anyway the portions are pretty decent size, except I got sick of it before the end :(. In it was carrots, mushrooms, tofu (not fried to crisp like usual tofu in vermicelli hahah), cabbage, etc. And the only time the waitress smiled at me was when I was leaving....at least she didn't pull the all-of-a-sudden hella nice "thank you soo much" when it was time to give tip. Ahaha. I didn't enjoy this place, but it did have quite a few (edible) vegetarian options, and..nothing terrible happened. Lol.
author: Betty W.

description: I swear by their garlic noodles. My friend Catlin loves the beef salad, the Vietnamese crepe, and the Vietnamese coffee. Tonight we had the honor of sitting next to two "proto-lesbians" while they discussed (and I kid you not) Mylee Cyrus, if Starbuck's "Tall" is actually an Italian spelling, and the mainstream music they listened to before they realized it was "uncool"... Oh, and about *HOW* lesbian they are to each other... It was quite entertaining. I think they may have been on a first date, trying to "out-lez" each other. How cute!
author: Sam A.

description:
I've never written a review. If the food is bad or service unpleasant, I write it off as a fact of life. 
And here I am, on Yelp swearing NEVER to go back to this place. The point? Blah food, and horrendous service. 
This is how it happened: 
- We arrived early for dinner and told the waiter that we had a party of 4 but only 2 of us were there now and we're willing to wait. He told us to sit straightaway. 
- 10 mins later, realizing that our 2 friends were not there yet (did he listen when we told him?) the waiter told us to leave our table. Which of course was silly so we just went ahead and order. 
- 15 mins later: friend no. 1 arrived. Our food came out, but our drinks did not. Friend no. 1 waved and asked and was short of dancing Zumba for attention. She didn't get a menu for another 15 minutes. 
- Another 15 mins: friend no. 2 arrived while friend no. 1 was struggling to eat pho without a spoon or the herbs that were supposed to come with it. We still could not get hold of a waiter so friend no. 2 gave up trying to order. 
- While we were still working on our food, some waiter left the check on our table, effectively rushing us out of a meal. 

We paid and decided to not tip, because they were terrible to us throughout. The waiters (suddenly there were 3 of them, all VERY attentive it seemed), confronted us about why we did not tip. We explained our disappointment in the service. They started screaming at us so we left. The last of our group was in the rest room, as she came out, she was seized by the same 3 men, screaming at her. 

We're not cheap. We understand that waiters don't get paid well and depend on tips. But that doesn't mean they are entitled to it. Tips, like goodwill, are earned.

The whole encounter left a bad taste in my mouth. I'd NEVER come back.
author: Penny L.

description: I ordered their lunch special...I think it was number twelve, with BBQ. Those imperial rolls are just so delicious, the soup is sweet and sour--but mostly sweet because of the pineapple--and oddly enough, ridiculously good. The mushrooms and tofu in the soup were all so very fresh and delectable. The barbecue was very good, very delicious. I did not expect much, but I enjoyed my meal immensely.
author: Christine S.

description:
This review is subject to change after I have the tossed beef.

But I went here for the first time last night and ordered the hot & sour catfish soup. My friends ordered some variety of Pho- beef or chicken, etc. They all felt that they got a big bowl of broth and some bean sprouts. But it was good broth they said. 
I feel like I got a decent portion of catfish in my soup, which I found to be very tasty. They also chopped in some bad looking tomatoes that tasted like they looked. 
One thing that really stuck out were the fresh vegetarian spring rolls. My budddy ordered them for the table and all 5 of us were enjoying them. Next time I go I'm going forn the tossed beef and the fresh veggie spring rolls.
author: Andrew B.

description:
Sunflower Prawns (over garlic noodles) are one of my favorite meals in town.  The Shaken Beef is super good too (but sometimes a little too salty).  Usually excellent service, unless they are slammed. 

Somehow, everytime I go here, the place is full, but I have never had to wait for a table.  Every time, it's like there is ONE table available. No more, no less.  Go figure...
author: Val U.

description:
cheap, super fast, healthy portions, super yummy food....

Can't Go Wrong!!!

update: i just recently tried the to die for catfish in blackbean sauce. i've changed my mind from hating fish!!
author: K K.

description:
Sadly, I am giving you one star for now.

I tried three dishes - one dine in, and two take out within a week and was not impressed by either.  Other diners at the table for our dine in experience had items that looked good, but I didn't try them myself.

The Veggie Curry I was unfortunate enough to order was watery and bland.  The Garlic Veggie  was nothing to write about, and the Fried Rice with Crab was in our delivery instead of what we ordered for take out and to be honest, it was very plain also.  So, until I risk it again, one star for you.
author: Alicia W.

description:
I like Sunflower, they're always nice to me and that bun shows up fast.
A little cramped, but I suppose that's why they have the white table cloths around the corner.

Last time I was by the window a deranged crackivore lurched up to the glass and began gesticulating and moaning like the walking dead.  I'm not complaining though, that's 16th and Valencia, it's not really the worst street of desperation and urban decay, yet the panhandlers seem especially prone to grand displays and pushiness.   Perhaps it's the out of town prey that shows up for Puerto Allegre & Blondies?

Sunflower's food is uniformly competent.  The beef and Imperial roll bun is good, fills me up and leaves me content.  The beef is really tender and rather well spiced (five spiced).  The Imperial rolls and the rest of the presentation are fairly unremarkable, but nothing's off.  All proper condiments are supplied, though sometimes the onions are insufficient.  It's a big bowl though, and its got a nice mass of shredded red leaf as the salad portion, and big slivered cucumber chunks.

I'm not saying Sunflower offers anything amazing, but it's good and uniformly so, which I'm starting to think is the best one can hope for in bun around SF.
author: Gustie L.

description:
Average. I like my vietnamese either dingy and delicious like Ao Sen in Oakland, or upscale and good like Le Soleil in San Leandro. This place is just average all the way around. 

Don't go out of your way.
author: Andrew L.

description:
Is it only me that thinks it's strange none of the people there speak vietnamese?  (see, vietnamese restaurant owned and operated by chinese people)

The food is pretty decent, though it's more "standardish" vietnamese food than anything spectacular.  If you like vietnamese, and are in the mood, you could do worse than this place -- but don't go out of your way to go here.
author: Daniel H.

description:
This place is great. You get a ton of food for not much money and the wait staff is really friendly. 

I had the bbq pork and spring rolls on vermicelli (bun). It was excellent! The pork was cooked perfectly - crispy on the outside but tender, which is pretty hard to do with thin strips. Well, maybe not hard if you do it all the time. The imperial roll had some really interesting flavors. Not your run-of-the-mill egg roll.  The only not-so-great thing was the greens - lettuce and cucumbers. Not the cornucopia of greens you get at other places.
 
The pho with beef is good, too.
author: Dana D.

description:
The food comes from the same restaurant as the 16th Street side -- they meet in the middle but offer extremely different ambiances (is that a word?).  I only go there for Vegetarian Soup (and I'm not even Vegetarian).  The ingredients are fresh and you get enough to share with one order.  

Try going for lunch and the prices are cut drastically -- a GREAT lunch idea!!
author: Shayne H.

description: Ok...totally love this place. They were nice to me when I was drunk in there and the food is awesome. I go here all the time, so I felt obligated to update my posting.
author: Katie Sue A.

description: Again, had take out from this joint. Garlic noodles with vegetables. Nothing special and nothing memorable and I don't understand why people are coming back to this place. Please wake up. Potrero Hill eating residents don't support restaurants that are meager in their service and taste.
author: Lord G.

description: I liked the food, but have not been back since the server was very rude to myself and my friend.  We met up for dinner and split a big dish of food + appetizer.  The total came to around $22, and there were plenty of open tables around us the whole time (we stayed about 1.5 hours).  It seems we overstayed our welcome, though, because the server kept asking to box up our food.  He plunked the check down on our table, refused to serve my friend a post-dinner tea, and shooed us out.
author: Lindsay M.

description: On a scale of 1-10, I rate Sunflower a Pho-sure. Damn good Vietnamese food at good prices. I can't believe how much food you get with some of their dishes - we ordered the sub-$8 fried egg noodle dish, and they brought it out on a plate the size of those serving trays you get in cafeterias.
author: Nick H.

description: Egads! This place is awesome. Even though I work in the FiDi it's worth the trip to the Mission to eat here during my lunch hour. Ingredients are fresh, price are cheap and the service are nice and FAST. Did I mention fast? Well, they are. I get back to my office within the hour. Okay give or take 5 to 10 minutes extra but then my office doesn't have a lunch Nazi.
author: Kathy T.

description:
+ Vegetarian noodle soup
+ Vegetarian salad
+ Spicy green beans (w/ scrumptious mushrooms)
+ Lemongrass tofu
+ Crispy vegetarian egg noodles
+ Fresh lemonade

it's my medicine
author: Tulip F.

description: We waited 20 minutes for our table, it was truly worth the wait!  Our waiter was in the weeds, he was taking care of at least 10 tables. . . with that said he did not falter!  Our food was delicious, fresh and rather inexpensive.  The crepes are delicious (especially).  Nothing fancy, but defiantly something I would go out of my way for!
author: Jeanine S.

description: This is one of our all-time favorite restaurants!  We compare every imperial roll to these.  I recommend #28 - beef vermecelli with imperial rolls. We have moved to the east coast and still visit every time we go to SF.
author: Don M.

description: Let's face it, Pho is soup for the soul and this place comes correct.  Had the imperial rolls which were really good and served scalding hot, just the way they should be.  Service was meh, but if you sit at the counter, then they can't ignore you.  Great place to go for Vietnamese on the run, especially during lunch.
author: Darren B.

description:
I love this place, one of my favorite places to eat "BUT ONLY AT NIGHTS". The night staff "two chinese/Vietnamese guys" are super cool! 
 You really need to eat on the Valencia side not the 16th street side. The restaurants are attached and look totally different but are in fact one in the same, just two different entrances and two different vibes. The Valencia side is much much much better. I recommend the # 28 if your alone. If your with someone I recommend the Cat fish in a clay pot, a big bowl of rice and the curry veggies and tofu. That would be enough to fill-up two adults. ENJOY IT!
author: Tim M.

description:
I'm actually shocked at how many positive reviews are listed here on Yelp for this place. I went last week... not my first time, but it had been awhile... and the food was decent, but the service was HORRIBLE. We were a group of six and the waiters were so rude it took us all by surprise. I won't go into all of the details, but suffice to say, we were all feeling quite uncomfortable and not enjoying our dining experience. 

I consider myself a strong tipper, but this was the first time in years where I was actually wanting to reflect the bad service in a bad tip... but as they handed us our check they said there was an automatic gratuity already added in for our large group so we were forced to give them a (I believe 17 or 18%) tip. I will never go back. 'Nuff said.
author: Claudine G.

description:
had the pork and imperial rolls with vermicelli noodles.  good, lots of fresh vegetables, but i've had better.

the vietnamese crepe, stuffed with bean sprouts, chicken, and shrimp was alright.  however not a lot of taste to it.

food is inexpensive, service was very friendly, cozy dining area.

i must come back to try their other selections.
author: Ethan L.
Linda C.

description:
This place is well priced and their Imperial Rolls are so good, I wanted some for breakfast this morning.
Sometimes a long wait, but it usually goes pretty fast.
And GOD Dammit do they have a huge bathroom. Just sayin'.
author: Sarah M.

description:
This is a good standby. Somehow - though there are zillions of places to eat in this neighborhood - we end up going here quite often. We are fairly indecisive, and don't know what we want for dinner. Someone says veggies, someone says noodles, and we end up at Sunflower.

The food is good - not insanely delicious, but quite decent. The portions are large and the prices are low. There are plenty of options, especially vegetarian.

Service is friendly. We've never had to wait more than a minute for a table and in most cases can usually walk right in and sit down, though the place is always basically full. Ambiance and decor is pleasant and comfortable.
author: Caitlin H.

description: I eat here once or twice a week, I just can't get enough! mainly because it's the only Vietnamese place where I take there word for it when they say the veggie soup has veggie broth. I recommend the lemon grass tofu, veggie noodle soup, and the brown rice, which is actually fragrant and a deep red color.
author: Amber K.

description: Nice American-sized portions if you know what I mean.  I'm no expert when it comes to Vietnamese food, but I do know what tastes good and Sunflower consistently hits the spot .  The lunch specials are a good deal and the dinner prices aren't bad at all compared to other frilly places. The imperial rolls and garlic noodles are my faves.
author: Andrea S.

description: Looking for a place to eat on a Friday night should be easy.  In fact, when you're in the mood for Vietnamese food and you're in the Mission, you should give this place a try.  I definitely recommend the 5 spice chicken and the seafood crispy noodles.  YUM!
author: Diana D.

description: I tried it. I was really looking forward to it because some foodie friends said it's their favorite Vietnamese place. It was just OK. I should probably try it again sometime but based on my first experience I haven't been that motivated to go back. Nothing at all was negative. I just don't have any particularly positive stories to share.
author: Kelly S.

description: Why fix it if its not broken, you often hear said. Maybe thats why I have never ordered anything besides the chicken noodle soup. Boring...I know, but every time I go to sunflower its cos Im in the mood for soup and after reviewing the menu each time Ive been there its always been #18 for me.
author: Vivek N.

description:
I've been going here about once a month since I moved to San Francisco a year ago and it has never disappointed me.

Oh wait, there were those few months where they couldn't serve alcohol, but THANKFULLY that dry spell is over.

I usually order the Beef Pho.  The only thing I don't like about the Pho is they have one size, and I can never finish it.  I guess that is not much to complain about.

A few other things that I specifically liked:

The Fried Tofu appetizer
Lemongrass Bean Curd
and of course the Imperial Rolls

This place gets packed everynight around dinner time so expect a little wait.
author: Adam C.

description: Okay so its a hole in the wall but their spring rolls are amazing from veggie to lemongrass beef. This place makes my favorite spring rolls ever!!! Also a big fan of their 5 spice chicken. Wow flavor. I normally order the vegetarian dishes they are great. Not a fan at all of their PHO, it leaves room to be desired. But for a super casual and inexpensive dining experience with good peps its awesome!
author: amy g.

description: Sunflower has become a personal ritual. Until my sister took me here and got me hooked like some kind of pho pimp, I had never had the desire to eat out alone. I have since gone to Sunflower on my own on several Sunday afternoons.  I have a meditation hour which includes the vegetarian pho. There vegetarian pho is much better than other vegetarian pho soups, they put in lots of different veggies and tofu. All the waiters are adorable especially the formal older gentleman who has real old fashion waiter manners. I also really enjoy the younger waiter who tends to be there at night. l actually love eating here by myself on a quiet sunday afternoon when it isn't busy inside. I sit alone and become one with my noodle.
author: Dana H.

description:
A few months ago I had an engagement in the city but was sick as a dog. I needed pho. This was the only vietnamese restaurant w/in walking distance from where I needed to be, so I had my lunch here.

Just 2 types of pho. Sad face. Beef, and....something else. I just remember beef because that's whta I ordrered. 

The pho is average. Nothing spectacular, with all the requisite fixins.

I did come back for the pork and garlic stirfry with brown rice. This isn't your run of the mill tan colored brown rice, but some hardcore purplish wild rice variety. The portion was a bit small for my taste but it was pretty yummy. 

The lunch specials look like one hell of a deal, with  a salad, a springrool, rice, and meat. Might be back to try that.
author: Polly F.

description: Waiter that has always been nice to me through a little hissy fit. It's all about the customer, buddy.
author: S D.

description: Super tasty surprise! Tiny cafe  with huge freshly prepared portions!  Yummmm can't wait tell next  snack there!
author: Dave V.

description:
I loved this place the first time I went there.  That said, I was so drunk at the time that I think I would have enjoyed it if they had served me oatmeal with ketchup.  So, I decided to give the place another go-around, and I must say I was impressed.

Lemon grass chicken was quite good.  Chicken spring rolls are the size of a burrito, so that's a pretty good deal too.  The shaken beef is also quite good, although it is beef and nothing else.  Even the most basic burger comes with a bun, some fries, and a pickle.  Couldn't they mix it up a bit?

The help was very, well..helpful!  Of course, when I got the bill, I understood why.  They charge you for each bowl of rice.  That's like an extra $1.20 right there that I hadn't budgeted for.  Okay, Mr. Sunflower, I'm onto you.  Of course, I see this as a business opportunity.  I'm going to open my own stand and sell bowls of rice for $1 to all people going into Sunflower.  Don't get me wrong --- I won't make as much money as the scary homeless guy across the street from Sunflower who "saves" public parking spots for you for a gratuity.  But hey, it's a start.
author: Dan H.

description:
1st visit... good & friendly service. Yummy food. Was surprised how big the appetisers were: we orederd the vegetarian imperial roll and the crepe, and those alone would've been enough for dinner for two. Of course, greedy us, we ordered the eggplant dish to share, which we couldn't finish. It actually tasted better as leftovers the next day! 
And another plus: the wine was cheap! :)
author: M L.

description:
Just you know so-so. 

It is cheap food it both senses of that word. Big potions. medium quality. I guess if lived in small rural town with only one Vietnamese restaurant I would be like Yeah lets go back Right Now! but in Sf? hmmm
author: Vasile S.

description:
it was good. filling. kinda tasty. 

not great. Vietnamese? i would say kinda. kinda not. 

will i go back? sure. did i expect more? yes. 

next time i will get the pho...
author: Art A.

description: I have to say, Sunfower is probably my favorite place in my hood. I LOVE the Pho, and even though the staff can be rude occasionally, SOMETIMES, they will surprise you with a free Thai Iced tea with you carry out order. At least, that happened to me once. So, yeah, thumbs up Sunflower. I love y'all.
author: Brittany B.

description: After eating the pho and the bun here... id have to say get the bun(vermicelli bowl).  The pho is nuthing special.  I was here last week and got the bun with bbq beef and imperial spring rolls... i added grilled shrimp for an extra dollar.  Usually the fish sauce they give you on the side doesnt seem enough so I ask for extra sauce.. I love my noodles and everything drenched with the sauce... unfortunately that same night my friends were saying how horrible my breath smelled like fish sauce when i met up with them at the bar!  I guess it really sticks to ya!
author: Jasen L.

description: Three words: Order the pho. Actually, the other stuff is good as well. This is my favorite pho place in SF. If there's a wait, don't linger after you've finished your food. They do a good job of keeping things moving.
author: Eric M.

description:
A cheap yet high quality place to eat in the Mission. I've been here a couple times. First time, I got the garlic noodles with chicken. Second time, I got the pork vermicelli with imperial rolls. 

Both were tasty. I definitely preferred the vermicelli to the garlic noodles. The garlic noodles were good, but they were... just noodles cooked with garlic. I was expecting a bit more, maybe, given the tremendous reviews on Yelp. Nothing out of this world. The vermicelli was a more varied collection of food. 

More notably, though, they were both huge portions for the price (both around $8.) As an individual, I had enough to eat half in the restaurant and take the rest back for the next day. Since this place is really close to my apartment, it's my safe spot for eating, whenever I'm too tired to find somewhere else.
author: Chris L.

description:
I love their Crepes, their Phos and their veggie dishes. I love their coffee, for me this is really the best vietnamese food I have had in SF. The only thing I really don't like is the attitude of the waiter in the big store on Valencia - I recommend going around the corner to the more-to-go-like-looking place - it's the same great food...!

I must say although I don't *neeeed* alcohol, I find it sad that they do not sell vietnamese beer anymore..
author: Sandra L.

description: Got togo the other day, it was a lot of food! Had the spicy beef lunch special, price is reasonable - came with some pickle veggies, soup, and the main pretty good. The place isn't really worth sitting down to eat at, great place to take back home or quick eat for lunch during work.
author: Dang L.

description: 6 dollars gets you two meals worth of food at this place! The pork vermcelli with spring rolls is AMAZING, as is their pho and Shaken Beef. Their waiters are all so nice and entertaining. During the day you get to hear singing in the kitchen (Vietnamese hymns) and at night they play 90's love songs, so classic. Is the restaurant fancy or a place to take a snobby bitch out on a date? No. Is it great, authentic food served by sweet, caring people? YES!
author: Deseray T.

description: Great food, enormous portions.  If you're going with two people, get the spring rolls and one entre to share and you'll still leave with a to-go box.  The two times I've been there they have been very under staffed, so go there with time on your hands and enjoy your company while you wait for them to get around to you.  Once they do, they are super helpful, accommodating, and friendly.  Even when busy they still made time to refill our water glasses many times.
author: Jim S.

description: Indecision usually results in disaster.  This evening, indecision led me to wander into the doorway of Sunflower "Authentic" Vietnamese Restaurant.  To limit my risk, I ordered plain old beef noodle pho.  My reasoning - if restaurants can't master the simple how can anything else be worthwhile. In this case, they barely received a passing grade. Not enough depth in the broth, but I've had worse.  Beef also a tad dry.  This place also lacks condiments, which is typical of most pho places. People are friendly enough, and this place seems to pack in the locals.  I'm glad the locals enjoy, but I think the "authenticity" is not quite there.
author: Gregory C.

description: Two entrances, one on Valencia and one on 16th Street. We ordered the Vietnamese vegetarian crepe - it came with lettuce, a spicy fish sauce, cucumbers and carrots. Inside the crepe were tofu and tons of bean sprouts...this was by far their best dish and I saw a ton of people sitting around me order it.  It got a bit messy, but they brought over extra napkins since I wrapped my crepe into the lettuce and drizzled the spicy sauce over it. I also had the beef pho which came in a huge pot and I barely finished it, partly because I was so full off of the crepe!  So good and the prices are reasonable.  The waiter was especially friendly.
author: Natalie S.

description: The waiter/host is one big fat SOB.  I thought he was just rude to me and my friend, but later saw that he was clearly intent on being an a-hole to just about everyone.  I will never return.
author: Shin C.

description:
love this joint.
cheap, fast, delicious. 

Dishes Dominated: 
03 Shrimp Spring Rolls :: Shrimp, vermicelli, peanut sauce  6.75 
22 Vermicelli Imperial Rolls ::  7.95 
25 Vermicelli B.B.Q. Pork (Lemongrass marinade) & Imperial Rolls ::  7.95 
42 Garlic Noodles :: Our house favorite, pan fried noodles with egg, garlic  7.75
author: Andy G.

description: This place is ok. I like pho- theirs isn't amazing but it can satisfy a craving, for fairly cheap. I like the Imperial Rolls alright. Also, I have vegetarian friends and it accommodates them too!
author: Kate A.

description:
Authentic, Delicious, and Cheap

Definitely more than you can say about the tranny hookers in the tendernob. And unlike the tranny hookers, this food goes down easy without hurting my pocketbook.

This place is one of the best Vietnamese places in the city. With 2 store fronts, the staff is friendly and helpful, and offer a different experience on each side. I love the food, I love the location, and I love the staff...Yum!!
author: Brian S.

description: Price isnt bad, the place is a bit small and dirty, but the food is awesome.  I wouldnt order PHO togo because it wouldnt taste the same.  My suggestion, order the meat, eggroll, and vermicille with the fish sauce.  mmm so good. That's my favorite.
author: Mimi S.

description: Mmmmmm I could live off of the garlic noodles from Sunflower. They are so good, so plentiful, and really cheap. I always come here with one of my girlfriends and we split the fresh spring rolls and an order of garlic noodles. We leave full, happy and not broke. Minus one star for all the fools that feel like they have to crowd in the restaurant while waiting for a table. Hello! Other people are trying to finish their meals and don't need your impatient ass in their face.
author: Vivienne L.

description: This is a nice neighborhood place that offers good food at a great price.  I give it four stars for a combination of value, quality, and service.  It's far from the best Vietnamese I've ever had, but it's good and hits the spot and very reasonably priced.  I had bbq pork over rice noodles with imperial rolls for under $8 with tax today.  You can't beat that.  Plus the wait staff is pleasant, efficient, and friendly.  A nice Mission joint without pretentiousness.
author: Paul S.

description: Perfect food to order out while watching Grey's Anatomy with friends!  I recommend the pan fried garlic fried noodles, Shaken Beef, Spicy Lemongrass Chicken with green beans and Beef Pho(noodle soup) with basil, lime and chili.
author: Stacy R.

description: I really dislike this place. I was kicked out promptly at 10pm after entering the restaurant at 9:45 and being assured we had enough time to eat. The waiter literally showed us to the door, making us leave most of our food and our drinks behind on the table. I will not return. The small amount of food I did eat can't compare to Le Cheval in the East Bay.
author: Mark H.

description: The food was delicious. The service was fast and friendly. The portions were very generous and the prices reasonable. I'll definitely go back there!
author: Velma G.

description: Awesome egg rolls and I hear the Pho is pretty good. The vermicelli and Bun you have to look no further around the city for this. Great little place to pick up and bring it home or chill in the cozy area. Prices are pretty cheap and for the food you can't get much better. If I had any knock (and it was slight) is that the wait service was a little all about business.
author: Eric R.

description:
in my quest for the perfect vietnamese restaurant i discovered this little gem in the mission. with two different locations on the same block i never have any trouble being seated and served quickly. always go for the thai iced tea, and spring roll appetizers. their rice vermicelli noodles and BBQ pork with imperial rolls are my usual, however any of their soups on a rainy/foggy day just warms you through and through. prices are ridiculously cheap, and i always leave with leftovers.
i'm starting to drool.......
author: Rachel R.

description: The pho here is pretty decent. Not the best ever, but definitely does the job if you're craving Vietnamese in the MIssion.
author: Ben E.

description: Best Spring Rolls Ever....so good. Their number is programmed in my phone!
author: Natalie D.

description: I'm a little in love with this place at the moment.  I've loved everything I've had, but the lemongrass chicken and the imperial rolls stick out in my mind.  When the nasty weather hits, this'll be the #1 spot for steamy pho!
author: Kyla B.

description: Sure, I'm not Vietnamese. Nor am I some sort of pho expert. I am, however, an expert at eating expertly grilled pork served on a bed of vermicelli, topped with a couple crispy, awesome imperial rolls. The service could be bit more on the speedy side, but whatever. How about you stop whining and sit still, talk to your friend for a couple minutes and enjoy your cheap, delicous food when it ends up on the table? I prefer the 16th street entrance, as the flourescent lighting scares away vampires.
author: Steven C.

description: Hmm, I've eaten here twice, and while it wasn't bad, I wasn't really all that impressed either.  Most of the food was kinda gloppy and really sauce laden, but maybe that's just the nature of vietnamese food, at least, in san francisco.  I kind of like the wrap-around layout, it adds a dimension of suspense if you're planning on meeting someone there. Nice, quriky waitstaff, too.
author: Ben V.

description: Really could not believe the kind of tasty food we got at this place for the price.  Four of us ate with two appetizers and two drinks for $54!!!!! Crazy for the price.  The only gripes I had was that we got one appetizer, then an entree, then another appetizer, then the rest of the entrees.  All of this was on a pretty crowded Saturday night.  Overall, I am definately coming back to this place given the value.
author: Matt W.

description:
What a great little find in the Mission. Met a vegan friend for dinner here and had a most delicious meal. The place is deceptive--from the outside it looks like just a nondescript hole in the wall, but on the inside it's actually quite cozy, quiet, and pleasant. The place is busy, but not so much that it feels crowded or noisy. The multi-page menu has tons of options, both vegetarian and not and includes lots of noodle dishes, soups, salads, stir-frys and appetizers. It was hard to decide what to order--the spring rolls sounded really good, as did the shrimp salad and the spicy green beans with portabello mushrooms. I was in a noodle mood so I ended up getting the vegetarian noodle soup which was a ginormous bowl heaping with a variety of tasty veggies, tofu, and thin rice noodles. My friend got the curry vegetable and had nothing but good things to say about it. A nice touch is they also offer brown rice--in fact, we had a laugh over my friend's brown rice bowl that was so brown it looked like a bowl of coffee grounds but tasted quite yummy.

The prices are really reasonable and it's close to BART & public transportation. But being the Mission it's a bitch to park there so plan your arrival time accordingly or be lucky enough to not have to drive there. I'll be back to try more dishes but hopefully without having to park in the area.
author: Megan K.

description: I've tried them all and this is simply the best damn pho in the city!! If you don't believe me then try it pho your own damn self.
author: Todd L.

description: SO goooood! I go here at least twice a month. My favorite thing to order is the veggie yellow curry. Love the brown rice here too.
author: Heather B.

description: Good down home Vietnamese food for a good price. The portions are grand and it's yummy.
author: SF N.

description:
Stopped in here for lunch the other day with a friend.  He ordered one of the lunch specials and I got a vermicelli noodle bowl.  We split an order of fresh spring rolls.  Service was really quick and the spring rolls were HUGE!!  Should have prepared us for what came next.  I don't know if I just wasn't particularly hungry that day or what, but the portions seemed Gigantic!!  Food was very tasty and enjoyable.  I felt bad asking for a to go box for more than half the food because the waiter asked if we didn't like the food.  Quite the contrary.  I would certainly go back if I'm craving Vietnamese in that neighborhood.
**Update:  Went back for lunch again and had to downgrade.  This time had the 5 spice chicken lunch special..hrmm.  Although the hot/sour soup that come with the lunch special was quite good, then chicken was very fatty with some gristle treasures hidden inside.  Might go back but wouldn't recommend that particular dish.
author: Jason M.

description: Had a pretty good papaya salad here, but it was luke warm...kinda weird. I prefer my salad to be crispy cold.
author: Yuchi C.

description: The beef pho hits the spot if you are under the weather. Not sure if they use real stewed beef broth or a mix, but it is flavorful enough even for someone with shot taste buds to be able to taste it.
author: Sue L.

description: The service I receive here is always fabulous,  the waiter loves and always remembers me (although I do think he is in love with my straight brother/ha!).  What I can tell you is this:  You will enjoy the spring rolls,  you will love the Viet crepe, and the lemon grass tofu is amazing.  The fact that they are also DIRT CHEAP helps a lot too.  Amazingly huge lunch special with a friend,  we each payed $11.00 including a $4.00 tip.
author: Matt G.

description: This place has some delicious options and I've always enjoyed their Vietnamese food - it's better than a botched circumcision, for example. It's not super fancy, and I've had one off experience, but it's great and worthwhile for Vietnamese.
author: Aris V.

description:
Went there this past Saturday and boy was i surprised. 

I had the 7.95 lunch special and it was awesome! Tons of food with great flavor and freshness.
author: J.B. A.

description: Pretty good Vietnamese food in the Mission, especially for the price. It's perfect for a casual dinner with friends. Writing this makes me want to go back and try it again because it's been awhile since I was last there.... It's the kind of restaurant that is good but doesn't necessary pull me back very often. It doesn't help that I am in love with Aux Delices at the moment.
author: Kimi W.

description: So it's been weeks since I've eaten at Sunflower, and I'm still marveling at how scrumptious the BBQ pork vermicelli with imperial rolls is.  Yum-my!  This is my benchmark dish at every Vietnamese pho place I go to, and Sunflower is now high on my list.  Lean, well-grilled pork, unusually crunchy and delicious imperial rolls, and plenty of fish sauce.  I often request an extra bowl of fish sauce for this dish (since I like to drown my noodles in it), and when I did so here, the waiter quickly and and happily obliged--even bringing a bowl for my dining partner--topped with a carrot garnish and a smile.  I look forward to going back.
author: Vivien W.

description: Very good garlic noodles (ask them to make it spicy and add some chicken).  Five spice chicken is also great here.
author: Manoj L.

description: One of the most affordable yet yummy places I know about, and very conveniently located at 16th and Valencia. I usually get the eggplant dish, and I know that the shaken beef is supposed to be fantastic. I've never heard anyone say they weren't happy with their food here. The server is very funny, a bit of a character. I would recommend the Valencia side of the restaurant over the Sixteeth side. Better ambiance.
author: Cyrelle D.

description: I had the worst experience here. I ordered a chicken dish that claimed to be boneless white meat and instead I got a disgusting plate of fat-filled dark meat chicken. Gross. I couldn't look at it; let alone eat it. I told the server it wasn't what the menu stated and he said I "didn't know Vietnamese food," and refused to exchange it. I asked for the check, left a $20 bill to cover $11 worth of drinks, appetizer, and rude service and left. I walked away quickly, feeling that it was the kind of place where I could expect a server to run after us claiming we'd stiffed them. I still cringe when I walk by.
author: Dora A.

description: We use this place when we have large groups of friends over for dinner.  Super inexpensive way to feed a large group of people and everyone loves it...the fare doubles as munchies for those who want to go lite and some hearty dishes for those who need a meal.   The service has always been excellent...people on the phone are really helpful figuring out selection for a big group.   Another review names 16th street location as good service, Valencia street sucks. That's been our experience, too.
author: James B.

description: Basic food for a simple lunch. Met my GF for lunch and we ordered Imperial Rolls, Chicken noodle soup and the Vietnamese crepe. Everything was tasty, but the crepe was a bit greaser than I remember--but wait that was Slanted Door's crepe--but i would go back to Sunflower and try other stuff--missed out on the garlic noodles--next time.
author: Deborah S.

description:
The waiter is riot.  In the story of my life he will undoubtedly have a cameo.  Every time I stop into Sunflower for dinner I have the "pleasure" of being waited on by the same guy who sets and serves tables as if he were on crack.  This guy has some serious need for speed.  He is constantly flying around the room and I think he's so focused on waiting and cleaning that he forgets what he is doing sometimes.  Last night  we had brought some papers with us to dinner and laid them on the table.  Lo and behold, he wizzes by to pick them up and throw them in the trash.  Way to keep it clean buddy!  Thanks for throwing away my super important documents.  Yet he still takes the time to shake his butt when he walks.  It's nice to see he's got priorities.  The only real difficulty from his fast paced serving style is that he is in such a hurry that he often says "Thank you" before you've even finished completing your order.    It goes sort of like this....

"Hi can I get a Chai iced tea and...
-"Tank youuuuu."  Waiter starts to walk off.
"Oh but could I also get an order of spring rolls"
-"One order spring rolls."  Tank youuuuu."  Begins to walk away again.
"Wait, wait, and an order of beef pho as well?"
-"Numba too.  Tank youuuuu."  Finally moves on like lightening to another table.

As for the food... it's pretty decent and dependable.  It doesn't wow me, but it's always there when I need it.
author: Dubs W.

description:
I love this place! The food is really delicious.  I always want to fill up on the appetizers, namely the Fresh Spring rolls and the Vegetarian Vietnamese Crepe.  After trying the crepe here I've tried it elsewhere and nothing has been as good!

They have two locations near corner of 16th and Valencia.  One is at 3111 16th St between Valencia & Guerrero.  The other is around the corner at 506 Valencia St between 16th and 17th st.  The menu is the same, and they might even share a kitchen.  This is good to know since sometimes there are free tables at one when there is a line at the other location.

The service is good and friendly in both locations, especially the younger, flamboyant guy in the Valencia spot.  The atmosphere is better at the Valencia location, but 16th St has that hole-in-the-wall feel, if you are into that.

I think they do good takeout business out of the 16th St location, but I've only eaten in so far.
author: Jared D.

description: their lunch special is DANK. like seven bucks for a giant ass bowl of vermiceli topped with whatever you want, plus it comes with delicious salad and sweet & sour soup. imperial rolls are a must as well. it's totally cramped and hot and celine dion is always playing, but it's part of the experience.
author: Monika S.

description:
The food is okay and they have a lot of items on the menu. For the prices I would expect a little better lighting though.

I don't like the cramped seating and how you reek of the oil/grease smell afterwards.
author: Retired B.

description: Yuck, I wasn't impressed at all by this place.  The chicken was very, very fatty and I couldn't finish it.  Our drinks were forgotten, and we had to ask for them.  The salad rolls didn't taste very fresh.  I have had much better Vietnamese food for the same price elsewhere.  The worst was when we tipped 13% on a meal that sucked for 2 people.  The waiter actually brought back the check and demanded we tip 15%. I wont be going back here.
author: Greg D.
